site_title: Punchlines: Sep 1, 2015
summary: There is no article content provided.

site_title: GE2015: Independent candidate Tan Lam Siong pulls out of Potong Pasir
summary: Independent candidate Tan Lam Siong has withdrawn from the Potong Pasir SMC election, reducing the likelihood of a three-cornered fight. He cited a personal encounter with incumbent Sitoh Yih Pin, where he felt sorry for her and recalled her recent statement about retiring from politics. Tan will now support Sitoh, while challenger Lina Chiam of the Singapore People's Party remains in the running, and independent candidate Zeng Guoyan has also announced his intention to run.

site_title: Completed China Cultural Centre to boost arts exchange
summary: The 11-storey China Cultural Centre in Singapore has been completed, featuring a 240-seat theatre and various facilities, including a library, classrooms, and a multi-purpose hall. The centre, costing over $44 million, will host a series of pre-launch programmes, including a writers' forum with five renowned Chinese novelists. The centre aims to foster cultural exchanges between China and Singapore, with plans to promote Chinese culture and boost soft power abroad. Its official opening is expected to be hosted by top leaders from both countries later this year.

images.alt_text: The 11-storey China Cultural Centre (above), located between a hotel and an HDB block, cost more than 200 million yuan (S$44 million) and took over two years to build.

site_title: Woman held over fatal knife attack on husband in Bukit Panjang flat
summary: A 26-year-old woman, Vivien Teoh, has been arrested and charged with murder after allegedly stabbing her 33-year-old husband, Gordon Yeo, to death in their Bukit Panjang flat. The attack occurred in the couple's master bedroom, leaving Yeo with multiple injuries. The couple, who had a 14-month-old daughter, were married for nearly two years and had a seemingly happy life. Police received a call for help at 1am and Yeo was pronounced dead at 1:19am. Teoh was taken to hospital with slight injuries and is being held in custody as investigations continue.

images.alt_text: Police officers leaving the couple's Senja Road flat yesterday morning. The couple have been married for close to two years and have a 14-month-old daughter. Police have classified the case as murder.

site_title: Breast-feeding tips for working mums
summary: Working mothers can successfully breastfeed in the workplace with supportive employers and colleagues. Key steps include discussing milk expression with the employer, identifying a private space with necessary amenities, and using a good-quality breast pump. Mothers can also benefit from having a supportive network of colleagues and a comfortable lactation space. Additionally, continuing to express milk frequently and nursing the baby at night can help increase milk supply. By taking these steps, working mothers can overcome common hurdles and successfully breastfeed their babies in the workplace.

images.alt_text: Mothers breast-feeding their babies in a commuter train as part of World Breast-feeding Week last month. Supportive employers and colleagues, as well as having a private space in the office, are factors that help make the breast-feeding journey successful

site_title: We will never turn away those who need protection: EU commissioner
summary: EU Vice-President Frans Timmermans announced that Europe will not turn away migrants seeking asylum, pledging an additional 5 million euros to help France manage the thousands of migrants in Calais. French Prime Minister Manuel Valls called for more EU countries to assist, criticizing those who refuse to contribute to the effort. Valls also proposed deploying European border guards and creating a common list of "safe" countries to limit asylum applications. EU interior ministers will meet on September 14 to discuss strengthening the European response to the migration challenge.

site_title: Residents flag off community walk
summary: Residents from Marine Parade GRC took part in a community walk, part of an islandwide event celebrating Singapore's golden jubilee. Approximately 3,000 residents formed the Singapore flag and walked to Gardens by the Bay, as part of the One Community Walk, which involved around 100,000 participants at 70 venues. The event promoted community bonding and raised $100,000 for local charities, with participants encouraged to exercise and spend time together. The walk was seen as a meaningful way to celebrate the nation's milestone.

images.alt_text: Residents from Marine Parade GRC took a scenic stroll to Gardens by the Bay on Sunday as part of an islandwide event.

site_title: US President Barack Obama takes climate drive to Alaska
summary: US President Barack Obama visited Alaska to highlight the impact of climate change, delivering a speech at an international conference on the Arctic. He aims to build support for an international pact to curb warming, despite Republican skepticism about human-caused climate change. During his visit, Obama announced the renaming of Mount McKinley to Denali, sparking opposition from some Republicans. He also met with native leaders and received survival tips from TV host Bear Grylls. The visit comes ahead of the UN's COP21 conference in December, which seeks to cap global temperature increases by two degrees Celsius.

site_title: Keen to champion issues faced by Malays here
summary: Singapore Democratic Party candidate Mr. Abu Mohamed, 64, a co-director of an oilfield services company and president of the Singapore Malay National Organisation, is running for office. He aims to champion issues faced by the Malay population, including education, employment, healthcare, and hijab issues. Mohamed, who has a heart for the people and solutions, emphasizes that his team is not seeking recognition but rather to drive solutions to problems like the cost of living and population growth. His focus will be on addressing the Malay community's concerns.

site_title: HK retail sales fall for fifth month as tourism slows, stocks slump
summary: Hong Kong retail sales declined 2.8% in July from a year earlier, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline, as tourism slowed and the stock market slump hurt consumer sentiment. The number of visitors to Hong Kong fell 8.4% in July, with mainland Chinese tourists experiencing a 9.8% decline. Sales of big-ticket items such as jewelry and watches plummeted, while medicines, cosmetics, and apparel also saw significant drops. The government expects weak sentiment to persist for the rest of the year, citing the impact of slowing tourism and increased stock market volatility.

site_title: Video shows ISIS burning four Iraqi Shiite fighters alive
summary: ISIS has released a video showing the gruesome burning alive of four Iraqi Shiite fighters, suspended from chains by their hands and feet, in what the militant group claims is revenge for alleged burning of its members by pro-government forces. The victims were from the Popular Mobilisation forces in southern Iraq. The video, attributed to the ISIS media unit, is the latest in a series of atrocities claimed by the group, including mass executions and targeting of minorities. The incident highlights ongoing violence in western Iraq under ISIS control.

site_title: GE2015: Contests expected in all 89 seats today
summary: The 2015 Singapore General Election (GE2015) is set to see contests in all 89 seats, a first since Singapore's independence in 1965. The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its entire slate for every group representation constituency (GRC) and single-member constituency (SMC) in advance, potentially reducing surprises. The Workers' Party (WP), led by Low Thia Khiang, may focus on protecting its seven seats rather than expanding aggressively. Key contests are expected in Fengshan, Sengkang West, and East Coast GRC, where the WP is expected to challenge the PAP. The election will see a record 178 candidates, with the highest number of parties contesting.

images.alt_text: The Singapore People's Party will take the challenge to the PAP in Potong Pasir SMC, where Mr Sitoh Yih Pin (left) will defend his seat, and in Mountbatten SMC, where Mrs Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss (right) will face incumbent Lim Biow Chuan.

The Singapore People's Party will take the challenge to the PAP in Potong Pasir SMC, where Mr Sitoh Yih Pin (left) will defend his seat, and in Mountbatten SMC, where Mrs Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss (right) will face incumbent Lim Biow Chuan.

site_title: Singapore, Egypt hail longstanding ties
summary: Singapore and Egypt are set to strengthen ties as they mark the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations next year. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and Singapore President Tony Tan Keng Yam welcomed their longstanding friendship and cooperation opportunities during al-Sisi's first state visit. The two countries have a long history of maritime links, with the 1869 Suez Canal opening benefiting Singapore's port. They agreed to enhance cooperation in education, water management, and port development, and signed a memorandum of understanding for an integrated water and power project in Egypt.

images.alt_text: Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, with Singapore President Tony Tan Keng Yam, inspecting the guard of honour during a welcome ceremony at the Istana yesterday. Mr Sisi is on his first state visit here.

site_title: Handy way to pay for bus and train rides goes on trial
summary: The Land Transport Authority in Singapore has launched a six-month trial to test a wristband that can replace the ez-link card for bus and train rides. The wristband, encoded with a digital Cepas chip, allows users to top up stored value and track transactions via Bluetooth. The trial, involving 200 commuters, aims to test the technology's effectiveness in improving efficiency, but transport expert Park Byung Joon notes that actual improvement depends on user adoption. The wristband's ability to simplify payment and provide real-time tracking may enhance the commuting experience, but its long-term impact remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: The Sony wristband that can replace the ez-link card is encoded with a digital Cepas chip, and allows users to establish a Bluetooth connection to check their value balance and transactions while on the go. The six-month trial starts today.

site_title: Rugby union: Political party taking court action over Boks' World Cup participation
summary: A South African political party, the Agency for New Agenda (ANA), is taking court action against the government to prevent the Springboks from participating in the World Cup in England and Wales due to allegations of favoring white players. The ANA claims rugby is a "white-man's sport" that excludes and marginalizes the majority black population. Despite this, the team's coach has named a 31-man squad with nine black players. The court application, set to be heard on September 2, seeks to force the team to surrender their passports and order a commission of inquiry into the lack of transformation in South African rugby.

site_title: Concerned about retirement issues and approach to economy
summary: Singapore Workers' Party candidate Leon Perera, 44, a CEO of a business research and consulting agency, has announced his candidacy for the upcoming election. He aims to focus on retirement adequacy and ageing issues, as well as holistic economic development that prioritizes quality of life. Perera, who holds a Bachelor of Philosophy, Politics and Economics from Oxford University, believes taking citizenship seriously and shaping the country's system to reflect citizens' values is essential. He emphasizes the importance of ageing actively and with dignity, and seeks to address economic development beyond GDP.

site_title: Dubai gold retailer defaults on $191m, banks consider options
summary: A Dubai-based gold and jewellery retailer, Atlas Jewellery, has defaulted on loans worth approximately $191.4 million, leaving banks considering options including legal action. The non-payment affects at least 15 banks and has sparked a meeting among banks to discuss recovery options. The UAE's insolvency laws make it challenging for lenders to seek legal redress, and banks are exploring alternatives, including taking control of Atlas's healthcare business. The company's owner, M.M. Ramachandran, has been arrested on suspicion of bounced cheques, adding to the complexity of the situation.

site_title: Man jailed for threatening girlfriend, kicking policemen
summary: A 50-year-old unemployed man, Ivan Vincent, was jailed six months for threatening his 30-year-old girlfriend with a knife and kicking two policemen. He admitted to three charges, including threatening to kill his girlfriend and kicking Station Inspector Goh and Sergeant Shahril. The incident occurred when Vincent became agitated and violent after his girlfriend refused to get up to find money. He was restrained by the officers and subsequently arrested for disorderly behavior and criminal intimidation.

site_title: GE2015: Catch The Straits Times' live coverage of the coming general election
summary: Singapore's general election is set to be the most hotly contested polls in recent history, with all 89 seats likely to be challenged. The Straits Times will provide round-the-clock coverage, including live updates on Nomination Day (Sept 1), election rallies (Sept 1-9), and Polling Day (Sept 11). Readers can access live coverage, videos, graphics, and commentaries on The Straits Times' dedicated GE2015 site (straitstimes.com/GE2015) and through various social media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp.

site_title: No time to waste? Check the way you work
summary: A recent kitchen competition at Jurong Point highlighted the importance of efficient work methods in cooking. Judges evaluated contestants based on both cooking skills and time-saving techniques. Participants who relied on common sense and tools, such as whisks and basins, performed better than those who used inefficient methods, like mixing batter with a frying ladle. Effective techniques include using multiple whisks, rinsing utensils in a basin, and using cutting sheets to prevent cross-contamination. These methods save time and reduce waste, making them essential for quick and successful kitchen work.

site_title: GE2015: Singapore People's Party candidate Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss unveils manifesto for Mountbatten
summary: Singapore People's Party candidate Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss unveiled a manifesto for Mountbatten, a single-seat ward, ahead of the upcoming general election. The 52-year-old lawyer proposed plans to establish a Mountbatten Social Mobility bursary, conserve Dakota Crescent, and make Mountbatten a more affordable and community-driven area. Chong-Aruldoss, who has previously run under the National Solidarity Party banner, has the full backing of the SPP and emphasized her commitment to the constituency.

site_title: Malaysia police to release four arrested at Bersih rally
summary: Malaysian police announced that four men arrested during the Bersih 4 rally will be released on Monday. The arrests were made for separate incidents, including hurling firecrackers at the crowd and engaging in an obscene act. A scuffle broke out after a protester threw firecrackers at Bersih 4 protesters, injuring four. Police arrived to calm the situation, and the arrested individuals and injured protesters received medical attention. The release comes after the arrests sparked concerns about police handling of the rally.

summary: Singaporean MP Sitoh Yih Pin has announced his campaign slogan and 5-year plan for Potong Pasir, his constituency. His slogan, "1 vision to actively improve Potong Pasir, working 2gether to unite the community and better the lives of 3 generations," aims to unite the community and improve lives of residents. Sitoh has completed over 120 projects and plans to launch an anti-bird barrier system to solve the 31-year-old problem of pigeons seeking shelter in the sloping roof design of Housing Board flats.

site_title: US weighs China sanctions after cyber hack
summary: The US is considering economic sanctions against Chinese firms and individuals that profited from cyber attacks on American targets. Following a series of cyber attacks blamed on China, the administration plans to respond "in a manner and timeframe of our choosing". The sanctions would target those who profited from cyber attacks and could also be aimed at countering unfair economic advantages gained through illegal intelligence gathering. The move comes amid growing tensions between the two nations and amid concerns about national security.

site_title: Seeing black dots after having cataract surgery
summary: A 60-year-old man experienced black dots, resembling 20 small flies, after cataract surgery three weeks ago. The floaters, caused by posterior vitreous detachment, are usually not a cause for concern and tend to subside over several months. However, a consultation with an eye doctor is recommended to rule out a retina tear or detachment. The condition is a common complication after cataract surgery, and monitoring the situation is advised. Floaters result from the degeneration of vitreous fluid in the eye, which can be a normal aging process.

site_title: Plugging the leak in the eye
summary: Seventy-year-old Alan was diagnosed with vision-threatening severe proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which can lead to blindness if left untreated. Diabetic retinopathy is a common complication of diabetes, affecting 180,000 out of 600,000 diabetics in Singapore, but only 30,000 have been diagnosed. Early detection and prompt treatment, such as laser surgery, can preserve vision. Alan underwent scatter laser treatment, which involved up to 2,000 laser burns, and has since kept his vision and made lifestyle changes to manage his diabetes. Regular eye screening is crucial to prevent complications.

site_title: The magic of the mushroom
summary: This article highlights the health benefits of mushrooms, particularly maitake and buna shimeji. Rich in vitamins, minerals, and dietary fibre, mushrooms can help relieve stress, depression, and fatigue. They are also low in calories, fat, and sodium, making them an ideal addition to meals. Maitake mushrooms, in particular, have been found to stimulate the immune system and may have anti-cancer properties. The article also provides a simple recipe for a maitake and buna shimeji mushroom salad, showcasing the versatility and nutritional value of these fungi.

site_title: Two men to appear in court for errant driving
summary: Two men, aged 25 and 26, will appear in court on September 3 on charges of dangerous driving and participating in an unauthorized speed trial. They were caught in a joint operation by the Traffic Police and Land Transport Authority along Seletar Link, where one of them was driving at over 140km/h, exceeding the 60km/h speed limit. Convictions can result in fines of up to $3,000, prison terms of up to 12 months, or both, and confiscation of their vehicles.

site_title: BOC Aviation taps cash-rich Japan banks for $422 mln loan
summary: Singapore-based BOC Aviation has secured a $422 million syndicated loan with 18 Japanese banks ahead of a potential rise in US interest rates. The unsecured financing, led by Development Bank of Japan, is the latest in a series of deals by the aircraft lessor. BOC Aviation, the world's fifth largest lessor, aims to secure funding for 195 aircraft on order, which have deliveries through the early next decade. The loan is part of the lessor's efforts to diversify its funding sources and capitalize on the current liquidity in the Japanese banking system.

site_title: India's top court suspends ban on Jains fasting to death
summary: India's Supreme Court has temporarily lifted a ban on the traditional Jain ritual of Santhara, or fasting to death. The ban was imposed after a court in Rajasthan ruled that Santhara was a form of suicide, which is illegal in India. Thousands of Jains protested the ban, claiming it violated their constitutional rights to practice their religion. The court's decision gives the Jain community time to make a full hearing into the matter, and community leaders welcomed the ruling, stating that "our principles have won."

site_title: Abnormally heavy menstruation? See the doc
summary: Abnormally heavy menstrual bleeding, or menorrhagia, occurs when menstrual flow exceeds two pads per day or lasts more than a week. Symptoms include using multiple pads/hours, waking up to change pads, passing blood clots, and anaemia symptoms. Dr. Cynthia Kew, a consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist, warns that menorrhagia can be caused by hormone imbalance, uterine fibroids, pregnancy complications, cancer, and certain medications. Various treatments, including oral medications, progesterone injections, and surgery, are available, but may impact fertility. Early evaluation by a gynaecologist is crucial to rule out serious underlying conditions.

site_title: Indonesian workers to stage mass protest for higher wages, against layoffs
summary: Indonesian workers are staging a mass protest against job cuts and for higher wages, with up to 100,000 layoffs expected this year. The protest, involving 50,000 workers in Jakarta, comes as the country's economy struggles with slow growth and high inflation. The government plans to introduce a stimulus package with tax incentives for industries, but unions demand regulations to protect workers' purchasing power. The protest marks pressure on the government to address labor issues, with unemployment rates estimated to be much higher than the official 5.81%.

site_title: Paying for your ride? It's all in the wrist
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has launched a six-month trial using Sony SmartBands with NFC technology to pay for public transport rides. 200 commuters will wear the wristbands, which can be topped up and checked using the Singtel mWallet app. The device uses Near Field Communication to pay for fares, similar to Hong Kong's successful payment system. The trial aims to increase mobility and convenience for commuters, with the possibility of widespread adoption in the future.

site_title: Falling tree crashes into balcony, injuring boy
summary: An 11-year-old boy, Sheik Sheqal Muhd Fazel, was injured when a 10-storey tree crashed into his grandparents' balcony in Pasir Ris, Singapore. The tree, estimated to be over 20 years old, fell due to heavy rainfall and strong winds, causing significant damage to three units and injuring Sheik Sheqal on the head. He was taken to hospital for outpatient checks and is expected to recover. The town council plans to make insurance claims for replacement windows and is considering removing similar trees in the area for safety measures.

site_title: First batch of pilgrims head for Mecca
summary: The first group of 43 Singaporean pilgrims departed for Mecca, Saudi Arabia, early this morning to perform the annual haj. Led by a 21-member delegation, the group will be accompanied by medical professionals. A total of 680 Singaporeans are expected to make the pilgrimage this year, with subsequent groups leaving between September 15 and 18. The event was seen off by the Mufti of Singapore and officials from the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore.

site_title: Bizview: Today's top business news
summary: Singapore's total bank lending rose 0.59% in July, driven by stronger demand for property loans and commerce sector loans, but the monthly growth eased. Keppel Corp acquired LeTourneau jackup rig designs for $141 million, while Frasers Centrepoint Ltd rebranded Australand as Frasers Property Australia. Meanwhile, two adjoining Chinatown shophouses are up for sale, and the yen and euro are seen as havens from global market uncertainties, including China's economic slowdown and a possible US interest-rate increase.

site_title: Charges for intensifying use of land in Singapore are mostly unchanged
summary: Singapore's development charge rates remain unchanged for six months, except for industrial use, which was cut by an average of 3% due to the exception of 87 out of 118 sectors. The cuts apply to areas like Kaki Bukit, Simei, Boon Lay, and Jurong West, with the largest decrease at 4%. The rates for other land uses, including commercial, residential, and hotel/hospital uses, remain unchanged.

site_title: Changing realities for today's youth
summary: The article reflects on the changing realities for today's youth, particularly teenagers, who are growing up in a vastly different world from those who came before them. The author reminisces about their own childhood experiences, which were marked by playfulness, friendships, and part-time jobs. In contrast, the article highlights the need for "externships" to bring real-world training to students between 13 and 16, mirroring the SkillsFuture initiative. This approach aims to equip young people with practical skills to tackle tomorrow's challenges, with the hope that future generations will have a more fulfilling and skill-based upbringing.

site_title: Austria orders migrants from trains at Hungarian border
summary: Austrian security forces halted two trains with hundreds of migrants near the Hungarian border, stopping them from entering Austria despite some having valid train tickets and papers. The migrants, mostly from Syria, were among 2,000 people stuck in makeshift camps in Budapest. Austria is in close contact with Hungary and Germany authorities, with migrants who had been registered in Hungary to be returned to Budapest. The decision follows criticism of Germany's eased asylum rules, with Hungary demanding clarification on the legal situation.

site_title: Eurozone inflation steady at 0.2% in August
summary: Eurozone inflation remained steady at 0.2% in August, exceeding analyst expectations. Core inflation held at 1%, and the eurozone's inflation rate is expected to average 0.3% this year before improving to 1.5% in 2016. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program aims to revive consumer-price growth, and policy makers are prepared to do more if needed. The ECB's goal is to achieve inflation of just under 2% to combat anemic growth.

site_title: Aiming to unlock pioneers' CPF savings
summary: Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) candidate Mr. Ong Teik Seng, 44, aims to unlock pioneers' CPF savings and restore the 20% employer's CPF contribution rate, which was reduced to 12% during the Asian financial crisis. As a sales director and married father of three, Ong seeks to address the issue of stagnant wages and help pioneer citizens make the most of their CPF savings. His platform focuses on supporting Singaporean workers and restoring the employer's CPF contribution rate, which he believes is a long-overdue change.

site_title: Ashley Madison owner says site still adding users after data hack
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people signed up for Ashley Madison in the last week, despite a data hack that leaked millions of users' information. The site's parent company, Avid Life Media, denied reports that the site had few genuine female users, citing internal data that showed over 2.8 million messages sent by women and 87,596 new female sign-ups. The company also announced that CEO Noel Biderman had left by mutual agreement, as the site continues to attract new users.

site_title: School sports: Bowen girls thrash Greenview 5-1 in C Division football final
summary: Bowen Secondary School's girls football team defeated Greenview Secondary 5-1 in the C Division football final on Aug 31, 2015, at Serangoon Stadium. The defending champions scored three goals in the opening 10 minutes, with Nikki Nur Jannah securing the win with a brace in the second half. The victory avenged a previous 1-3 loss to Greenview in the tournament, as Bowen secured their second consecutive C Division title.

site_title: S'pore becomes venue for settling sea disputes
summary: Singapore has become a venue for settling disputes under the Law of the Sea, following the signing of a joint declaration with the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (Itlos). The declaration allows the tribunal to hold proceedings in Singapore, utilizing the country's facilities. This move demonstrates Singapore's commitment to the international rule of law and its role in promoting peaceful dispute resolution in the region. The agreement was signed by Singapore's Ministry of Law and Itlos' president Vladimir Golitsyn, solidifying the country's position as a neutral venue for international disputes.

site_title: Seeking a platform to air views rationally, constructively
summary: Singapore Democratic Party candidate Wong Way Weng, a 53-year-old quality assurance manager, is seeking a platform to air his views rationally and constructively. With over 25 years of experience in shipping and logistics, Wong aims to shape people's lives and address issues such as population and employment. A diploma and master's degree holder, Wong is also an avid runner and believes effective communication is key to representing residents' concerns. He plans to focus on population and employment as his key issues.

site_title: United Nations climate talks begin divided, but with hope for Paris accord
summary: The United Nations climate talks began in Bonn, Germany, with senior officials aiming to cut an 83-page draft text by November 30-December 11 in Paris. Experts say chances of a successful agreement are brighter than in 2009, with the US and China more engaged. The draft text includes voluntary offers to cut greenhouse gas emissions, and ambitions for a fix to climate change are lower. The Paris summit will be a step towards a long-term goal of limiting global temperature rise to 2 degrees Celsius, with a focus on action from 2015-2020.

site_title: Football: Signing coup as Athletic Club Bilbao capture Garcia's services for $15.8 million
summary: Athletic Club Bilbao has signed attacking midfielder Raul Garcia from Atletico Madrid for $15.8 million. Garcia, 29, joins the Basque region-born player pool and has previously scored 66 goals in the Primera Liga. He signs a four-year contract, leaving Atletico after seven titles, with hopes of securing a spot in the Spain squad for the European Championships. Garcia aims to add bite to Athletic, who have relied on Aritz Aduriz's goals. The signing follows Bilbao's recent Spanish Supercup win and Europa League group stage qualification.

site_title: Dangerous driving: 2 suspects to face court
summary: Two men, aged 25 and 26, will appear in court on charges of dangerous driving and participating in an unauthorised speed trial. They were caught in a joint operation by the Traffic Police and Land Transport Authority on New Year's Eve and New Year's Day after speeding on Seletar Link at over 140km/h. They face fines of up to $3,000, jail of up to 12 months, or both, and potentially six months in prison and $2,000 in fines if convicted. Vehicles involved in the offence may also be confiscated.

site_title: India's economy grows by 7% in first quarter
summary: India's economy grew by 7.0% in the first quarter, slower than expected, according to official figures. This marks a slowdown from the previous quarter's 7.5% growth rate. Analysts attribute the decline to the government's efforts to boost growth, citing stalled initiatives and sluggish new investments. The slower growth rate has raised concerns about the right-wing government's ability to revive Asia's third-largest economy, which had previously overtaken China's growth in the first three months of 2015.

summary: The general election in Singapore is set to begin with the opening of nomination centers, including Raffles Institution, where Workers' Party (WP) bigwigs Low Thia Khiang and Sylvia Lim are expected to defend their Aljunied GRC seat. The People's Action Party (PAP) is also fielding a team led by veteran MP Yeo Guat Kwang in the constituency. The election is expected to be a close fight, with many seats contested for the first time since Singapore's independence.

Investors were cautious amid worries over China's slowdown and continued turbulence in global markets, with the Tokyo and Shanghai exchanges also falling. The Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates remained unclear, and analysts predicted downside risks for commodity prices, exchange rates, and stock markets to persist.

site_title: CCTVs reduce illegal parking cases
summary: CCTV cameras have reduced illegal parking cases by up to 90% in Singapore, improving traffic flow near MRT stations and major roads. The cameras, first introduced last year, are now operating at 70 locations across the island, with the number of summonses per location decreasing from 30 to three. Motorists and bus drivers have reported improved journey experiences, with fewer complaints about illegally parked vehicles and better flow of traffic, especially near MRT stations. The Land Transport Authority plans to deploy cameras at 60 more locations over the next two years.

site_title: China to open high-speed rail link to North Korean border
summary: China is set to open a high-speed rail link to the North Korean border on Thursday, connecting the cities of Shenyang and Dandong. The 207 km line, under construction since 2010, will reduce travel time from 3.5 hours to under one hour and boost economic ties between the two countries. The rail line will primarily benefit trade between China and North Korea, with up to 80% of trade passing through Dandong. The move aims to enhance the region's economic competitiveness, despite strained relations between China and North Korea.

site_title: Shedding light on night sweats
summary: A 75-year-old woman experiences excessive night sweats, sweating her chest, back, and head while sleeping, and frequent urination. After visiting a traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) physician, who prescribed dried herbs, the problem recurred. TCM practitioners link night sweats to kidney, lung, and spleen imbalances. Common causes include kidney function decline, lung qi weakness, and spleen dysfunction. Remedies include dietary changes, herbal supplements, and lifestyle adjustments, such as avoiding cold, spicy, and oily foods, and staying up late. Regular exercise and avoiding diuretic medications can also help alleviate symptoms.

site_title: At least 4 firms double paternity leave for staff
summary: At least four major Singaporean companies, including Singtel and DBS, have implemented double paternity leave for their staff, allowing up to two weeks of paid leave for working fathers of newborn children. The scheme, announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, applies to Singaporean children born from January 1 this year and can be taken within 12 months. The government will pay for the extra week of leave, which is now voluntary for employers.

site_title: Toshiba delays annual results again as more accounting errors found
summary: Toshiba Corp has delayed announcing its annual financial results for the second time, citing more accounting errors discovered after a scandal was uncovered, which may cost US$1.2 billion. The company had previously delayed results by three months due to an independent investigation into past accounting practices, which found Toshiba overstated results by around US$1.2 billion over several years, prompting CEO and executives to step down. Toshiba plans to submit results by September 7 and has taken impairment charges of 127 billion yen for the past financial year.

site_title: White supremacist aiming to kill Jews convicted in 3 Kansas murders
summary: Frazier Glenn Cross, a 74-year-old white supremacist, was found guilty of murdering three people, including a 14-year-old boy and his grandfather, outside two Jewish centers in Kansas in April 2014. Cross, who acted as his own attorney, admitted to the killings and stated he was motivated by a desire to protect the white gentile race from Jewish power. He faces the possibility of the death penalty.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang Academy joins training pool
summary: Eu Yan Sang Academy, a non-profit institution, has joined the training pool for Continuing Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) Education (CTE) courses. Since its incorporation in June last year, at least 207 physicians have attended courses, with 111 staff members and 96 external physicians. The academy aims to elevate standards, educate patients, and reach out to Western doctors to demystify TCM. Courses cover topics such as cancer management, recurrent miscarriage, and infertility, with fees ranging from $540 to $1,080 for electives.

site_title: Going round in circles over toxic smoke
summary: A Singaporean taxi driver, Gerald Neo, has reported that his taxi frequently leaks toxic smoke into the interior, despite multiple trips to the workshop and reports to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and National Environment Agency (NEA). The problem remains unresolved, affecting Neo's health, causing dizziness and chest discomfort. Neo is seeking assistance from authorities to address the issue, which he believes requires urgent attention to ensure public safety and driver well-being.

site_title: GE2015: AHPETC will have surplus of $1.7m once it receives Govt grant, says Sylvia Lim in letter to residents
summary: Workers' Party chairman Sylvia Lim has written to residents of Aljunied, Hougang, and Punggol East, assuring them that the town council, Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC), is in a strong financial position. Despite recording an annual deficit in its latest audited accounts, the town council expects to receive a $7.2m government grant, resulting in an annual surplus of $1.7m once received. Lim attributed the deficit to higher tender prices and start-up costs, and stated that steps taken by AHPETC have improved its financial position.

The US Open began with drama on the Flushing Meadows hardcourts, setting the stage for a thrilling tournament.

site_title: Soap, rinse, repeat - 40 times a day
summary: Individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) may experience repetitive behaviors, such as excessive hand washing, due to anxiety and brain processing issues. OCD affects 1 in 33 people worldwide, with 100-200 children and adolescents treated annually in Singapore. The condition is linked to anxious temperament, family history, stressors, and low serotonin levels. Treatment strategies include "exposure and response prevention" and support from caregivers and educators, who can help patients overcome their OCD symptoms.

site_title: Migrant trains arrive in Austria as 20,000 protest over migrant truck tragedy
summary: Austria welcomed migrant trains with 20,000 protesters in support, as Europe grapples with the largest movement of people since WWII. The trains, carrying hundreds of migrants, arrived in Vienna after Hungary allowed them to bypass the city's refugee camps. The crisis has divided the EU, with Western leaders calling for more help, while countries on the eastern border struggle to cope. The deaths of 71 migrants in an abandoned truck near the Hungarian border have led to a security crackdown and calls for EU funding for countries refusing to take their share of migrants.

summary: Singaporean candidates are gearing up for their election campaigns, with concerns over rising cost of living, job opportunities, affordable public housing, and the impact of foreign workers competing for jobs. The article emphasizes the importance of responsible voting and appeals to Singaporeans to prioritize quality policies over personal interests.

site_title: WP town council problems 'set to be key election issue'
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) town council management is expected to be a key election issue in Singapore's upcoming polls. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) plans to focus on municipal issues to counter the opposition's argument that more opposition MPs in Parliament will make the government more responsive. Meanwhile, the WP is likely to emphasize its performance in managing the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council, which has been plagued by problems. The opposition may also highlight the PAP's alleged changes after the 2011 general election, emphasizing the need for checks and balances on the government.

site_title: HSA warns public against dangerous cosmetic products
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore is warning the public about three Shantique Bellaza cosmetic products containing undeclared prohibited ingredients, including mercury and hydroquinone. The products, SB Facial Fuel Toner Mezzo, SB UV Pro Day Cream Mezzo, and SB Rejuvenating Night Cream Mezzo, can cause unwanted skin pigmentation and lead to adverse reactions affecting organs, including kidneys. The HSA advises consumers to stop using the products, discard them, and seek medical attention if adverse effects occur. The public is also cautioned to be vigilant when purchasing health products.

site_title: Asian market turmoil forces Croesus Retail Trust to rethink deal terms
summary: Croesus Retail Trust, a Singapore-based retail trust, is rethinking its acquisition strategy due to market turmoil. The trust, which owns One's Mall in Chiba, Japan, has seen its units decline 3.3% in August amid concerns about China's economy and global growth. Croesus plans to focus on acquisitions outside of Tokyo, targeting cities with good demographics and tourism, and will price in uncertainty in its deal terms to account for increased risk. The trust's assets rose 28% to 100 billion yen in the year ended June 30.

site_title: Separate SPP manifestos for different constituencies
summary: The Singapore People's Party (SPP) has launched separate manifestos for four constituencies, including Mountbatten, Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, and single-seat wards of Potong Pasir and Hong Kah North. Lawyer Jeannette Chong-Aruldoss unveiled her Mountbatten manifesto, outlining initiatives such as a social mobility bursary and plans to conserve low-rise blocks. The SPP will also campaign on policy changes, including pushing for a Freedom of Information Act. Chong-Aruldoss, a former contestant in the 2011 Mountbatten by-election, aims to win the contest against PAP's Lim Biow Chuan.

site_title: Three missing, three injured in explosion at Spain fireworks factory
summary: An explosion occurred at a fireworks factory in northeastern Spain, leaving three people missing and three injured. The Pirotecnia Zaragozana factory, which employs around 40 people, experienced a blast near Zaragoza airport. The cause of the explosion is unknown, and firefighters are on the scene, with small explosions still occurring. Three of the injured are in serious condition, and authorities are working to locate the missing individuals. The incident occurred during a busy time for fireworks factories in Spain, with many towns celebrating religious festivals.

site_title: Jail, caning for abusing daughter
summary: A 46-year-old divorced bus driver was jailed 19 years and ordered to be caned 24 strokes for sexually abusing his 10-year-old biological daughter over a four-year period. He continued the abuse until she was 14, using his position of authority to exploit her and emotionally manipulate her. The judge described the man's actions as "heinous" and said the victim trusted him, but he betrayed that trust. The abuse came to light when the girl's teacher questioned her absences and the case was marked as one of the most severe.

site_title: Bersih organisers thank Malaysia police for their restraint during rally
summary: The Bersih 4 rally in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, ended with organisers thanking the police for their "minimal involvement" and praising their restraint compared to previous rallies. The police were commended for not using excessive force, but the organisers felt they could have done better in managing crowd and traffic control. Former Prime Minister Tun Dr Mahathir Mohammad made an appearance, but his involvement was seen as a positive gesture but not aligning with all Bersih demands. The rally aimed to promote clean and fair elections, with organisers noting that they were the ones responsible for managing security.

site_title: Charles Chong prepares for stiff contest in 'homecoming'
summary: Veteran People's Action Party (PAP) MP Charles Chong is preparing to contest the Punggol East single-member constituency, a seat he previously held from 2001 to 2011. Chong, 62, is facing off against incumbent Workers' Party (WP) MP Lee Li Lian. Despite the WP's initial 13.5 percentage point swing in the 2013 by-election, Chong remains optimistic, citing his experience and ability to connect with residents. His strategy focuses on raising support through his old ties with residents and addressing local issues such as childcare places, public transport, and estate cleanliness. Chong also plans to press the PAP's point that the WP has been incompetent in managing the finances of its town council.

site_title: British scientists develop slow-melting ice cream
summary: British researchers have discovered a protein, BslA, that can be used to make slow-melting ice cream. The protein binds together the components of ice cream, creating a smooth consistency and preventing gritty ice crystals from forming. This could lead to improved ice cream for consumers and manufacturers, with potential benefits including reduced calories and saturated fat. The ingredient is expected to be available within three to five years, offering a solution to the summer scourge of sticky hands from melting ice cream cones.

site_title: Why exclude doctor's review from health screening package?
summary: Clinics offer health screening packages, but patients must pay extra for a doctor's review of test results. This leaves patients with the responsibility of interpreting the results on their own. It is recommended that health screening charges should cover the cost of a doctor's review to ensure patients receive accurate and reliable results.

site_title: India plans to amend RBI Act by Feb to set up monetary panel - official
summary: India plans to amend the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Act by February to set up a new monetary policy committee, comprising representatives from the government, RBI, and independent members. Finance Secretary Rajiv Mehrishi stated that the committee's composition will reflect the views of RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan, the government, and lawmakers. The move aims to resolve differences over the panel's composition, which has been blocked by parliament. The RBI's high policy rate is seen as encouraging inflows of volatile "hot" money into Indian markets, and the government is seeking to find a balance.

site_title: Problems with tray-return campaign
summary: The tray-return campaign, launched by the National Environment Agency, faces challenges in achieving its planned benefits. The main issues include trays occupying too much space and the problem of returning them. However, cleaners are hesitant to allow patrons to return trays, fearing job loss, and some even encourage patrons not to return them. This results in patrons leaving trays on the floor, compromising the cleanliness and comfort of others. Unless there is a change in mindset, the campaign may not be successful.

summary: Fake goods seller Lee Kok Leong is appealing a four-month jail term for selling counterfeit items, including clothing, footwear, and bags. His online store and showroom sold mostly fake goods, with only 30% authentic. Lee argued he only failed to verify authenticity, but a judge noted he "actively sourced and procured" the infringing items from abroad. The business made a net profit of $4,000 to $5,000 a month, selling items like "Marc by Marc Jacobs" bags for $35 each.

summary: Singaporean Buddhist Lodge President Lee Bock Guan, 70, died last Saturday due to a viral infection after undergoing kidney dialysis. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hailed Lee as a "good man who never discriminated along racial, religious, or language lines." Over 7,000 people paid their respects, including PM Lee, who praised Lee's charitable acts and selflessness. Lee was a dedicated Buddhist leader who donated to other religious groups and supported the lodge's free food programme, leaving behind a wife and four daughters.

site_title: 5 key Wes Craven films, from The Last House On The Left to Scream
summary: Wes Craven, a renowned writer and director, left a lasting impact on the horror genre. His films, including "The Last House On The Left" (1972), "The Hills Have Eyes" (1977), "A Nightmare On Elm Street" (1984), "The Serpent And The Rainbow" (1988), and "Scream" (1996), showcased his ability to invent and portray psychopaths that tapped into people's deepest fears. Craven's work not only popularized the slasher genre but also elevated it to a mainstream phenomenon, inspiring numerous imitators. His legacy continues to influence horror films to this day.

site_title: What's Next: Sep 1, 2015
summary: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Christine Lagarde began a two-day visit to Indonesia on August 31, 2015, meeting with President Joko Widodo and Bank Indonesia governor Agus Martowardojo. During her visit, she will also participate in a high-level conference and a town hall meeting with university students. Additionally, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has opened applications for the first Singapore Savings Bond, set to be issued on October 1, with interest in the product growing following numerous calls from investors.

site_title: U.S. stocks slide as Fed Reserve rates in focus
summary: US stocks slid on Monday, with the S&P 500 heading for its worst month in over three years. The Dow Jones fell 0.57%, the S&P 500 lost 0.49%, and the Nasdaq dropped 0.6%. Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer's comments kept a September interest rate hike possibility alive, with bets rising to 38% chance. The Fed has signaled it will raise rates when the labor market improves and inflation reaches its 2% target, but investors remain anxious over global growth.

site_title: Boko Haram killers on horseback massacre nearly 80 in Nigeria
summary: Suspected Boko Haram gunmen on horseback attacked three villages in Nigeria's northeast, killing nearly 80 people in the weekend's bloodbath. The attacks on Baanu, Karnuwa, and Hambagda villages in Borno state occurred on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, with varying death tolls reported. The extremist group has stepped up attacks since Nigeria's new President Muhammadu Buhari was sworn in, claiming over 1,000 lives in the region. The violence is part of a six-year-old insurgency aimed at carving out an Islamic state in the volatile region.

site_title: Guardsman killed in protests as Ukraine MPs back more autonomy for rebel regions
summary: A Ukrainian national guardsman was killed and nearly 90 others were wounded in clashes between protesters and riot police outside parliament in Kiev on Monday, as lawmakers backed reforms to give more autonomy to rebel-held areas. The violence was blamed on the nationalist party Svoboda, and the bill to grant autonomy to eastern regions passed its first reading despite opposition from some coalition allies. The move has raised concerns about President Petro Poroshenko's ability to push through key parts of a peace agreement, which has been under pressure due to sporadic shelling and shooting.

site_title: China brokers tumble as Citic staff detained, rescue costs grow
summary: China's brokerages plummeted on Monday after four Citic Securities executives were detained for alleged insider trading. The executives, including managing directors Xu Gang and Liu Wei, admitted to the crime. The China Securities Regulatory Commission ordered brokerages to contribute an additional 100 billion yuan to a stock market rescue fund, with some falling as much as 10% in Shanghai. The move is part of a broader government effort to stabilize the market and root out corruption, with analysts suggesting that the impact on brokerages may be short-term but ultimately beneficial in the long run.

site_title: Israeli soldier scuffles with Palestinian boy
summary: An Israeli soldier scuffled with a Palestinian boy, aged 12, during a protest against Jewish settlements in the West Bank. The boy, with a broken arm, threw stones at soldiers, prompting the soldier to restrain him. Village women intervened, with one biting the soldier, allowing the boy to escape. The soldier responded with tear gas, and one Palestinian was initially arrested before being released amid crowd violence. The incident highlights ongoing tensions between Israelis and Palestinians over settlements, which are considered illegal under international law.

site_title: Mourners gather to remember US journalists killed on air
summary: Mourners gathered at the Jefferson Center in Roanoke, Virginia, to honor Alison Parker and Adam Ward, two US journalists killed on-air while conducting a live interview. The shooters, a disgruntled former WDBJ employee, killed himself after the incident. A memorial service featured WDBJ president Jeff Marks discussing the importance of addressing anger and mental illness. The killings sparked an outpouring of support from journalists worldwide and renewed calls for gun control in the US and Virginia, where the National Rifle Association is headquartered.

site_title: Bangkok bomb 'suspect' living in Turkey, denies involvement
summary: Thailand's police have identified two new suspects in the Bangkok shrine bombing, a 26-year-old Thai woman named Wanna Suansan and an unidentified man. Suansan, who denies involvement, is believed to have rented an apartment used as a hideout by the bombing network. Police found bomb-making materials and fake Turkish passports at the suspect's flat in Turkey, where she claims to be living with her husband. The motive behind the August 17 attack remains unclear, with speculation focusing on various groups, including Islamist militants and rebels in the kingdom's south.

site_title: Singapore becomes venue in Asia to settle disputes relating to law of the sea
summary: Singapore has become a venue in Asia to settle disputes relating to the law of the sea, with a joint declaration signed by the country and the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (Itlos). The declaration allows Itlos to hold proceedings or exercise its functions in Singapore, providing facilities for the Tribunal. This move demonstrates Singapore's commitment to the international rule of law and its willingness to assist the Tribunal in promoting the peaceful settlement of disputes.

site_title: Myanmar's president signs off on law seen as targeting Muslims
summary: Myanmar President Thein Sein signed the Monogamy Bill into law on August 31, despite criticism that it discriminates against the country's Muslim minority. The law, one of four "Race and Religion Protection Laws" championed by radical Buddhists, sets punishments for people with multiple spouses or unmarried partners. The government denies the law is aimed at Muslims, but critics warn it poses a risk for discrimination and communal tension. The laws are part of a broader trend of anti-Muslim hate speech in Myanmar, which will hold its first democratic national poll on November 8.

site_title: Maersk gets approval for $6.3 billion U.K. North Sea gas field
summary: A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S has received UK approval for a $6.3 billion development plan for the Culzean natural gas field in the North Sea, expected to produce enough gas to meet 5% of the UK's demand in 2020 or 2021. Maersk Oil will operate the field with a 49.99% stake, alongside JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp. and BP Plc. Production is set to start in 2019 and continue for at least 13 years, with the field having estimated resources of up to 300 million barrels of oil equivalent.

site_title: When even a migrant camp is little refuge
summary: Hungary's refugee camps require migrants to be held for 24 hours, prompting some to escape to avoid fingerprinting. Several migrants attempted to flee the Roske camp in southern Hungary, with some successfully jumping the fence. The policy is seen as a deterrent due to the risk of being sent back to Hungary by Western European countries. This comes after police used tear gas against protesting migrants, who claimed to be treated poorly and held in scorching temperatures with little water. The move has raised concerns about the treatment of migrants in Hungarian camps.

site_title: GE2015: Application for post-election vehicle procession permits open on Sept 1
summary: Election candidates in Singapore can apply for post-election vehicle procession permits from September 1 to September 17. The permits are required for processions held between September 12 and September 18, and applicants must adhere to specific conditions, including not deviating from the route, not exceeding the number of vehicles, and ensuring the vehicles do not obstruct pedestrians or traffic. A $50 fee is required for the permit, and applicants must also provide prior notice to the police and follow specific guidelines.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai police get $118,000 reward in probe
summary: Thai police will reward the investigative team that helped find the Bangkok bombing suspect with a $118,000 cash bounty. The reward was initially offered to the public, but will now be given to the police team for their diligence and hard work in capturing the suspect. Army interrogators have revealed the name of three accomplices, and searches of properties in Bangkok have uncovered bomb-making materials and two new suspects, an Asian man and a Thai woman wearing a hijab. The arrest of the suspect and accomplices follows an explosion in Bangkok on August 17 that killed 20 people and injured over 130.

site_title: Trump defends the Tea Party
summary: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump defended the Tea Party, calling them "hardworking Americans" who get "beaten up" by the media. He praised their distrust of special interests and lobbyists, saying he shares their anger with conventional politics. A recent poll showed 73% of Republicans believe a "D.C. outsider" would make a better president. Trump assured the crowd he won't become weak like other Republicans in Washington, promising to make a difference. He received a positive reception from the Tea Party crowd, who cheered his criticism of the media and his commitment to conservative values.

site_title: New chairman and board members for National Library Board
summary: Mr. Chan Heng Kee, Permanent Secretary for Social and Family Development, has been appointed the new chairman of the National Library Board, succeeding Ms. Yeoh Chee Yan. Four new members, including Mr. Sajjad A. Akhtar and Dr. Shashi Jayakumar, will join the board, while ten other members were reappointed for a further two-year term. Mr. Chan's appointment is effective from September 1, following six years of Ms. Yeoh's leadership, during which she strengthened reading programs and developed new libraries.

site_title: Football: Ronaldinho jeered, Moreira defends his quest for rhythm
summary: Fluminense coach Enderson Moreira defended Ronaldinho after the 35-year-old was jeered by fans in a 1-2 loss to Atletico Mineiro. Ronaldinho, a two-time FIFA World Player of the Year, has yet to score in six matches since joining Fluminense in July. Moreira attributed Ronaldinho's struggles to a lack of rhythm due to his inactivity since leaving Queretaro in June, stating that the player needs a sequence of matches and good preparation to regain his form.

site_title: In pictures: Scenes of the Bersih 4.0 rally
summary: Bersih 4.0, a coalition of non-government organisations, held rallies in Kuala Lumpur, Kota Kinabalu, and Kuching on August 29-30, calling for clean governance in Malaysia and the resignation of Prime Minister Najib Tun Razak. The rallies, which followed similar events in 2007, 2011, and 2012, were attended by thousands, including opposition leader Wan Azizah Wan Ismail and former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The events were peaceful, with protesters clapping, singing, and marching, but were met with police presence. The rallies came ahead of Malaysia's National Day on August 31.

site_title: Hermes says in talks with Birkin about renaming croc bag
summary: Hermes is in talks with actress Jane Birkin about renaming the Birkin Croco bag due to disagreements over the farming and slaughtering practices of one of its suppliers. Birkin, who named the bag after herself, sought to disassociate herself from the luxury item after seeing a video of live reptiles being treated inhumely. Hermes CEO Axel Dumas said the brand is trying to impose higher ethical standards and has preserved a relationship of trust with Birkin, with discussions ongoing.

site_title: Beijing deploys monkeys and falcons for war parade: Report
summary: China's People's Liberation Army Air Force has deployed monkeys and falcons to ensure safe skies for a military parade marking the 70th anniversary of Japan's defeat in World War II. The monkeys, trained to destroy bird nests in one minute, will be rewarded with corn, while falcons will be used to deter airborne birds. The deployment is being made in a bird migration corridor, where 400-500 species are present, to minimize disruptions during the parade, which will feature 12,000 soldiers and 500 pieces of hardware.

site_title: Japan eyes defence budget hike to fortify island chain facing China
summary: Japan's Ministry of Defence is seeking a 2.2% increase in military spending to 5.09 trillion yen ($58 billion) for the year starting in April, its fourth consecutive annual budget hike. The increase aims to fortify the country's island chain in the East China Sea, close to China, amid growing tensions between the two nations. The budget plan includes purchases of F-35 Stealth warplanes, AAV7 amphibious assault vehicles, and Osprey tilt-rotor transport aircraft, as well as investments in military bases and radar stations to counter China's growing military power.

site_title: Taylor Swift leads winners as Kanye West hits MTV Video Music Awards with '2020 run for US presidency'
summary: Taylor Swift dominated the MTV Video Music Awards, winning four awards including Video of the Year for "Bad Blood." However, the night's highlight came when Kanye West, who famously interrupted Swift at the 2009 VMAs, announced an improbable run for US president in 2020. West received the Michael Jackson Video Vanguard award and criticized awards shows for replaying past incidents. Miley Cyrus released her new album for free, and Justin Bieber returned to the VMAs stage after a two-year break with an emotional performance.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai police hunt two bombing suspects after weekend raids
summary: Thai police have issued arrest warrants for two suspects in connection with the deadliest bombing in Thailand's history, which killed 20 people and injured over 100 on August 17. A 26-year-old Thai woman, Wanna Suansant, and a foreign man in his 40s were targeted in a second weekend raid on a suburban apartment block, where police found bomb-making materials. The suspects are believed to have a possible Turkish connection, and police have been investigating arrivals from Turkey. The investigation has been criticized for its slow pace, and speculation has focused on various groups, including southern ethnic Malay rebels and Uighur Muslim sympathizers.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party launches campaign video, unveils final batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) launched its campaign video "Empower Your Future" and unveiled its final batch of 28 candidates for the 2015 Singapore General Election. The candidates include three new faces, medical social worker Frieda Chan, funeral services company executive Bernard Chen, and research and consultancy firm CEO Leon Perera. The WP, led by chairman Sylvia Lim and Hougang MP Png Eng Huat, is fielding 28 candidates in five Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and five Single Member Constituencies (SMCs).

site_title: Former Thai PM Yingluck appears at Supreme Court over doomed rice subsidy scheme
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra appeared at the Supreme Court to review evidence in a case involving the failed rice subsidy scheme, which hemorrhaged billions of dollars and could lead to her 10-year jail term. The scheme, implemented in 2011, aimed to boost farmers' incomes but was criticized for distorting global prices and causing an estimated $16 billion in losses. Yingluck insists she acted honestly, and prosecutors have provided a 60,000-page evidence dossier and 23 witnesses. The court proceedings are expected to last at least six months, with potential implications for the royalist establishment and Yingluck's supporters.

site_title: Malaysian DPM Zahid's daughter: Bersih protests 'stupid', better for supporters to join the army
summary: Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi's daughter, Nurulhidayah Ahmad Zahid, has criticized supporters of the Bersih protests, calling them "stupid" for taking to the streets. The protests, which drew over 200,000 people, aimed to demand Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation over a financial scandal. Nurulhidayah suggested that instead of protesting, supporters should join the army to defend the country. Her comments have gone viral on social media, with many criticizing her father's stance on the issue.

site_title: Three must-read books by Oliver Sacks, writer who died aged 82 on Sunday
summary: Dr. Oliver Sacks, a renowned neurologist and writer, passed away at 82. Three of his must-read books include "Awakenings" (1973), which inspired a film and stage adaptations, "The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat" (1985), a collection of clinical stories about neurological conditions, and "On The Move" (2015), his autobiography that explores his life, struggles, and relationships. These books showcase Sacks' unique storytelling and insightful portrayals of his patients and personal life, cementing his legacy as a celebrated writer and neurologist.

site_title: Prime adjoining Chinatown shophouses up for sale
summary: A pair of adjoining shophouses at 205 and 207 New Bridge Road in Singapore's Chinatown are up for sale, with a combined land area of 1,728 square feet and a total gross floor area of approximately 5,800 sq ft. The properties, zoned "commercial," have 79 years left on their 99-year leasehold tenure and are expected to reap a potential gross yield of 3.5%. The sale represents a limited opportunity to own a slice of Singapore's heritage, with interest expected from traditional homegrown house brands and astute investors.

site_title: Bomb-making materials found in second Bangkok apartment: Thai police
summary: Thai police discovered bomb-making materials, including fertiliser bags, watches, and radio controls, in a second apartment linked to the arrested foreign suspect in connection with the Bangkok shrine bombing. The items were found during a raid on an apartment in the northeastern suburb of Minburi. The suspect, who was arrested on Saturday, allegedly possessed detonators, ball-bearings, and fake passports. Police believe the suspect was part of a crime group involved in illegal migrant document forgery and retaliation for a Thai crackdown. The attack killed 20 people, mostly ethnic Chinese tourists.

site_title: Yen, euro seen as havens from Fed, China uncertainties
summary: The yen and euro advanced on Monday for the first time in a week, driven by uncertainty over global monetary policy direction. The yen rose 0.5% to 121.12 US dollars, while the euro gained 0.6% to US$1.1249, amid concerns over China's economic slowdown and a possible Federal Reserve interest-rate increase. Market players are treating the currencies as havens, with hedge funds reducing their bearish bets on the yen. The Federal Reserve must decide on a rate hike, while China's manufacturing data is due out this week.

site_title: Led by ringgit, Asian currencies set for biggest monthly decline in three years
summary: Asia's currencies are set for their biggest monthly decline in three years, led by Malaysia's ringgit, due to a yuan devaluation and US interest rate hike concerns. The ringgit fell 8.7% this month, while Indonesia's rupiah and China's yuan declined 3.7% and 2.7%, respectively. The decline is attributed to investor risk aversion, a shift to market-determined exchange rates, and economic concerns in the region.

The event marked a reconciliation between Swift and rapper Nicki Minaj, who had previously clashed over a Video of the Year nomination snub. site_title: Cambodia says no plan to take more refugees from Australian detention camp
summary: Cambodia has announced it will not accept any more refugees from an Australian detention camp in Papua New Guinea, dealing a blow to a resettlement scheme criticized by rights groups. The agreement, made last September, allowed for the resettlement of refugees in Cambodia in exchange for Australian aid. However, only four refugees have arrived since then, and Cambodia's Interior Ministry spokesman stated that the country cannot receive hundreds or thousands of refugees due to its current situation. Australia's Foreign Minister denies the deal has collapsed, but human rights groups have long criticized the resettlement scheme.

site_title: Malaysian victim of Bangkok blast seeks closure after news of suspect's arrest
summary: A Malaysian man, Neoh Hock Guan, whose family members were killed in the August 17 Bangkok Erawan shrine bombing, expressed hope that the suspect arrested in connection with the blast would be the culprit. Neoh's family, including five Malaysians, died in the blast. Neoh, who is recovering from injuries, is now seeking closure as his family's house remains quiet without them. The 28-year-old suspect was found with bomb-making equipment and fake passports, matching the description of the man who left the bag at the shrine.

site_title: Malaysia's PM Najib reasserts command with National Day celebrations
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak staged a show of force with National Day celebrations, attended by thousands, after massive weekend protests demanding his ouster over a financial scandal. The protests, attended by over 200,000 people, were largely organized by ethnic Chinese minorities, but the government maintains control due to strong support among the majority ethnic Malay population. Najib defiantly refused to step down, calling protesters "shallow-minded," and his government has stalled investigations into the funding affair through personnel moves.

State-owned banks appeared to intervene on behalf of the central bank, buying yuan to support the currency. The People's Bank of China reiterated that the yuan will stay "basically stable" but market watchers believe there is pressure for it to weaken further to boost exports and support policy easing.

site_title: Boy struck by falling tree taken to hospital
summary: An 11-year-old boy, Sheik Sheqal Muhd Fazel, was taken to the hospital after being hit by a falling tree that uprooted and crashed into a Housing Board block in Pasir Ris, Singapore. The tree, estimated to be around 10 storeys tall, damaged three units and injured Sheqal on the head, despite no visible wound. The incident occurred on Sunday, and the tree's collapse was attributed to heavy rainfall and strong winds. The town council has announced plans to remove trees of similar type and size in the area as a safety measure.

site_title: Imagining Thailand in the next 50 years: The Nation
summary: Thailand's future in 50 years is uncertain, with the country struggling to think long-term due to its current daily focus on survival. Unlike Singapore, which has been planning for 2065, Thailand's leaders are more focused on short-term gains. To change this, the country needs to adopt a more open-minded and inclusive approach to planning its future. This includes improving education, making Thai farmers smarter through decentralization and community-based decision-making, and providing better life support systems for bureaucrats. By doing so, Thailand can rise above its current social issues and come up with a more sustainable and prosperous future.

summary: China's securities regulator has asked brokerages to boost market support by contributing 100 billion yuan to the market rescue fund and increasing stock buybacks. Despite this, Shanghai's Shanghai Composite Index slumped 2.5% on Monday, amid concerns over the level of state support and speculation about President Xi Jinping's upcoming World War II victory parade. The government's intervention aims to halt the biggest sell-off since 1996, but investors remain uncertain due to limited disclosures about state-linked fund purchases.

site_title: EU must defend migrants' 'dignity' say leaders ahead of talks
summary: European Union leaders are calling for action to defend the dignity of migrants ahead of emergency talks on September 14. Tensions are high on the bloc's eastern borders as record numbers of people, including 300,000 this year, flood across borders. Leaders are urging fair distribution of migrants among EU members, while some Eastern European countries are refusing to accept more migrants. Hungary has constructed a barrier and is building a 4m high fence along its border with Serbia, prompting criticism from French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius. The crisis has exposed deep divisions within the bloc and has led to the deaths of thousands of migrants attempting to cross the Mediterranean.

site_title: Great green hopes for Indonesia: The Jakarta Post
summary: Indonesia's President Joko "Jokowi" Widodo's special envoy on climate change, Rachmat Witoelar, has revealed the government's bid to set a higher national emissions reduction target ahead of the UN climate change conference in Paris later this year. This move aims to establish a global emissions reduction target and replace the expired Kyoto Protocol. A higher target would increase hope for slowing down greenhouse gas emissions blamed for climate change, and could also earn Indonesia more respect for its commitment to environmental protection.

site_title: Horror film legend Wes Craven, director of A Nightmare On Elm Street, dies at 76
summary: Wes Craven, director of horror classics A Nightmare On Elm Street and Scream, died on August 30, 2015, at 76, surrounded by his loved ones in his Los Angeles home. He had been suffering from brain cancer for the past three years. Despite his illness, Craven continued to work on projects, including a new film set to premiere at the 2015 Toronto Film Festival. The family announced his passing with a statement, saying their hearts were broken.

site_title: Australand becomes Frasers Property Australia
summary: Australand has been renamed Frasers Property Australia and will adopt the international Frasers Property brand. The re-branding marks the completion of integrating Australand with Frasers Property Australia, a business acquired by Frasers Centrepoint Ltd in 2014. CEO Rod Fehring stated that the single brand will leverage scale and reach to develop supplementary asset classes and align with FCL's REIT platform. The Australian business is trading strongly, with 167,500 sqm of space under development and a portfolio valued at A$2.7 billion.

site_title: Growth in Singapore bank lending eases to 0.6% in July
summary: Singapore's total bank lending rose to $610.4 billion in July, up 0.59% from the previous month, driven by stronger demand for property loans and commerce sector loans. This growth eased from the 1.6% month-on-month increase in June. Housing and bridging loans increased to $181.6 billion, while loans in non-Singapore Asian currencies rose to $561.4 billion. The July growth rate was 2.2% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Australia new home sales ease 0.4% in July
summary: Australia's new home sales eased 0.4% in July, according to the Housing Industry Association, despite remaining at historically high levels. This decline follows a cyclical peak in April, with detached homes experiencing a 0.7% increase, while multi-unit sales dropped 4.2%. HIA chief economist Harley Dale attributed the mild downward trend, stating that the peak for total new home sales occurred in April.

site_title: Keppel to buy jackup rig designs, rig kit and aftermarket service businesses for S$141m
summary: Keppel Corp announced the acquisition of LeTourneau jackup rig designs, rig kit, and aftermarket service businesses for S$141 million. The acquisition expands Keppel's suite of jackup rig designs and enables the company to offer customers LeTourneau rig designs through sale of rig kits or ready-to-drill solutions. Keppel will also provide aftermarket services, including repairs, upgrades, and modifications, to the approximately 100 LeTourneau rigs operating worldwide. The acquisition is seen as strategic, particularly with the current low oil price, allowing Keppel to capitalize on repair and upgrade opportunities.

site_title: Obama renames Alaska's Mount McKinley, tallest mountain in North America, Denali
summary: US President Barack Obama officially renamed North America's tallest mountain, Denali, from Mount McKinley, in a move aimed at addressing climate change as part of his legacy. The name change, which has been 40 years in the making, was supported by the state of Alaska and praised by Governor Bill Walker and Senator Lisa Murkowski. The decision comes as part of Obama's three-day presidential trip to Alaska, where he will meet with indigenous leaders and highlight the impact of climate change on Arctic communities.

summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad sparked controversy by attending Bersih protests, a demonstration against Prime Minister Najib Razak's alleged corruption. Umno Vice-President Hishammuddin Hussein criticized Mahathir's decision, stating it was unbecoming for a respected statesman to support a protest that threatened national harmony. Hishammuddin recalled Mahathir's own stance against street protests in the past, and questioned the relevance of joining a protest to bring down the government. Mahathir's attendance fueled excitement among Bersih participants, but also drew criticism from Umno leaders.
