site_title: Singtel, NCS and DBS give up to two weeks' paid paternity leave, in response to Government calls
summary: SINGAPORE - At least three local companies, Singtel, NCS, and DBS Bank, have introduced up to two weeks of paid paternity leave for married male employees, in response to government calls for extended paternity leave. The benefit, which takes effect from January 1, can be taken flexibly within 12 months of a child's birth. The move aims to support working fathers and promote work-life balance. The government has also announced measures to encourage couples to have children, including raising the re-employment age from 65 to 67.

site_title: China state media announces slew of confessions over stocks plunge
summary: Chinese state media announced a series of confessions related to the recent stock market downturn, including a detained reporter who admitted to spreading false information and a senior executive from Citic Securities who confessed to insider trading. The confessions follow investigations into fabricating trading information, malicious short-selling, and other strategies seen as hindering the market's recovery. The moves aim to boost the stock markets, which have plummeted 40% since mid-June due to concerns over China's slowing economy and yuan devaluation.

site_title: Australia urges more European nations to join ISIS air strikes
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop urged more European nations to join air strikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, citing the group's role in driving hundreds of thousands of migrants to Europe. site_title: US considering sanctions over Chinese cyber theft: Washington Post
summary: The US is considering sanctions against companies and individuals in China believed to have benefited from Chinese hacking of US trade secrets. The White House is expected to make a final determination on sanctions within the next two weeks, possibly as early as September. The move comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China, with President Xi Jinping set to visit the US next month. Sanctions would be the first use of an executive order authorizing the freezing of assets of suspected commercial cyber espionage entities and individuals, aimed at sending a signal to China that the US will fight back on economic espionage.

site_title: MORNING MINUTES: What will make headlines today, Aug 31, 2015
summary: The first group of pilgrims is set to depart for the annual Haj to Mecca on Monday, with the Mufti of Singapore and Muis officials sending them off from Changi Airport Terminal 2. US President Barack Obama is also scheduled to embark on a three-day tour to Alaska, focusing on climate change, as part of a drive to raise awareness on the impact of climate change on the Arctic. This tour comes after Obama faced criticism for allowing Shell to drill in the Arctic Ocean.

site_title: Asian stocks set for worst month since 2012 as Fed, China woes collide; STI down 0.7%
summary: Asian stocks are set for their worst month since 2012, with the STI down 0.7%, as Federal Reserve officials signal a possible interest rate hike amid China's market turmoil. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.2% despite efforts to stabilize markets before a military parade. Copper futures sank, and the Aussie traded near a six-year low, while the yen gained 0.5%. The MSCI All-Country World Index is heading for a 6.5% drop in August, its largest monthly decline since May 2012.

site_title: Party leaders urge Malaysians to stay united as country marks National Day after protests
summary: Malaysia's ruling party leaders have urged the country to remain united and celebrate its National Day on Monday, following a weekend of protests led by Bersih. The protests aimed to voice concerns over attempts to muzzle criticism and stifle investigations into Prime Minister Najib Razak's alleged receipt of state funds. In their National Day messages, BN component parties emphasized the importance of multiculturalism and unity in building a stronger Malaysia, while Bersih organizers called for a "people's power" movement to oust Najib.

site_title: Japan's industrial production unexpectedly declines in July as China demand slumps
summary: Japan's industrial production unexpectedly declined 0.6% in July due to weak domestic demand and a slowdown in China, which has weighed on exports. This marks a reversal from the 1.1% increase in June. The decline is attributed to production cutbacks in the electrical components and transport equipment industries, with economists citing concerns about China's economic slowdown and its impact on Japan's economy.

site_title: Italy's Eni makes mega gas discovery off Egyptian coast
summary: Italian energy group Eni has made a massive gas discovery off the Egyptian coast, with the Zohr field predicted to hold 30 trillion cubic feet of gas. This is the largest known gas field in the Mediterranean and could meet Egypt's gas needs for decades. The discovery is expected to have a significant impact on the region's economy, offering Europe new supply options and reducing its dependence on Russian gas imports. Eni plans to fast track development of the site, using existing infrastructure, and has full concession rights to the area.

site_title: Golf: Australia's Jason Day crushes competition by six strokes to win FedExCup opener
summary: Jason Day of Australia dominated The Barclays golf tournament, winning by six strokes with a 19-under-par 261 total. The PGA Championship winner carded an 8-birdie, bogey-free final round 62, securing his third victory in four starts. Henrik Stenson finished second at 13-under, with Bubba Watson and Zach Johnson tied for fourth at 10-under.

site_title: Group breathing new life into historic area
summary: The Emerald Hill Conservation Association, a group of homeowners, has revitalized the historic Emerald Hill estate in Singapore through various initiatives. The group, led by hotelier Richard Helfer, has eliminated 400 unsightly bins, improved back lanes, and incorporated 20,000 new plants into the estate's landscaping. Additionally, they are working with the Urban Redevelopment Authority to install plaques and information boards highlighting the area's history and notable residents. The efforts aim to enhance the liveability and beauty of the estate, which is often photographed by tourists and locals alike.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Aug 31 edition
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak faces mounting pressure as former leader Mahathir Mohamad supports mass protests demanding his ousting over a financial scandal. Tens of thousands of protesters gathered in the city centre, with Mahathir's arrival sparking a rapturous welcome. Meanwhile, a Chinese financial journalist confessed to causing chaos on China's stock market, and Saudi Arabia allowed women to register for local elections in a historic first. In other news, a truck carrying migrants was found with 71 people dead, and Swansea City defeated Manchester United 2-1 in the Premier League.

site_title: Man drowns in canal near Pasir Ris Park
summary: A 29-year-old chef, Mr Syed Shafiq Syed Peer, drowned in the Sungei Api Api canal near Pasir Ris Park while trying to untangle a fishing line. He was swept away by the strong river current, which prevented bystanders from rescuing him. Despite efforts by the Singapore Civil Defence Force and police, his body was recovered at 5:50pm. The incident is being investigated as an unnatural death, with the police reviewing the circumstances leading up to the tragedy.

site_title: Strange hues spoil views on Emerald Hill
summary: Residents of Emerald Hill, a historic shophouse estate in Singapore, have voted to maintain a traditional pastel palette on their facades, rejecting the use of "alien" colors such as black and neon orange. In a URA survey, 55 out of 126 owners polled opposed using unconventional colors, citing that they are "alien to the character of Emerald Hill." The owners will work with the URA and conservation association to define the preferred paint schemes by year-end, aiming to restore the neighborhood's historic beauty.

site_title: 5 things to know before the Singapore market trades this week: Aug 31-Sept 6
summary: Global stock markets will approach cautiously on Monday, August 31, amid concerns over the US economy and China's slowdown. The US Federal Reserve is still "data-dependent" on making a decision on interest rate hikes, with a September rate hike not ruled out. China's economy remains a focus, with the government intervening in the stock market ahead of the Victory Day parade on September 3. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank and Reserve Bank of Australia are expected to keep monetary policies steady, and Singapore's manufacturing PMI for August will be released on Thursday.

site_title: Baseball: Atlanta Braves honour fan who died in stadium fall
summary: A 60-year-old Atlanta Braves fan, Gregory Murrey, died after falling from the upper deck at Turner Field during a game between the Braves and New York Yankees on Saturday. Emergency medical staff attempted to help him, but he was pronounced fatal. The Braves paid tribute to Murrey on Sunday, displaying his picture on the video scoreboard and holding a moment of silence before their game against the Yankees. The incident is not believed to be foul play, and grief counsellors are available to players and family members who witnessed the fall.

site_title: Inclusive attractions for kids with special needs
summary: Staff from 45 local Singapore attractions recently attended a training session to learn about disabilities and plan activities for children with special needs. The session, led by trainers from the National Institute of Education, aimed to create inclusive exhibits for visitors with disabilities. The attractions plan to customize exhibits, such as providing worksheets for children with autism that play on their strengths, and adding multi-sensory details to engage visitors with sensory disabilities. The goal is to create a more inclusive environment for children with special needs, with the hope of holding a second, more in-depth session targeting specific attractions and disabilities.

The incident occurred at a time when the party is facing internal turmoil, with several potential candidates dropping out of the polls. The NSP is conducting its own investigations and will keep the public informed.

summary: Opposition parties in Singapore's upcoming elections have given hints about their potential candidates, including SingFirst and the National Solidarity Party (NSP). SingFirst, led by Tan Jee Say, deployed teams in Jurong and Tanjong Pagar GRCs, while the NSP is expected to field a team in Sembawang GRC. The opposition parties are likely to challenge the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) teams, which won 67% and 63.9% of the vote in the respective GRCs in 2011. The election is set to take place in 2015.

summary: Workers' Party chairman Sylvia Lim, 50, has stated that she and her boyfriend, retired football star Quah Kim Song, have no plans to get married. Despite their busy schedules, they continue to meet daily and have devised a plan to see each other during the upcoming election campaign. Lim also discussed her personal life, including her struggles with her father's ill health and her decision not to have children, citing her age and her father's past strokes. She emphasized the importance of self-acceptance and not dwelling on one's gender in politics.

site_title: Stepping forward to answer a calling in life
summary: Dennis Tan Lip Fong, a 45-year-old shipping lawyer, has announced his candidacy for a position in the Workers' Party. Tan Lip Fong believes in the "calling" to go into politics, which began in 2011 when he volunteered for a WP member's campaign. He aims to address issues such as retirement adequacy and governance, criticizing the current system of rushing through Bills without proper debate. A native of the East Coast area, Tan Lip Fong hopes to bring capable individuals into politics and challenge the "not in my backyard" mindset in Singapore.

site_title: Empathy with working parents' struggles
summary: Singaporean opposition candidate Bryan Long, 37, has announced his candidacy for the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC. Long, co-founder of a tech start-up, is married to a teacher and has three children. He aims to empathize with working parents and focus on issues such as encouraging children to learn how to learn and supporting entrepreneurship. Long, a Master of Business Administration graduate, believes that being in Parliament is the best way to make voices from the ground heard, citing his experience as a scholarship holder and RC vice-chairman in the civil service.

Singh had been told he would be a back-up candidate but later retracted his resignation after rejoining the WP. Singh was chosen after another potential candidate, lawyer Shaneet Rai, 27, quit over a team of young first-timers taking on a People's Action Party team in Nee Soon GRC.

He highlighted the government's efforts to create opportunities for Singaporeans, such as expanding university places and SkillsFuture programs, and stressed the need for extensive consultations with residents when developing policies that affect the country's future.

site_title: Interview with Sylvia Lim: Workers' Party 'prepared to run another town council'
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim believes the challenges faced by the party in managing the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) have prepared it to take on another town council of similar size. Despite the Ministry of National Development's (MND) assertion of overpayment to the town's managing agent, Lim says the WP is committed to being better and has learned from the experience. The party will not expand its town council further, but will consider running another if the opportunity arises. Lim defends the town council's performance, citing improvements made to estates and project spending.

site_title: Govt agencies used for politics: WP
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has accused the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) of using government departments to attack political opponents, specifically the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). WP chairman Sylvia Lim criticized the Ministry of National Development (MND) for its review of FM Solutions and Services, the town council's former managing agent, which found the company was "grossly profiteering". Lim claimed the MND is trying to discredit AHPETC before the polling day, citing a government review that found the town council suffered an operating deficit of $2 million in FY2014.

summary: PAP MP Lam Pin Min acknowledged that the Fernvale columbarium saga showed the Government is willing to reverse decisions if necessary, but the matter has largely been resolved. The issue sparked controversy over plans to build a columbarium next to a residential project, with residents protesting over undisclosed sales brochures and land use. Lam has since re-zoned the site for civic and community use, with plans for a new community facility and childcare centre set to be implemented.

site_title: Ng Eng Hen: Integrity critical in political parties
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) expects its candidates to uphold high standards of integrity, with Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasizing that compliance with the law is not enough. He stressed that the party will not tolerate even the slightest hint of wrongdoing, regardless of party affiliation. Ng also likened corruption to cancer, urging leaders to nip it in the bud and root it out systematically. The PAP sees honesty and integrity as the core foundation of Singapore's governance, and the upcoming elections will be about "hope and trust" in elected representatives.

site_title: With one day to Nomination Day, party line-ups almost complete
summary: Singapore's General Election 2015 is nearing its start, with most parties unveiling their candidates ahead of Nomination Day tomorrow. The People's Action Party, Singapore Democratic Party, Reform Party, and Singaporeans First have named their candidates, while the Workers' Party will finalize its slate today. The election is expected to bring a clearer picture of who will contest each town, with voters having a clearer picture of who is contesting their areas. The Workers' Party faces scrutiny over its town council's management contract with FM Solutions & Services.

site_title: President of Egypt begins state visit
summary: Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi began a three-day state visit to Singapore, marking the first visit by an Egyptian president since diplomatic relations were established in 1966. He met with Muslim community and inter-faith leaders at the Harmony Centre, where they discussed counter-extremism efforts. Sisi will be officially welcomed at the Istana, meet with President Tony Tan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and attend a state banquet. This visit comes as Singapore celebrates its 50th year of independence.

site_title: AHPETC rewarding friends, supporters excessively: Khaw
summary: National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan accused the Workers' Party-run Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) of losing residents' money due to excessive payments to its managing agent FM Solutions and Services (FMSS). The $3 million annual payment to FMSS is deemed excessive, with Khaw questioning why the town council is not also rewarding its own staff with similar amounts. The AHPETC's chairman, Sylvia Lim, disputed the allegations, while Khaw believes the situation raises questions about the WP's motives and the accountability of the town council.

site_title: Ban on entry into Singapore eased for foreigners with HIV
summary: Singapore has lifted its ban on entry for foreigners with HIV, allowing those with short-term visit passes to enter the country. However, the ban remains in place for long-term visitors, such as those seeking work or studying in Singapore. The decision was made due to the country's low risk of HIV transmission and the availability of effective treatment. Those found to be HIV-positive on short-term visits will be deported and put on a permanent blacklist, while long-term visitors will face restrictions. Advocacy groups have welcomed the change, but called for further easing of restrictions.

site_title: Nomination Day: What to expect
summary: On Nomination Day, Sept 1, 2015, nine nomination centres islandwide will open at 10am for candidates' supporters and the public to file nomination papers. Candidates have one hour from 11am to noon to submit forms, which must be complete and in duplicate, accompanied by a proposer, seconder, and assentors. Candidates who fill in forms incorrectly must correct the problems by noon, and can also apply for permits to hold election meetings and vehicle processions. The process is strictly regulated, with a focus on ensuring the integrity of the nomination process.

site_title: Reframing the ageing issue
summary: Singapore has launched a $3 billion Action Plan for Successful Ageing, aimed at helping seniors make the most of their golden years. The five-year plan covers areas such as health, infrastructure, lifelong learning, and research. It marks a significant shift in the country's approach to ageing, reframing it as an opportunity for personal growth and contribution, rather than a burden. The plan's focus on learning, volunteering, and living well aims to provide a better quality of life for Singapore's growing elderly population, set to reach 900,000 by 2030.

site_title: Tech innovations on show at this year's ITE fiesta
summary: The Institute of Technical Education (ITE) held its SG50 ITE Fiesta 2015, showcasing 45 student projects, including a brainwave-controlled headset for immobile patients and a smartphone-based attendance system. The event, attended by 8,000 people, aimed to raise the institute's profile and highlighted the potential of human capital in Singapore. The fiesta also raised funds for wheelchairs and groceries for senior citizens, with proceeds going to voluntary welfare organizations. ITE students demonstrated their capabilities, with one student stating that the event would showcase their potential.

site_title: Big party for NDP participants and volunteers
summary: Singapore's National Day Parade (NDP) participants and volunteers celebrated at a party at Universal Studios Singapore, attended by over 8,000 guests. The event was organized by the SG50 programme office and NDP 2015 executive committee. Minister Lawrence Wong and Education Minister Heng Swee Keat mingled with the crowd, praising the dedication of participants and volunteers. The celebrations marked the Golden Jubilee weekend, highlighting Singaporeans' love for their country and sense of unity.

site_title: Set aside time to help kids develop emotional intelligence
summary: A Singaporean author reflects on her own struggles with emotional intelligence, citing a lack of education on emotional regulation as a major factor. She advocates for schools to prioritize social-emotional learning, citing its positive impact on her own children. The author argues that emotional intelligence is essential for success, not just in academics, but in personal relationships and future employability. She believes that setting aside time for emotional intelligence education in schools can help children develop essential life skills, such as coping with setbacks and regulating their emotions.

site_title: Residents dabble in art as festival draws to close
summary: The fourth PAssionArts Festival drew to a close with nine festival villages held over the weekend, including the Kampong Glam event. About 500 residents attended the community club, where a visual art installation piece called My Home allowed participants to paint cardboard houses. The festival, which started on July 12, featured 63 events and activities across eight weekends, with about 250,000 residents participating. The festival's theme, "We Love Singapore," aimed to encourage residents to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday through art.

The foundation, which has pledged to sponsor the art competition at Nafa for at least five years, has a total of $70,000 in prize money. The brothers, who own the Killiney coffee shop chain and a large collection of art pieces, have also donated works from their collection to museums in Singapore and abroad.

site_title: Fall in Aussie dollar revives interest of Singaporeans to study there
summary: The Australian dollar's recent decline has revived interest among Singaporeans to study in Australia, with a 5% increase in enrollments from last year. In 2012, 8,000 Singaporeans studied in Australia, but numbers dropped to 7,300 in 2015. The decline was attributed to high tuition fees, living costs, and the strong Australian dollar. However, with the decline in the Australian dollar, making Australian education roughly 20% cheaper, student recruiters expect more Singaporeans to consider studying in Australia, with the country remaining the largest destination for Singaporean students abroad.

summary: The inaugural SingHealth Duke-NUS Academic Medical Centre gala dinner raised $30.5 million for medical research and education initiatives. Major donors included the Viva Foundation, pledging $8.2 million, and healthcare institutions such as the Singapore General Hospital and National Cancer Centre Singapore. The event celebrated a decade of partnership between SingHealth and Duke-NUS, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam in attendance. The funds will support research and education to advance the frontiers of medicine and prevent, predict, diagnose, treat, and halt disease progression.

site_title: More pursuing Aussie degrees in institutions here
summary: More Singaporean students are opting for Australian degrees through private institutions in Singapore, with 31,000 students enrolled in 2014, a 15% increase from 2010. The high value of the Australian dollar and expansion of Australian universities in Singapore have driven this trend. Tuition fees for Australian degrees in Singapore are 30-40% lower than in Australia, and students can graduate in two years with generous credit exemptions. Australian universities, such as RMIT and James Cook, have established partnerships with local institutions and hire faculty members in Singapore, offering well-recognized degrees by employers.

site_title: Restored, rebuilt, renewed
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority has conserved and adapted three historic buildings in Singapore over the past two decades. The Far East Square, a 61-shophouse complex, was transformed into a modern office and food area in 1999. House No. 1 on Pulau Ubin, a Tudor-style cottage, was restored as the Chek Jawa Visitor Centre in 2009. The 18-storey Ascott Raffles Place building, once the Asia Insurance Company's office, now houses service apartment suites, offering a unique blend of heritage and modernity.

site_title: Journalist 'confesses' to causing China market chaos: state media
summary: A Chinese financial journalist, Wang Xiaolu, has confessed to causing panic and disorder on the country's stock market, resulting in huge losses. He fabricated and spread false information, including a story claiming the securities regulator was studying plans to exit the market. Authorities have also detained several officials and executives for "stock market violations," including a CSRC official and four senior executives. The cases are part of a special campaign targeting online rumors and misinformation.

site_title: Putting together details on religious buildings
summary: A book titled "Faith In Architecture" has been launched, documenting 50 religious institutions in Singapore. The book, compiled by students from the School of Art, Design and Media at Nanyang Technological University, features the Darul Aman mosque, which won an award in 1987 for its unique architectural design. The book aims to fill a gap in religious architecture literature, providing insight into Singapore's diverse religious heritage, including the Burmese Buddhist temple, St Thomas Orthodox Syrian Cathedral, and Holy Tree Sri Balasubramaniar Temple.

site_title: Spanish bull run deaths rise to 12, deadliest in 15 years
summary: A man in his 60s died after being gored during a bull run in Cuellar, Spain, bringing the total number of deaths this year to 12, the deadliest in 15 years. The run, which dates back to the 13th century, was attended by nearly 3,500 participants. Five people were slightly injured during the first minute of the event. The incident occurred at the start of the run, where a bull gored a person on the urban side before entering the countryside.

site_title: 33-year-old man murdered at Senja Road flat in Bukit Panjang
summary: A 33-year-old man was found dead with slash and stab wounds at a flat in Block 636B Senja Road in Bukit Panjang, Singapore. The victim, identified as a married couple, was pronounced dead at 1:19am. A 26-year-old woman, also a Singaporean, was arrested in relation to the case and will appear in court on Tuesday. The couple's relationship status and the circumstances surrounding the murder are still under investigation. Police are collecting evidence and reviewing the case.

site_title: Five people per square metre: how the truck migrants met their end
summary: Seventy-one people, including three migrant children, were found dead in an abandoned refrigeration lorry in Austria, with forensic tests indicating they suffocated due to being crammed in at a rate of five to a square metre. The victims are believed to be refugees from Syria or Afghanistan, part of a large migrant wave testing the EU's ability to cope. A Romanian driver was arrested, and three Bulgarians and one Afghan were also taken into custody, with a fifth suspect, a Bulgarian citizen, arrested in connection with the deaths.

site_title: Golf: Brian Harman makes pair of aces at The Barclays
summary: Brian Harman achieved a rare feat at The Barclays, making a pair of holes-in-one during the final round, becoming only the third player to do so in a PGA Tour event. The 28-year-old American golfer hit two aces, one from 183 yards at the third hole and another from 218 yards at the 14th hole. Harman finished the tournament with a 68, shooting two-under 278, but expressed a desire to be in contention rather than achieving the aces, which raised the total to 40 holes-in-one this season on the PGA Tour.

site_title: Football: Flying Roma send Juventus to second straight defeat
summary: AS Roma secured a crucial 2-1 victory over Juventus, ending their 30-month wait to beat the Serie A champions. Roma took a 2-0 lead before Juventus defender Patrice Evra was sent off, and Paulo Dybala scored a consolation goal in the final minutes. The win pushed Roma to second place in the league, two points behind Sassuolo, while Juventus fell to third from bottom after failing to win their opening two games of the season.

site_title: Growing numbers of rhinos poached for horns in South Africa: minister
summary: South Africa's Environment Minister Edna Molewa reported 749 rhinos were poached nationwide as of August 27, with 544 in the Kruger National Park. This year's figure surpasses last year's total of 716. Demand for rhino horn in Asia drives the slaughter, despite its composition being mainly keratin, the same as human nails. 138 poachers were arrested in Kruger National Park this year, up from 81 in 2014. Conservation efforts are underway, but experts believe the real figures may be higher due to unrecovered carcasses. Only 20,000 rhinos remain in South Africa.

site_title: David Lagercrantz, author of Millennium trilogy sequel, wrote it in a state of constant terror
summary: Swedish author David Lagercrantz wrote the fourth Millennium series sequel, "The Girl In The Spider's Web," in a state of constant terror and psychological fever while writing the 500-page novel. The book, released in August 2015, follows protagonists Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander as they work together to take on cyber criminals and the National Security Agency. Lagercrantz credits his spouse, Anne Lagercrantz, as the first reader for his drafts, and says he was inspired by the Batman Begins film to delve deeper into Salander's past. The book has sold over 2.7 million copies worldwide, eclipsed only by Go Set A Watchman.

site_title: Man drowns at Pasir Ris Park, body recovered by SCDF
summary: A 29-year-old man drowned at Pasir Ris Park's Sungei Api Api canal on Sunday afternoon while trying to untangle a fishing line. Relatives identified the victim as Mr. Syed Shafiq Syed Peer. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) responded quickly, deploying amphibious vehicles and divers from its Disaster Assistance and Rescue Team (DART). The body was recovered at 5:50pm, and the man was pronounced dead at the scene. Police have classified the death as unnatural and are investigating.

site_title: Malaysia PM Najib brands Bersih supporters traitors
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has labeled Bersih supporters as traitors, warning that he would not allow anyone to destroy the country. In a televised speech, Najib rejected street demonstrations, citing concerns over public order and national spirit. He also dismissed rumors of Malaysia's bankruptcy, stating the country's economic fundamentals are strong. The speech came after a two-day Bersih rally, which opposition leaders called for Najib's resignation. Najib's government has also removed critics from his Cabinet and broken up Parliament's Public Accounts Committee.

site_title: Football: Manchester City sign Kevin de Bruyne from Wolfsburg for club-record $117 million
summary: Manchester City signed Belgian playmaker Kevin de Bruyne from Wolfsburg for a club-record £54 million (S$117 million) on a six-year contract. The 24-year-old former Chelsea player joined the English Premier League leaders, with City's announcement on their website stating they are "delighted" to have him on board. De Bruyne expressed his desire to reach the highest level as a player and potentially win titles with the new club.

site_title: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, facing refugee influx, presses EU peers to take more
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged EU peers to take a greater share of refugees, citing a record number of arrivals in Germany. The country expects 800,000 asylum seekers in 2015, with Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere stating that this is unsustainable in the long term. Merkel emphasized the need for solidarity and action before winter, saying "Europe must move quickly." European governments have resisted taking in refugees, with some refusing to agree on a common plan, leading Merkel to call for an urgent European meeting to discuss immigration.

site_title: In first, Saudi women allowed to run in local elections
summary: Saudi Arabia has allowed women to register to stand in local elections, a historic first for the ultra-conservative Muslim kingdom. Women in Saudi Arabia face strict segregation and restrictions, including a driving ban and requiring a male guardian's consent for travel and work. While the move is seen as a step forward, critics argue it doesn't go far enough in providing women with equal rights. Human Rights Watch praised the move, but urged the kingdom to scrap the male guardianship system and ensure women's full integration into public life.

Mahathir defended his attendance, stating it's about supporting the people's feelings, not about party affiliations.

Three world junior records fell, including the women's 200m breaststroke, while Russia set new marks in the men's and women's 4x100m medley relays. Australia's Kyle Chalmers won the men's 100m freestyle, and Rikako Ikee claimed the women's 100m butterfly title.

site_title: Install red-light cameras at danger junctions
summary: A pedestrian narrowly escaped being hit by a speeding black Mercedes at a crossing in Simei Street 3, Singapore. The vehicle, which had a green light, failed to slow down despite other vehicles stopping. The incident has prompted the writer to urge authorities to install red-light cameras at danger junctions to prevent similar accidents. The writer hopes that such cameras will be installed before a fatal accident occurs.

site_title: Review literature assessment format
summary: Singapore's O-level literature exams have been criticized for their timed format, which can lead to students feeling pressured and penalized for minor errors. The exams require students to produce a detailed analysis of a text within a short time frame, often with subjective questions that can be difficult to answer. This format may be driving students away from studying literature, as it prioritizes speed over depth of thought. Experts suggest reviewing the assessment format to give students more time to plan their responses and reduce the emphasis on speed.

site_title: Shore up apparatus to protect consumers online
summary: The Singapore government should introduce fresh legislation to regulate online businesses and protect consumers from rogue e-commerce traders. These traders use "blank cheque" transfers, similar to rogue retailers, and engage in misinformation and entrapment. To combat this, the existing "Lemon Law" should be revamped to include specific provisions, such as increased scrutiny on credit card payments and mandatory detailed invoices. The government should also invest in investigating e-commerce malpractice and encourage industry standard guidelines on fair business practices to cultivate a consumer protection culture.

Germany, France, and Britain have asked for a special meeting to establish a common EU list of "safe countries of origin" and set up reception centers in Italy and Greece. The crisis has sparked concerns over the EU's response, with French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius labeling the attitude of some eastern European countries as "scandalous" due to their anti-migrant barriers, including Hungary's razor-wire barrier.

site_title: Oliver Sacks, neurologist who chronicled his demise, dies at 82
summary: Oliver Sacks, a renowned neurologist and author, has died at 82. He chronicled his own terminal cancer diagnosis and wrote about people with brain disorders, including those with phantom limbs and hallucinations. Sacks, a professor at New York University School of Medicine, wrote over a dozen best-selling books, including "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat" and "Musicophilia". He was known for his empathetic storytelling and ability to combine science, philosophy, and personal histories, earning him the nickname "the poet laureate of medicine".

summary: South Korean actors Lee Min Ho, Lee Seung Gi, and Yoo Ah In are rushing to complete their projects before enlisting in the South Korean army. The event also featured charity activities, including a cycling fundraiser for wheelchairs and a grocery delivery for seniors. The event attracted 8,000 attendees, with 2,000 secondary school students participating in a special session. The Minister of Manpower highlighted the importance of human capital development.

The city's mayor, Mitch Landrieu, led a somber tribute to the 1,500 who died, while residents and visitors attended block parties, second-line parades, and memorials across the city. site_title: Athletics: Mare Dibaba clinches women's world marathon title by just one second
summary: Ethiopian athlete Mare Dibaba won the women's world marathon title by a mere one second at the 15th IAAF Championships in Beijing, China. Dibaba finished with a time of 2:27:35, edging out Kenya's Helah Kiprop by just one second. Eunice Kirwa claimed bronze with a time of 2:27:39, while defending champion Edna Kiplagat finished fifth. Dibaba credited her fast pace over the final five kilometers, which left her competitors struggling to keep up, as the deciding factor in her victory.

site_title: Hungary's police make new arrest over migrant truck deaths in Austria
summary: Hungarian police have made a fifth arrest in connection with the deaths of 71 migrants found in an abandoned truck in Austria. The latest suspect is a Bulgarian national, a male, who is being investigated for people smuggling. The arrest was made late Saturday night, bringing the total number of arrests to five. The investigation is ongoing, with police focusing on those involved in the deaths of the migrants.

site_title: India's PM Modi accepts defeat on contentious land decree, will change law
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has accepted defeat on a contentious land decree, agreeing to let an executive order making it easier for businesses to acquire land lapse. The move comes after opposition parties failed to provide support in parliament, hindering Modi's economic reform agenda. Modi criticized false rumors spreading fear among farmers and expressed willingness to accept suggestions for the benefit of farmers. The decision may lead to states passing their own laws, allowing the government to continue implementing land acquisition despite parliament's lack of support.

site_title: Horse Racing: Legendary horse trainer Bart Cummings dies
summary: Bart Cummings, Australia's most successful horse trainer, has died at 87 in Sydney. He won the Melbourne Cup 12 times, a record, and earned the nickname "The Cups King." Cummings began his career as a strapper for his father and went on to win 268 Group One races, including the Caulfield Cup seven times and the Cox Plate five times. He was the first person inducted into Australia's Horse Racing Hall of Fame in 2001. Cummings' legacy continues to be celebrated, with his 12 Melbourne Cup wins remaining a testament to his remarkable career.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Thai officials say suspect is part of people-smuggling gang, and is uncooperative
summary: Thai authorities have arrested a suspect in connection with the deadly Bangkok bombing, which killed 20 people, mostly ethnic Chinese tourists. The suspect, identified as a foreigner believed to be part of a people-smuggling gang, was found with bomb-making equipment and multiple passports. He is being held in military custody and is uncooperative during interrogation. Police believe the suspect's gang helped illegal migrants obtain counterfeit documents, leading to a retaliation attack. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are working to determine if the suspect is the same person seen in security footage from the Erawan shrine attack.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Junta accuses media of inserting unrelated suicide vest photo during TV address
summary: Thailand's junta has accused media outlets of inserting an unrelated picture of a suicide vest into a televised address announcing the arrest of a foreign man linked to a deadly Bangkok shrine bombing. The image was not found at the suspect's flat, prompting the police to warn against sharing it online. The junta claims the picture was inserted by broadcasters, who were required to air the address. The image actually originated from the US Transportation Security Administration and has been widely used to illustrate stories about suicide bombings.

site_title: 16 get food poisoning at Bersih rally; organisers say contaminated drinks an 'act of sabotage'
summary: Sixteen people suffered food poisoning after consuming free fruit juice packets with puncture marks at a Bersih 4 rally in Kuala Lumpur. The drinks were distributed by unknown individuals, sparking suspicions of sabotage. Medical team coordinator Tan Gengta said the affected individuals experienced vomiting, nausea, and stomach discomfort. Bersih chairman Maria Chin Abdullah condemned the incident, calling it an "act of sabotage" and urging supporters to only accept bottled water from official volunteers. Police have launched an investigation into the matter.

Despite this, the rally's demands were highlighted, with the event coordinator stating it was a "victory" for the group.

Police are investigating the incident, while the NSP is conducting its own inquiries, amid the party's internal turmoil and setbacks in the lead-up to the September 11 General Election.

site_title: The Girl In The Spider's Web is good, but not as good as Larsson's thrillers
summary: The Girl In The Spider's Web, written by David Lagercrantz, is a compact thriller that follows journalist Mikael Blomkvist and hacker Lisbeth Salander as they team up to solve a complex case. While the book is readable and enjoyable, it lacks the manic energy and eccentricity of Stieg Larsson's original trilogy. Lagercrantz's portrayal of the characters is generally faithful, but some fans may be disappointed by the simplified explanation of Lisbeth's online handle and the handling of certain plot points. Overall, the book is a solid but not spectacular addition to the series, and its success may depend on the publisher's decision to commission more sequels.

Greste called for Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi to pardon them, describing the verdict as "politically motivated." The journalists were retried after an appeals court granted them a new trial, citing lack of evidence. Greste vowed to use all available means to fight the verdict, which has drawn international criticism, and urged President Sisi to pardon them to correct the "injustice."

site_title: GE2015: Police issue traffic and security advisory for Nomination Day
summary: The Singapore Police Force has issued a traffic and security advisory for Nomination Day on September 1, 2015. Nomination proceedings will begin at 11am, with parking prohibited at all nine centres. The police will step up deployment and conduct security checks, and advise supporters and the public to arrive early. Items such as sharp objects, flammable liquids, and bulky items are not allowed, and the display of candidate-related placards, flags, or banners is prohibited. Drones flying over or into the centres are also not allowed. Arrivals are recommended after 10am.

site_title: GE2015: NSP outreach effort offers clue to Sembawang line-up
summary: The National Solidarity Party (NSP) was seen actively campaigning in Sembawang GRC on August 30, 2015, with over 20 party members and activists distributing flags and fliers. The party's five-man team lineup was confirmed, but details were not revealed until nomination day. Potential candidates spotted included Spencer Ng, Eugene Yeo, Kevryn Lim, Yadzeth Haris, Ramli Mohamed, and Nicky Tan, with some members leading outreach efforts and taking photos with residents. site_title: Bangkok blast: Thailand police hunt more suspects after arrest of man
summary: Thai police widened their investigation into the deadliest bombing in the country's history after arresting a 28-year-old foreigner suspected of possessing illegal explosives. The suspect, who has been in Thailand since 2014, was found with stacks of fake passports and bomb-making materials during a raid on a Bangkok apartment block. Authorities believe the suspect was involved in the August 17 bombing at the Erawan Shrine, which killed 20 people, including 14 foreigners. Police are now searching for more suspects and monitoring over 1,000 mobile phone numbers to track down the perpetrators of the attack.

site_title: Austria death truck suspects tell court they are innocent
summary: Four suspected human traffickers appeared in a Hungarian court, claiming innocence in the deaths of 71 migrants found in a truck in Austria. The victims, believed to be mainly Syrian refugees, may have been dead for up to two days. The suspects, three Bulgarians and an Afghan, were remanded in custody until September 29. Meanwhile, Europe struggles to cope with a record influx of hundreds of thousands of refugees, with Hungary completing a razor-wire barrier along its border with Serbia.

site_title: 'Orang putih' woman mistakenly labelled as foreigner the favourite at Sarawak's Bersih rally
summary: A Sarawakian woman, Karen Shepherd, was mistakenly labelled a foreigner by a state minister, but became the favourite at the Bersih rally in Kuching, where she defended her right to be involved in the political scene. Shepherd, an Eurasian Sarawakian, emphasized the need for free and fair elections and equal voting rights for all citizens, regardless of ethnicity or location. Her speech was well-received by the crowd, with her husband also speaking at the rally, and was seen as a call for accountability and change in the system.

site_title: GE2015: Chiam See Tong will not contest coming polls, but says he still has a long way to go
summary: Opposition veteran Chiam See Tong, 80, will not contest the upcoming Singapore elections, but says he still has a long way to go in politics. Chiam, the secretary-general of the Singapore People's Party, made the announcement at a coffeeshop in Bishan-Toa Payoh, where he unveiled a joint team with the Democratic Progressive Party. He had previously led a team in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC in 2011, winning 43.1% of the vote. Chiam's decision comes as he has reduced public appearances due to age and health issues.

site_title: GE2015: Mood is better on the ground, says Ng Eng Hen, but PAP will not take votes for granted
summary: Singaporean People's Action Party (PAP) organising secretary Ng Eng Hen expressed optimism about the upcoming general election, citing a better mood among voters compared to 2011. He emphasized the PAP's commitment to integrity and trust, stating that its 89 candidates are trustworthy and will work hard to serve the people. Ng likened corruption to cancer, stressing the importance of nipping it in the bud before it spreads. He welcomed the contest in the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC under the Singapore People's Party banner, but emphasized that the PAP will not take votes for granted and will continue to work hard to win the support of the people.

site_title: GE2015: Possible candidates for SingFirst go on walkabout at Mei Ling St Market
summary: The Singapore First Party (SingFirst) has formed teams for the Tanjong Pagar and Jurong Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) for the upcoming election. The Tanjong Pagar team consists of Melvyn Chiu, Ang Yong Guan, Chirag Desai, Fahmi Rais, and Tan Jee Say, who went on a walkabout at Mei Ling St Market on August 30. The remaining candidates, including Wong Chee Wai, Tan Peng Ann, and Sukdeu Singh, will contest in Jurong GRC, marking the first time Tanjong Pagar GRC has been contested in over 20 years.

site_title: Day Two of Bersih rally begins with prayers, exercises after protesters sleep overnight in streets of KL
summary: Malaysian protesters gathered in Kuala Lumpur for the Bersih 4 rally, with around 1,000 people sleeping in the streets on Sunday morning. The rally, which began on Saturday, aimed to address growing discontent with Prime Minister Najib Razak over a funding scandal. Despite warnings to stop using horns, the noise level was lower on the second day, with some participants attending morning prayers and exercises. The rally drew an estimated 250,000 people, with many calling for clean elections and a clean government.

site_title: Wild Rice's Hotel is a five-star experience
summary: The five-star play "Hotel" by Wild Rice has been hailed as a masterpiece of Singaporean theatre, weaving a vast tapestry of history through 11 short plays spanning 100 years. The show, which tells the story of an unnamed hotel in Singapore, explores themes of identity, culture, and history, featuring a diverse cast speaking multiple languages and dialects. With its eclectic mix of genres and nods to international influences, "Hotel" has been praised for its nuanced portrayal of Singapore's linguistic heritage and socio-political climate. The play has received widespread acclaim and is now sold out, cementing its place in Singapore theatre history.

site_title: 100,000 join mass walk across 70 venues for SG50
summary: About 100,000 Singapore residents participated in a mass walk across 70 venues to celebrate the nation's SG50. The sixth annual One Community Walk, organized by the People's Association, raised $100,000 for charities. Residents from various constituencies, including Marine Parade and Ang Mo Kio, formed the Singapore flag and took a scenic stroll. The event aimed to promote community spirit and unity, with participants dressing in red to show their national pride.

site_title: 17-year-old migrant killed in shootout at sea between human smugglers and Greek police
summary: A 17-year-old migrant was killed in a shootout at sea between Greek port police and human smugglers off the island of Symi. The yacht carrying 70 migrants from Turkey's western shores was attempting to illegally enter Greek waters. Greek port police and Frontex officials managed to halt and board the boat, resulting in a scuffle that led to shots being fired. The dead migrant was "probably killed by gunfire" and an investigation has been launched. Greek Marine Minister Christos Zois expressed sadness over the youth's death, praising the police for their efforts in aiding migrants amidst Greece's struggle to cope with an unprecedented influx of migrants.

site_title: Bersih rally in Kuching cancelled, organisers cite technical issues and rule flouting
summary: The Bersih 4 rally in Kuching, Malaysia, was cancelled on August 30, 2015, due to technical issues and rule flouting. Organisers cited problems with the public address system and the presence of too many children at the event, which was prohibited by police. Despite the cancellation, the event's message of wanting free and fair democratic elections was conveyed, according to the Sarawak Bersih spokesman. The organisers plan to deliver signatures to the Chief Minister on Tuesday, viewing the event as a form of freedom of expression and action.

site_title: OCBC Cycle participants give event the thumbs-up
summary: The OCBC Cycle Singapore event concluded on Sunday with over 7,300 cyclists participating in the two-day event. Participants praised the challenging but thrilling routes, with many giving the event the thumbs-up. However, some riders, like 72-year-old Martin Tan, expressed concerns about the course's difficulty for those not physically prepared, and witnessed minor crashes along the way. Despite this, most riders enjoyed the experience, with many highlighting the National Stadium's grand finale as a highlight of the event.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Aug 30 edition
summary: Thai police have charged a foreign man, believed to be a Turkish national, over the deadly Bangkok bombing that killed 20 people and injured scores more. Four suspects in Austria's migrant truck tragedy were remanded in custody in Hungary, while three severely dehydrated refugee children were rescued in Austria. A road accident in Swaziland killed 38 girls on their way to a traditional beauty pageant, and West Ham handed Liverpool their first Premier League defeat of the season with a 3-0 win. Rafael Nadal said his form is "very close" to returning to top level after struggling through his worst season in 11 years.

site_title: Young voters say they will cast their votes with care
summary: Young voters in Singapore, aged 21-25, are expected to make their first-time votes in the upcoming election, with 245,500 youth eligible to cast their ballots. Many are concerned about education, social welfare, and job opportunities, and are looking for politicians to address these issues. While some prefer a more diverse Parliament, others believe in a stable government with good jobs and a decent standard of living. Ultimately, the key factor for young voters is the quality of candidates, not party branding.

site_title: Football: ‘World best’  Bayern go top after Mueller double
summary: Bayern Munich secured the top spot in the Bundesliga with a 3-0 win over Bayer Leverkusen, thanks to Thomas Mueller's double and Arjen Robben's penalty. Bayern coach Pep Guardiola praised his team's overall performance, while Leverkusen coach Roger Schmidt acknowledged that Bayern were the better team, saying they deserved the win.

summary: The Singapore People's Party (SPP) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have unveiled their joint team for the Bishan-Toa Payoh Group Representation Constituency (GRC) ahead of the 2015 general election. The team consists of five members: DPP chief Benjamin Pwee, chairman Hamim Aliyas, and three SPP members - Law Kim Hwee, Abdillah Zamzuri, and Bryan Long. The team will contest under the SPP banner, with Pwee and Long set to co-lead the team.

site_title: December Rains more moving than other recent works of Singaporean musical theatre
summary: Singaporean musical theatre production "December Rains" has been revived by director Goh Boon Teck, marking his company's Silver Jubilee. The 1996 musical, created by Liang Wern Fook and Jimmy Ye, tells a tear-jerking tale of love and self-sacrifice spanning 30 years. The new production features a fresh aesthetic vision with a slanted set and pastel-hued costumes. Despite initial mixed performances, the leads shine in the second act, delivering a heart-wrenching portrayal of love and heartbreak. The musical holds up as a classic work of Singaporean theatre, surpassing recent historical musicals in emotional impact.

site_title: Football: Vermaelen helps Barca overcome stubborn Malaga
summary: FC Barcelona maintained their perfect start to the La Liga season with a 1-0 win over Malaga at the Camp Nou. Thomas Vermaelen scored the only goal 18 minutes from time after a cross from Luis Suarez was parried by Malaga's Carlos Kameni. The win marked Barcelona's second consecutive 1-0 victory and saw them go top of the table. Vermaelen's goal was a surprise after a nightmare debut campaign last season, where he was perennially sidelined by injury.

site_title: New hope for families with new grant
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a Fresh Start Housing Grant to help families who sold their flats and are living in rental housing buy their own two-room flats. The grant will be given if families show they are determined to get back on their feet. Counseling will also be provided to resolve family, employment, and other problems. The grant aims to support 1,000 families living in Interim Rental Housing (IRH) blocks, with about half having already moved to rental flats and a third now owning their own homes.

site_title: Family sees light at the end of dark tunnel
summary: A 48-year-old mother, Madam Angelia Tan, has moved her family into a new two-room flat in Punggol after receiving help from a social work agency, Pave. The family had struggled with mounting mortgage arrears and limited financial resources, with Madam Tan working as a factory worker and her husband preferring to spend money on beer and 4-D bets. However, with Pave's assistance, the family's financial situation improved, and her children are now studying and working, with one accepted to study chemical engineering at Nanyang Technological University.

site_title: Finding the way home
summary: A community project in Singapore's Siglap neighborhood, led by Pave, aims to help families in need become self-reliant. Since 2012, the project, called "Project 4650," has helped about 1,000 households, with about one-third achieving homeownership. The project provides support with housing, employment, childcare, and healthcare issues, and encourages families to work towards self-reliance. Pave social workers meet with families regularly to set goals and provide guidance, and families must comply with agreements to receive aid. The project has seen success stories, such as Gary Tay, a young father who was helped by Pave to improve his job prospects and get his wife ready to work.

site_title: From heartbreak to hopes of a new home
summary: A Singaporean couple, Madam Noorliah Hawdi and Mr. Rosli Jadi, have finally found a permanent home after years of financial struggles. The family of seven, who had moved six times in three years, was forced to sell their previous homes due to mounting loan repayments after Mr. Rosli lost his job and fell ill. With the help of social workers and aid from the Social Service Office, the couple secured full-time jobs and improved their financial situation, allowing them to purchase a new three-room flat in Yishun, set to be ready in 2017.

site_title: Luxury is a bathroom to call your own
summary: A 39-year-old single mother, Shidah, has turned her life around after facing a series of challenges, including an affair that led to her husband leaving her, becoming homeless, and experiencing abuse. After receiving support from a shelter and social services, she rebuilt her life, found a job, and is now on her way to owning a four-room flat. Her twins, born prematurely, have a blood disorder and require ongoing medical care, but Shidah remains determined to rebuild her life and create a better future for her children.

site_title: Electoral prospects: It's number-crunching time
summary: Singapore's 2015 general election is approaching, with Polling Day set for September 11. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is seeking a strong mandate to claim it has received one. A convincing victory would require a significant vote share, with the opposition Workers' Party (WP) aiming for 20 opposition members in Parliament. The PAP's traditional support base, particularly among older voters, is being tested due to the Pioneer Generation package. Younger voters, who are heading to the polls for the first time, are concerned with issues such as political diversity and representation.

site_title: 'My nephew killed my sis but I can't blame him'
summary: A Singaporean PR veteran, Leela Jesudason, is now dedicating her life to helping people with mental illness after her schizophrenic nephew killed her elder sister in 2012. Her nephew, Sujay, was found guilty of culpable homicide and faces life imprisonment. Jesudason set up PSALT Care, a self-help support group for those with mental illness and addictions, and Little Bells, a non-profit to build orphanages in Nepal, in memory of her sister. Jesudason, who has an aneurysm, aims to raise awareness about mental health in Singapore and make a positive impact on her community.

site_title: Famed professor isolated flu virus; promoted arts and chess
summary: Professor Lim Kok Ann, a renowned microbiologist, isolated the flu virus in 1957 and later became dean of the medical faculty at the University of Singapore in 1965. He was also a passionate advocate for the arts, founding Centre '65, a multiracial arts group, and popularizing chess in Singapore, winning the national championship in 1949. A dedicated public servant, Lim led the Singapore Chess Federation for 18 years and served as secretary-general of Fide from 1982 to 1988, leaving a lasting legacy in Singapore's scientific and cultural communities.

site_title: Noted travel writer named tourism board chief
summary: Austin Coates, a British travel writer and novelist, was appointed director of the Singapore Tourism Promotion Board in September 1965. He aimed to attract US tourists and defined the board's image as "happy" and "harmony". Coates struggled to convey Singapore's safety subtly and eventually resigned four months later in 1966, citing the need for regional cooperation. He went on to work in Hong Kong and Portugal before his death in 1997 at 74.

site_title: PAP not taking vote of Pioneer Gen for granted
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is providing a slew of benefits to citizens aged 65 and above, dubbed the Pioneer Generation, amid shifting political landscape. The $8 billion Pioneer Generation package, which includes subsidies for healthcare, and a $3 billion package to help seniors age well, aim to alleviate concerns over rising healthcare costs and inflation. While the PAP's efforts may be seen as an attempt to secure votes, experts argue that addressing the needs of seniors is crucial for the party's electoral success, as it can influence younger generations' voting decisions and shape the future of Singapore's politics.

site_title: Record 7,000 join Orange Ribbon Run to make a stand against racism
summary: A record 7,000 participants joined the Orange Ribbon Run in Marina Bay to stand against racism, marking a significant milestone in promoting racial and religious harmony. The event, organized by OnePeople.sg, featured a 3.5km Fun Family Walk, 10km run, and 5km run categories. Key figures such as former national sprinter C. Kunalan and Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean participated, emphasizing the importance of unity and inclusivity. The event aimed to inspire a sense of national pride and unity among participants.

site_title: What would be a 'good' win for PAP?
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore is seeking a "strong mandate" in the upcoming general election, which would be an acknowledgement of its past efforts and approval of its current and future direction towards an "inclusive society" with stronger social safety nets. A convincing victory would require a vote share of around 65 per cent, according to analysts, with estimates suggesting the PAP may retain around 60 per cent of the vote share but still lose some seats to the opposition. The PAP's success is measured by the size of its winning margin and the number of seats it concedes to the opposition, with maintaining the status quo being seen as a reason for celebration in this "milder political climate."

The family, who were injured in the blast, received medical treatment in Thailand before being cleared to fly back to Singapore. They were welcomed back by a family member and friend at Changi Airport, and will undergo further treatment at Singapore General Hospital.

site_title: Indonesia launches its first air raid on Malaysia
summary: Indonesia launched its first air raid on Malaysia on September 1, 1965, targeting a remote highland settlement in Pa' Umor, Sarawak. Two Mitchell bombers strafed the village, but no casualties were reported. The attack, deemed to have no military value, was intended to boost Indonesian forces' morale, following their losses in previous incursions. This marked the first air attack by Indonesia on Malaysia, which had repeatedly violated Malaysian airspace in opposition to Malaysia's formation.

site_title: 'Expect more to be self-radicalised'
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean warns that the ongoing conflict in Syria and Iraq will draw more individuals to violence, increasing the likelihood of self-radicalised cases in Singapore. The country has seen a rise in detained individuals, including a 51-year-old Singaporean who was on his way to join ISIS, and others who have been issued restriction orders. Teo notes that anyone is susceptible to extremist rhetoric, highlighting the need for continued vigilance and rehabilitation efforts.

site_title: Festive start to new NTU academic year
summary: Thousands of people gathered at Marina Bay Promontory for NTU Fest, a celebration marking SG50 and the start of the new academic year. Education Minister Heng Swee Keat officiated the event, which included a carnival, charity run, and concert. The concert featured the National Day song Home and K-pop group Dal Shabet, kicking off the festive occasion. The event aimed to bring students and the community together to kick off the new academic year.

site_title: Activist apologises to minister for remarks
summary: Independent scholar and activist Sangeetha Thanapal, 33, has apologized to Law and Foreign Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam for a Facebook post criticizing his comments on growing polarization in Malaysia. The post, which was deemed "inaccurate and seditious" by the minister, falsely attributed sentiments to him that he never held. After a meeting with the minister, Sangeetha accepted his apology and acknowledged the mistake. Minister Shanmugam has declined to lodge a police report, citing a lack of intention to cause ill will between races.

site_title: 'Improper activities' by American officials
summary: Singapore-US ties were strained in 1965 after the CIA offered the Singapore Government $10 million to hush up the arrest of an American intelligence officer, Ho Ai Li. Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew revealed the incident in an interview, stating that he was prepared to work with other countries, not the US, after Britain withdrew its military base. Lee claimed the US government "lacked depth of judgment" and that an offer of $10 million was an "insult." The US denied the allegations, prompting Lee to release a letter of apology from US Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

site_title: Movie treat for 2,200 ST readers, partners
summary: More than 2,200 ST subscribers and corporate partners were given complimentary tickets to the critically acclaimed movie "7 Letters" as part of The Straits Times' 170th anniversary celebrations. The film, an anthology of short films celebrating SG50, features prominent local directors and was extended to Sept 2 due to popular demand. Attendees praised the film's nostalgic value and appreciation for Singapore, with one sales manager stating it helped her "appreciate my country more." The event was held at the Golden Village cineplex at VivoCity on Aug 30.

site_title: Therapy on wheels for senior citizens
summary: Singapore's Lien Foundation aims to address the shortage of therapists by deploying "therapy" buses to eldercare facilities, equipped with specialized gym equipment for the elderly. The initiative, inspired by Finland's successful model, seeks to increase access to therapy services. The foundation also plans to bring in Finnish expertise to boost the training of Singaporean therapists, with a goal to address the country's aging population and the expected shortage of 13,000 physiotherapists by 2030.

site_title: Exercise helped singer turn his life around
summary: Finnish opera singer Hannu Ilmolahti, who performed in a wheelchair due to health issues, turned his life around after joining a gym chain in Finland at age 53. He lost 45kg, improved his sugar and cholesterol levels, and regained mobility, inspiring others to take action. Ilmolahti, who had 6 surgeries, credits the gym for his transformation, saying "it's never too late to get off the sofa." His story highlights the importance of taking control of one's health and seizing opportunities for positive change.

site_title: Boss of sugar dating sites on the defence
summary: Singapore's largest sugar dating website, SeekingArrangement.com, has been defended by its CEO, Brandon Wade, who claims the site is not a front for prostitution. Wade likened sugar daddies to wealthy boyfriends and argued that paying for companionship is not prostitution. The site has 1,200 male and 700 female members from Singapore, and Wade insists that prostitutes and escorts are not allowed on the site. Experts, however, warn that the business model is attractive and that surveillance is needed to prevent vulnerable women from being drawn into prostitution.

site_title: SingFirst brings up foreign labour issue
summary: Singapore's SingFirst party has criticized the government's liberal immigration policies, citing the influx of foreign workers as a cause for increased psychological problems among Singaporeans. The party's candidates, including retired police officer Sukdeu Singh and psychiatrist Dr Ang Yong Guan, argue that the current policies have led to income stagnation and a widening gap between citizens and foreigners. SingFirst plans to introduce a $6 billion social safety net plan to support poor and middle-class Singaporeans, including monthly cash allowances and subsidized healthcare and childcare fees.

site_title: Crowd-funding to raise funds for elections allowed
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) in Singapore has allowed candidates to use crowd-funding to raise money for the upcoming polls, as long as they comply with restrictions outlined in the Political Donations Act. Candidates can accept donations from permissible donors, with anonymous donations capped at $5,000. Donations from foreign sources or individuals under 21 are prohibited. Candidates, such as Reform Party member Roy Ngerng, are using online platforms to raise funds, with the goal of reaching their election deposit of $14,500.

site_title: Accountability and transparency are vital
summary: Singapore Democratic Party secretary-general Chee Soon Juan announced his candidacy for the upcoming general election, focusing on accountability and transparency. He plans to introduce more opposition MPs in Parliament, allowing for meaningful debate and challenge of bills. Chee, an adjunct lecturer and PhD holder, aims to run town councils directly without managing agents and ensure resident-elected boards. His party's platform prioritizes citizen involvement and informed decision-making, contrasting with the current system where party whip obligations often lead to party-line voting. Chee's candidacy is seen as a push for more citizen participation in governance.

site_title: Elder-friendly gym machines for active ageing
summary: The Lien Foundation has introduced $2.2 million worth of elder-friendly gym equipment from Finland to promote active ageing habits among seniors in Singapore. The equipment, featuring air-pressure systems and smart cards, allows users to track their progress and adjust settings individually. The goal is to prevent incidents such as falls by building strength and promoting exercise among seniors. Research from Finland shows that strength training can reduce falls by up to half, resulting in significant healthcare cost savings. The initiative aims to encourage seniors to engage in physical activity, rather than isolating them, and has already seen positive results.

site_title: Focus on 'you' may reflect changing times
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore has introduced a new election slogan, "With You, For You, For Singapore", emphasizing its direct appeal to individual voters, a change from its past use of "our" in slogans. This shift is seen as a reflection of the changing times and politics following the 2011 General Election, when the PAP's vote share fell and opposition members entered Parliament. The PAP's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has emphasized the party's responsiveness to voters, while warning against the dangers of voting opposition while wishing for a PAP government.

The SDP has a slate of 11 candidates, and Chee described his candidates as individuals with brains and hearts, committed to speaking up for the people in Parliament. The party will focus on its alternative policies in education, healthcare, and other areas, aiming to address the cost of living and other issues affecting Singaporeans.

site_title: Party makes call for national minimum wage
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has proposed a national minimum wage pegged to the average expenditure of a four-person household, starting at 80% of $1,250, a figure based on the 2013 Household Expenditure Survey. The party aims to help financially strapped families and promote productivity, as well as encourage older Singaporeans and women to re-enter the workforce. The proposal, listed in the party's 2015 election manifesto, also includes measures to support the poor, such as adjusting Silver Support Scheme payouts and maintaining 10% of total land area as reserves.

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the PAP has kept all its promises, including those made at the 2011 General Election. The 88-page manifesto covers five chapters, including the PAP's achievements, plans, and vision for Singapore. Key promises include investing in education, providing affordable healthcare, and building affordable public housing. The PAP will also work with Singaporeans to address internal and external challenges, such as a diverse society and uncertain global economic outlook.

site_title: WP 'can propose policy alternatives'
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has released its manifesto, titled "Empower Your Future," which proposes over 130 policy alternatives to the People's Action Party's (PAP) offerings. The party's central executive council member Gerald Giam said the larger slate of elected MPs and increased membership since 2011 put the WP in a stronger position to propose alternatives. Giam emphasized the party's goal is to bring good ideas to the table, not to form the government, and urged voters to keep the momentum going to entrench the opposition's presence in Parliament.

site_title: The extent of Yang Yin's manipulation
summary: A former China tour guide, Yang Yin, was found to have manipulated an 88-year-old widow, Madam Chung Khin Chun, into giving him control of her $35 million fortune. Yang had promised Madam Chung's maid $1 million if she said good things about him, but she declined. Yang allegedly took control of her life and finances, evicting her family and friends, and even changing her medication. The judge threw out the will that left the fortune to Yang, replacing it with one that leaves most of the money to charity. Yang is contesting the decision and faces over 300 criminal charges, including falsifying receipts and misappropriating $1.1 million.

Many are making trips to Johor Baru to purchase goods such as dental services, household items, and food, with some saving up to 50% on costs. The low exchange rate has also benefited JB residents who commute to Singapore, and some businesses have opened outlets in JB to capitalize on the trend.

Lee emphasized that voters must take the general election seriously and not "live dangerously" by voting for one party but expecting another to form the government.

site_title: Egypt court hands Al-Jazeera reporters three years in jail
summary: An Egyptian court sentenced Al-Jazeera reporters Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed to three years in prison for broadcasting "false" news that harmed Egypt. The verdict sparked international condemnation, with Qatar-based Al-Jazeera calling it an "attack on press freedom." Canadian journalist Mohamed Fahmy's lawyer, Amal Clooney, expressed concern that the ruling sets a "dangerous precedent" for journalists in Egypt. The journalists were arrested in 2013, months after the military ousted Islamist president Mohamed Morsi.

summary: Austria has arrested four suspects in connection with the deaths of 71 refugees found in a truck on an Austrian motorway. Meanwhile, Hungarian police have remanded three Bulgarians and one Afghan in custody for their alleged involvement in human trafficking. Two children were found in a van near the German border, and three others were rescued from a truck with 26 migrants. The UN has estimated 300,000 people have fled conflict in the Middle East and Africa for a better life in Europe, with 2,500 dying in the attempt.

site_title: MAKE IT YOURSELF: SIMMERED LOTUS ROOT
summary: A recipe for simmered lotus root is provided, requiring 1kg of lotus root, 250g of streaky bacon, and various seasonings. To prepare, soak 20cm konbu in water for an hour, then make a dashi broth with the konbu and bonito flakes. Slice the lotus root and soak it in acidulated water to prevent browning. The root is then stir-fried with bacon and dashi, simmered for about an hour, and seasoned with mirin, shoyu, and scallions. The dish serves six to eight as a side.

site_title: Murder charge in ‘cold-blooded assassination’ of US policeman
summary: Deputy Darren Goforth, 47, was fatally shot from behind and multiple times in Houston, Texas, due to his job as a police officer. Shannon Miles, 30, with a long criminal history, was charged with capital murder. Authorities believe Goforth was targeted because of his uniform, with no other motive identified. The killing has sparked outrage, with officials pointing to increased rhetoric against police officers in the US, particularly during protests against perceived police brutality. The incident has highlighted the dangers faced by law enforcement and the need for support.

site_title: MND alarmed at WP agent's profits
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) accused managing agent FM Solutions and Services (FMSS) of grossly profiting from its contract with the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) at the expense of the town council. FMSS made a $2 million net profit in 2013/2014, despite paying its owners $1.14 million in salaries. The ministry also found that AHPETC suffered an operating deficit of $2 million in the same year. WP chairman Sylvia Lim disputed the allegations, saying payments were made in accordance with contracts and not "overpayment".

site_title: AHPETC faced losses while agent's profits jumped 300%: MND
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has released figures showing that the managing agent of the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) made a 300% jump in profit after tax, while the town council's revenue rose by only 30% over the same period. MND described the profit margin as "abnormal" and accused FM Solutions and Services (FMSS) of "gross profiteering" from its only client, AHPETC. The ministry also noted that payments to FMSS owners, who were also senior officers of the town council, amounted to 22% of the town council's revenue in 2012/13 and 36% in 2013/14.

summary: A road accident in Swaziland killed 38 girls and seriously injured 20 others who were on their way to the traditional Reed Dance ceremony, where King Mswati III chooses a new wife.
