King Mswati III has expressed his condolences to the parents of the deceased and promised to support them, as well as provide further treatment to those injured.

site_title: Arrest in Bangkok bomber hunt - what we know so far
summary: Thai police have arrested a 28-year-old foreign man in connection with the deadly August 17 Bangkok shrine bombing that killed 20 people, mostly ethnic Chinese tourists. The suspect, believed to be Turkish but whose nationality is being verified, was found with bomb-making equipment and dozens of passports at a four-storey apartment in Bangkok's eastern suburb. The arrest is a potential breakthrough in the investigation, which had been struggling to find a clear motive or name a suspect. Police are still trying to determine the suspect's nationality and what led them to the apartment.

site_title: Football: Goal-shy Arsenal continue to stutter
summary: Arsenal's goal-shy attack continues to hinder their Premier League performance, despite being touted as title challengers before the season. The team has failed to score in two matches at the Emirates Stadium and only managed 21 efforts on goal in their last outing, which ended in a 1-0 victory over Newcastle. Manager Arsene Wenger attributes the underwhelming start to lack of clinical finishing and notes that the team still has offensive potential, with several key players out injured. Wenger remains optimistic about bringing in attacking reinforcements before the end of the transfer window.

site_title: Football: Hammers hand Liverpool first defeat of season with 3-0 win
summary: West Ham United handed Liverpool their first Premier League defeat of the season with a 3-0 win at Anfield, ending a 52-year wait for success at the stadium. Goals from Manuel Lanzini and Mark Noble put West Ham in control, with Diafra Sakho sealing the rout in stoppage-time. Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho was sent off in the second half, and the team struggled to create scoring opportunities without him, ultimately succumbing to their first defeat of the season.

site_title: Vatican paedophilia suspect died of heart problems: Autopsy
summary: Former Polish archbishop Jozef Wesolowski, 67, who was set to go on trial for paedophilia, died of natural causes linked to heart problems, according to the Vatican. Wesolowski was charged with possessing child pornography and abusing minors during his time as the Vatican nuncio in the Dominican Republic. His death ends the first trial of its kind initiated by the Vatican against a church official. A post-mortem was conducted, and further laboratory tests are pending. Wesolowski's funeral will be held on Monday, with his body to be transported to Poland according to his family's wishes.

site_title: New Orleans mourns dead, celebrates life on Katrina anniversary
summary: New Orleans marked the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina on August 29, 2015, with a mix of solemnity and celebration. The city remembered the 1,800 people killed and 1 million displaced, with over $150 billion in damages. Leaders laid wreaths at a memorial for unknown victims, while Mayor Mitch Landrieu stated, "New Orleans will be unbowed and unbroken." The city has made significant progress in rebuilding, with improvements in tourism, education, and crime rates. US President Barack Obama praised the "extraordinary resilience" of those who returned to repair and rebuild.

site_title: Tennis: Murray urges patience as Kyrgios matures
summary: Britain's Andy Murray has expressed sympathy for Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, who made crude remarks about Stan Wawrinka's girlfriend during a match in Canada. Murray believes Kyrgios is a talented player who needs patience, as he matures at a different rate. Despite a 28-day ban for "aggravated behaviour" and a fine, Murray thinks the controversy might not hinder Kyrgios' game, as he likes playing on big stages. The two will face each other in the first round of the US Open, with Murray focusing on their upcoming match rather than Kyrgios' controversy.

site_title: Olympics: Rio 2016 organisers 'extremely concerned' over sick sailor
summary: German sailor Erik Heil fell ill after competing in the test event for the Rio 2016 Olympics, with organisers expressing "extreme concern" over the incident. Heil, who won third place in the 49er class, was treated in a Berlin hospital for multiple infections, which he believes were caused by polluted waters in Guanabara Bay. The incident has raised pressure on Rio organisers to ensure the safety of athletes competing in sailing, swimming, and triathlon events, with Heil's case being taken up by the German Olympic Sports Confederation.

site_title: Football: Palace stun Chelsea as slick City set club record
summary: Chelsea suffered its second Premier League defeat under Jose Mourinho as Crystal Palace clinched a 2-1 win at Stamford Bridge. Bakary Sako scored in the 65th minute for Palace, but Radamel Falcao equalized in the 79th minute for Chelsea. Joel Ward headed home in the 81st minute to secure Palace's first win at the Bridge since 1982, ending Mourinho's 100th home fixture unbeaten streak. Meanwhile, Manchester City extended its 100% record with a 2-0 win against Watford at Eastlands.

site_title: Thai police charge foreign man over Bangkok bombing
summary: Thai police have charged a foreign man, believed to be a Turkish national, with illegal possession of bomb-making materials over the deadly Bangkok bombing that killed 20 people. The suspect was arrested during a raid on an apartment and found with bomb-making equipment linked to the August 17 blast. He is also suspected of involvement in a blast near a popular tourist pier, which caused no injuries. Authorities believe the suspect was motivated by a "personal feud" and that international terrorism is unlikely.

site_title: Bangkok blast suspect 'unlikely' international terrorist, spurred by 'personal feud': Police
summary: A suspect in the Bangkok bomb attack, which killed 20 people, is unlikely to be an international terrorist, according to Thai police. The suspect, identified as Adem Karadag, used a false Turkish passport and is believed to have been motivated by a "personal feud" rather than a terrorist ideology. Police chief Somyot Poompanmoung stated that the suspect was angry on behalf of his friends and family members, and not driven by a desire to target a specific group or shrine. The motive behind the attack remains unclear.

site_title: Athletics: Bolt caps Beijing outing with Jamaica triumph in 4x100m, China get silver
summary: Usain Bolt capped off his Beijing 2015 IAAF World Championships with a third gold medal in the 4x100m relay. Bolt ran the final leg of the Jamaican team, crossing the line in 37.36 seconds. Initially, the US team was awarded silver but was later disqualified. China was upgraded to silver in 38.01 seconds, while Canada took bronze in 38.13 seconds.

site_title: Activist apologises to minister for remarks
summary: Independent scholar and activist Sangeetha Thanapal has apologised to Law and Foreign Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam for a Facebook post that he deemed "inaccurate and seditious". The post, which questioned Minister Shanmugam's comments on growing polarisation in Malaysia, was later found to be untrue. The minister met with Sangeetha and accepted her apology, stating that he would not lodge a police report and that their conversation was not prompted by her apology or conduct.

site_title: Chad executes 10 Boko Haram suspects by firing squad
summary: Chad executed 10 alleged members of Boko Haram, a Nigeria-based Islamist group, by firing squad on Saturday, following a guilty verdict in a double suicide killing that left 38 people dead in the capital N'Djamena. The defendants were found guilty of various crimes, including criminal conspiracy, killings, and using psychotropic substances. The executions mark the first trial of presumed Boko Haram members in Chad. The regional force against Boko Haram, involving 8,700 troops and police, is expected to be deployed soon.

site_title: Hollande, Merkel, Putin back ceasefire plan for eastern Ukraine
summary: France, Germany, and Russia support a complete ceasefire in eastern Ukraine starting September 1, following agreements between Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists. The leaders of the three countries, including French President Francois Hollande, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and Russian President Vladimir Putin, spoke by telephone and expressed the need for a lasting ceasefire to protect civilians in eastern Ukraine. A summit with Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko is proposed in the coming weeks to discuss the situation.

site_title: RSAF wins three awards in American air combat exercise
summary: The Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) won three awards at the recent Exercise Red Flag-Nellis in Nevada, US. The RSAF's Peace Carvin II detachment took home the "Best Aircraft Maintenance Unit" award for maintaining its F-16C/D fighter aircraft. Capt. Jireh Ang received the "Best Overall Mission Commander" award for his performance as a mission commander, while Capt. Sean Teo won the "Best Personnel Rescue Warrior" award for leading a successful recovery mission. The RSAF has been participating in Exercise Red Flag-Nellis since 1982.

site_title: Learning mother tongues should be "special", "alive" and "easy" says Education Minister
summary: Singapore's Education Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that learning mother tongues should be made "easy", "alive", and "special". He suggested that schools find ways to help children learn naturally and easily, and that resources should be tailored to appeal to children at different ages. Heng also urged educators to teach mother tongues in a way that makes them come alive, beyond textbook learning, and to incorporate cultural performances, books, and media into the learning process.

site_title: Swimming: Australia women's relay team keep golden streak at Fina World Juniors going
summary: Australia's women's 4x100m freestyle relay team secured their fifth consecutive gold medal at the Fina World Junior Swimming Championships, breaking the world junior record with a time of 3:39.87 seconds. Meanwhile, New Zealand's Gabrielle Fa'Amausili set a new 50m backstroke record with 27.81 seconds, and Italy's Simona Quadarella took gold in the 1,500m freestyle final with 16:05.61 seconds. The event concluded with Australia maintaining their dominance in the championships.

site_title: Turkish jets join US-led coalition strikes on ISIS
summary: Turkish jets participated in US-led coalition air strikes against ISIS fighters in Syria for the first time, following a technical agreement with the US on August 24. The operation began on Friday, targeting IS targets that pose a threat to Turkey's security. This marks the first time Turkish jets have been involved in the coalition campaign, following a previous attack on ISIS targets on July 24. Turkey had agreed to open its air bases to the coalition last month, despite initial reluctance to play a leading role in the fight against ISIS.

site_title: Malaysia DPM Ahmad Zahid Hamidi: Deputies have no right to question election funds
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi has stated that Umno deputies have no right to question the sources of election funds, advising them to be loyal to superiors or face the same fate as sacked deputies. This comes amid a multi-million-dollar payment made to Prime Minister Najib Razak's account, sparking a peaceful protest in Kuala Lumpur. Zahid urged Umno leaders to work together to overcome internal conflict and confusion, warning that the real enemy lies within the party itself.

summary: The Singapore People's Party (SPP) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have signed an agreement to field a joint team in the Bishan-Toa Payoh Group Representation Constituency (GRC) for the 2015 General Election. The joint team, comprising five members, including DPP chiefs Benjamin Pwee and Hamim Aliyas, will contest under the SPP banner. The agreement was finalized just three days before Nomination Day, following a month-long negotiation that was marked by disagreements over team composition.

site_title: Malaysians involved in Bersih protests overseas could face legal action
summary: Malaysian Deputy Minister Reezal Merican announced that the country's Foreign Ministry will gather information on Malaysians involved in Bersih 4 protests abroad to take legal action. He stated that participating in overseas protests could tarnish the country's image and expressed concern that demonstrators were not patriotic by choosing a date close to National Day celebrations. Merican emphasized that freedom of speech must be exercised within the law and that demonstrations can result in harsh penalties. The move aims to deter Malaysians from participating in protests abroad.

site_title: Egypt's president in 1st State Visit to Singapore since diplomatic relations began in 1966
summary: Egypt's President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi is set to make a State Visit to Singapore from Aug 30 to Sept 1, marking the first visit by an Egyptian president since diplomatic relations began in 1966. He will be officially welcomed at the Istana, meet with President Tony Tan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and attend a business event. President Al Sisi will be accompanied by Egyptian ministers, and President Tan will host a State Banquet in his honor. This visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties between the two countries.

site_title: Politicians who have strayed should return to the right path: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad urged politicians who have strayed to return to their duties and protect the rights of the people who voted for them. He criticized Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is facing allegations of illegal fund transfers, and called for his resignation. Mahathir also expressed uncertainty about attending a mass rally demanding Najib's resignation, stating he is "still thinking". His comments reflect his long-standing criticism of Najib's leadership, with the former leader repeatedly calling for his removal from office.

site_title: Dr Mahathir and wife visit Bersih rally site at Dataran Merdeka
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Dr. Mahathir Mohamad and his wife Dr. Siti Hasmah visited the Dataran Merdeka rally site on August 29, 2015, where protesters demanded Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation due to allegations of embezzlement. The crowd surrounded Dr. Mahathir after he exited his car, but he only stayed for five minutes. The rally, organized by Bersih, drew an estimated 200,000 people, with similar events held in other cities worldwide, including Sydney, Melbourne, and Hong Kong.

site_title: GE2015: Highlights of proposals from the Workers' Party's manifesto
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) released its 48-page "Empower Your Future" manifesto for the 2015 general election, outlining over 130 proposals across six areas. Key proposals include providing assistance for childcare and work-life balance, a mandatory unemployment insurance scheme, and a national minimum wage pegged to household expenditure. The WP also proposed a 10-year through-train school programme and raising the CPF payout eligibility age to 60. Additionally, the party called for the abolition of group representation constituencies and the establishment of an independent election commission.

site_title: GE2015: 10 things about PAP's unveiling of election manifesto
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong unveiled the People's Action Party's (PAP) manifesto for the 2015 general election, marking a new phase of development for Singapore. The election was called in the SG50 year to seek a fresh and strong mandate, with PM Lee emphasizing leadership renewal and the importance of a full slate of candidates across the board. The PAP's campaign slogan, "With you, for you, for Singapore," was introduced, and the party promised to support its candidates in opposition-held wards. The election is scheduled to take place in January 2017.

site_title: Golf: Jordan Spieth's reign as world No. 1 ends with missed cut at The Barclays
summary: Jordan Spieth's reign as world No. 1 ended after a missed cut at The Barclays, allowing Rory McIlroy to reclaim the top spot. Spieth, the US Masters and US Open champion, shot a 147, five strokes over par, after a first-round 74 and a 73 in the second round. Bubba Watson took the lead at the halfway mark, followed by Zach Johnson and Henrik Stenson. Spieth vowed to rebound, but couldn't gain traction, and McIlroy will return to No. 1 when the rankings are updated on Monday.

site_title: Basketball: Los Angeles Lakers are open to extending Kobe Bryant's contract
summary: Los Angeles Lakers president Jim Buss is open to extending Kobe Bryant's contract, despite his advancing age and injury record. Bryant, 37, will earn $25 million this year and has won five NBA titles with the Lakers. Buss believes Bryant deserves the generous contract due to his contributions to the team and fans, and will discuss the possibility of an extension with him. Buss leaves the decision ultimately up to Bryant, stating he will "explain the role" and allow him to decide his own fate.

site_title: Athletics: Bolt set for 3rd gold medal after Jamaica qualify fastest for 4x100m final
summary: Usain Bolt's team, Jamaica, easily qualified for the men's 4x100m final at the world athletics championships, setting the fastest qualifying time of 37.41 seconds. This move puts Bolt on track to win a third gold medal, having already won the 100m and 200m events. Jamaica's heat victory also puts them ahead of the US, who finished second with a time of 37.91. Bolt is attempting to complete the sprint treble for the third time at the championships, a feat he previously achieved in 2009 and 2013.

site_title: North Korea agrees to talks with South on family reunions
summary: North Korea has agreed to Red Cross talks with South Korea to discuss reunions of families separated during the Korean War. The talks, set to take place on September 7, aim to resume meetings between families, with nearly 130,000 South Koreans seeking relatives in the North. The agreement follows a recent accord to defuse tensions, ending a military standoff that sparked artillery fire. This will be the first meeting under the accord, which also includes working towards resuming family reunions.

site_title: MND accuses managing agent FMSS of "grossly profiteering" from WP-run town council; Sylvia Lim responds
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has accused FM Solutions & Services (FMSS) of grossly profiteering from its sole client, the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC), which was run by the Workers' Party (WP). MND claims that FMSS made a net after-tax profit of $2 million in 2013/2014, while AHPETC suffered an operating deficit of $2 million. WP chairman Sylvia Lim has responded, saying the MND's accusations are "careless" and "politically motivated" aimed at discrediting the party.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Police arrest man who fits description of main suspect
summary: Thai police have arrested a man "likely involved" with a deadly bomb attack on the Erawan shrine in Bangkok, killing 20 people and wounding scores more. The suspect, described as a foreign man, was found in an apartment in Bangkok's eastern outskirts. Authorities discovered bomb-making materials and dozens of passports in his room, but it's unclear if he's the same suspect seen on security cameras. The arrest comes as investigators continue to explore multiple theories, including involvement by China's ethnic Uighur Muslim minority or international militants.

site_title: SUTD's pioneer batch graduates, and gets $500 each to come back and keep learning
summary: Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) held its first graduation ceremony for 308 pioneer batch students. Two-thirds of the graduates have secured jobs or will pursue graduate studies, with top sectors including engineering, banking, and finance. Education Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of character and inner strength. SUTD is giving all graduates $500 in an electronic account to encourage continued learning, matching the Government's SkillsFuture initiative.

site_title: Myanmar approves first ever national minimum wage
summary: Myanmar's government has approved a national minimum wage of 3,600 kyat (S$4) per day for a standard eight-hour workday, effective Tuesday. The wage applies to all sectors and industries, excluding small businesses with fewer than 15 employees. The decision follows months of negotiations with labor groups and employers, and comes amid growing protests for better pay and conditions. The move is seen as part of Myanmar's economic reforms, following the end of direct junta rule in 2011.

site_title: Egypt court sentences Al-Jazeera reporters to three years in jail
summary: An Egyptian court sentenced three Al Jazeera journalists to three years in prison in a retrial. Mohamed Fahmy, Baher Mohamed, and Peter Greste were found guilty of operating without a press license and broadcasting material deemed harmful to Egypt. The case has sparked international outrage, with many criticizing the verdict as a restriction on press freedom. The journalists were initially arrested in 2013 and held for two years before being released in February. The sentence has been widely condemned by human rights groups and international organizations.

site_title: Bersih rally organisers promise not to enter historic Merdeka Square
summary: Malaysian protest group Bersih has assured the Human Rights Commission that they will not enter historic Merdeka Square during their rally, after police barred them from the venue. Bersih chief Maria Chin Abdullah confirmed that participants will instead gather around the historic field, out of respect for police rehearsals and preparations for the country's Independence Day on Monday. The decision comes after the police gave the assurance that they would not take action if protesters did not break the law. The rally participants will still march through city streets, waving the national flag.

site_title: GE2015: Singapore Democratic Party's Chee Soon Juan says he will contest election, unveils 2 more candidates
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) secretary-general Chee Soon Juan announced his candidacy for the upcoming election, unveiling two additional candidates, ex-political detainee Wong Souk Yee and Mr Sadasivam Veriyah. This marks Chee's first election contest since 2001, after being declared bankrupt in 2006 and 2011. The SDP plans to contest multiple constituencies, focusing on cost of living, CPF Minimum Sum, and population growth issues. Eight other SDP candidates have already been introduced, with the election scheduled for September 11.

site_title: Record number of awards from self-help groups for kids who did well in exams
summary: The Chinese Development Assistance Council, Eurasian Association, Sinda, and Yayasan Mendaki presented Joint Tuition Awards to 694 students in Singapore, recognizing their academic improvement in exams such as the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) and O levels. This marks the highest number of awards given by the self-help groups, with each student receiving $100 to $150 worth of Popular bookstore vouchers. The awards aim to promote education and social mobility in Singapore, with the Education Ministry and self-help groups partnering to set up 30 school-based student care centers.

site_title: Australian PM Abbott rules out random visa checks
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has ruled out random visa checks on the streets, stating that such actions would never happen under his government. The announcement came after a planned police operation in Melbourne was cancelled due to public outrage over a press release announcing the operation, which sparked fears of targeting individuals of foreign appearance. Abbott described the press release as "clumsy" and "over the top," and clarified that the government would only refer suspected visa breaches to the Australian Border Force in the usual way.

site_title: GE2015: PAP's manifesto sets out its achievements, challenges and vision
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) launched its 2015 general election manifesto, titled "With You, For You, For Singapore," on August 29. The 98-page document outlines the party's achievements, challenges, and vision for the country. Key points include the party's vision for every Singaporean to realise their full potential, addressing challenges such as healthcare costs, affordability of housing, and competition for jobs. The PAP also highlights its plans to tackle external challenges like global economic uncertainty and regional competition, and to build a meritocracy of skills and support families.

site_title: A sea of yellow in Kuala Lumpur as protesters demand Najib's resignation
summary: Thousands of protesters gathered in Kuala Lumpur's Merdeka Square to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Najib Razak over an alleged multi-million-dollar transfer of state funds to his personal account. The rally, organized by Bersih, attracted an estimated 80,000-200,000 people, with many wearing yellow "Bersih 4" T-shirts. Despite a government ban, protesters continued to march and rally, with prominent figures including opposition leaders and civil society activists. The rally marks the second consecutive day of protests demanding Najib's resignation amidst widespread corruption allegations.

site_title: Split in Japan's biggest yakuza crime syndicate; police warn of wave of violence
summary: A rift has emerged in Japan's largest yakuza crime syndicate, the Yamaguchi-gumi, with 13 leaders being kicked out and 11 members forming a new group. The split could lead to a wave of gang violence, prompting police to warn of potential inter-gang conflict. The Yamaguchi-gumi, with 23,000 members, has been weakened by periodic crackdowns, a poor public image, and Japan's economic struggles, making membership less attractive. Police are working to collect information and take measures to weaken the organization.

The rally, part of a nationwide protest, aimed to bring attention to electoral reform and Najib's alleged misuse of funds.

site_title: Hong Kong thief swapped diamond for fake
summary: A thief in Hong Kong swapped a $220,000 diamond with a fake at a luxury jewelry store in the city's Central financial district. The diamond was taken by a man in his 30s on Friday after he picked it out and was suspected to have swapped it with a fake. No arrests have been made. Shop theft in Hong Kong has increased by over 15% in the first half of the year, with 4,961 cases reported. A similar diamond necklace theft in January remains unsolved.

site_title: A HeadStart for School Pocket Money Fund beneficiaries, as centre donates $20,000
summary: HeadStart for Life, a paediatric intervention centre, donated $20,000 to the Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, benefiting 14,000 low-income students. The donation supports services including speech and occupational therapy, social skills training, and play programmes. The funds will help meet the needs of students from disadvantaged families. The donation aligns with HeadStart for Life's mission to improve the lives of children and youth through education, and is part of the centre's grand reopening at its newly renovated premises.

site_title: More cases of self-radicalisation expected in Singapore due to Syria conflict: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean warned that more self-radicalised individuals can be expected in Singapore due to the ongoing conflict in Syria and Iraq. The conflict is drawing more individuals to violence, and Singapore can expect more cases of self-radicalisation. In the last few months, the Internal Security Department has detained three individuals, including two in their late teens and one 51 years old, who were susceptible to ISIS's online extremist rhetoric. The Inter-Agency Aftercare Group and Religious Rehabilitation Group have provided religious and social rehabilitation to radicalised individuals.

site_title: UN chief defends trip to Beijing for military parade amid Japan's concerns
summary: UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon defended his trip to Beijing to watch a military parade marking the end of World War II, despite Japan's concerns. Ban stated that China's contribution and sacrifice during the war are recognized and appreciated by the world. He emphasized the importance of looking to the past to learn lessons and move forward. Thousands of Chinese troops will march through Beijing on Thursday, with South Korean President Park Geun Hye and a senior North Korean official also in attendance, but Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will not attend due to strong displeasure with Ban's attendance.

summary: Tens of thousands of Hindu pilgrims and holy men took a sacred dip in the Godavari river during the first main bathing day of India's Kumbh Mela festival, with organizers citing increased safety measures to avoid a repeat of a deadly stampede in 2003 that killed 39 people. Despite some initial chaos, the event passed without major incident, with officials and police present to manage the crowds. The two-month festival, which draws millions of pilgrims, has two main bathing dates left.

site_title: California doctor dubbed 'Candyman' convicted of illegal prescriptions
summary: A California doctor, Julio Gabriel Diaz, nicknamed "Candyman," was convicted on 79 counts of distributing controlled substances for writing 1.7 million opioid prescriptions in 2011. Diaz, 67, was found guilty after a two-and-a-half week trial, with evidence showing he prescribed powerful painkillers to drug addicts, leading to some deaths from overdoses. Diaz faces a maximum 1,360-year sentence, but federal guidelines typically call for less time, following the revocation of his medical license by California.

site_title: Wall Street ends flat in quiet end to dramatic week
summary: Wall Street ended a dramatic week on a flat note, rebounding from earlier losses after Fed vice-chairman Stanley Fischer suggested the Fed had not yet decided to raise interest rates in September. Despite concerns about a potential rate hike, the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average ended the week with gains, with the S&P rising 0.9% and the Dow gaining 1.1%. The Nasdaq Composite added 2.6% for the week, while overnight indexed swap rates implied a 35% chance of a September rate hike.

site_title: Virginia TV gunman plotted to hurt more people: Governor
summary: A gunman, Vester Lee Flanagan, who shot and killed two young journalists, Alison Parker and Adam Ward, on live TV in 2015, had planned to hurt more people, according to Virginia's governor. Flanagan, a former reporter, fatally shot himself after police caught up with his car. Authorities found additional ammunition and a to-do list with 17 stamped letters, but the contents of the list remain undisclosed. The incident reignited debate about gun control in the US, with Governor Terry McAuliffe calling for extending background checks for firearms purchases.

site_title: Year-long Mars isolation experiment starting in Hawaii
summary: Six people, including a French astrobiologist, a German physicist, and four Americans, are about to embark on a year-long isolation experiment in Hawaii's HI-SEAS habitat, simulating conditions for a potential Mars mission. The crew will live in a dome with limited access to the Internet and fresh food, with only powdered cheese and canned tuna available. The experiment aims to study how long-duration missions affect team dynamics and conflict resolution, with NASA hoping to apply the findings to future Mars missions.

site_title: Man jailed for filming women in fitting rooms
summary: A 22-year-old student, Loh Wei Quan, was jailed for 32 weeks for filming women changing in fitting rooms at Cotton On outlets across Singapore over nine months. He admitted to 16 of 50 charges, including 49 for insulting modesty and one for possession of obscene films. Loh, who has been diagnosed with voyeurism, had used a mobile phone to record women in the fitting rooms, often deleting the footage if the person caught on video was a male. The court described the videos as "extremely intrusive" and lasting one to five minutes.

summary: President Barack Obama will name James O'Brien as special presidential envoy for hostage affairs, a response to complaints about the government's handling of hostage situations. This appointment comes after a six-month review of the government's policy on hostage situations, which was spurred by concerns from families whose initiatives to free relatives were discouraged or blocked by officials. The envoy will work closely with families and foreign leaders to develop strategies for addressing hostage situations.

The incident occurred at the home on Dec 27, 2014, when Hoe was restrained by officers and placed in a segregation dormitory. His actions were described as premeditated and violent.

site_title: Rise in air pollutants during Hungry Ghost period: Study
summary: During the annual Hungry Ghost Festival in Singapore, air quality worsens due to increased concentrations of pollutants, with PM2.5 particles rising by 18-60% during festival months. Nine hazardous metals, including lead and tin, show average increases of 18-50% in concentrations. While still lower than high haze periods, these elevated levels can pose health risks. To mitigate pollution, local authorities and town councils advise responsible burning practices, such as using containers and burning pits, and testing smoke-reducing burners. Researchers call for further studies on organic compounds released during burning, which could be more toxic.

site_title: Rain helps lessen impact of haze from Sumatra fires
summary: Rain in Singapore over the past few days has helped ease hazy conditions, with the air quality in the moderate range as of 7pm yesterday. Despite haze in South Sumatra, the rain has maintained air quality, with the National Environment Agency reporting a 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) between 64 and 70. Two hot spots were detected in Sumatra, with occasional slight haze possible today if winds shift. Rain is expected to continue, potentially attenuating the smoke-haze impact in the region.

site_title: Election battle lines begin to emerge
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its final candidates for the 89 seats in Singapore's General Election 2015, including a team tasked with retaking the Aljunied GRC from the Workers' Party (WP). The PAP's team, led by veteran MP Yeo Guat Kwang, will face off against the WP's "A" team led by Low Thia Khiang. PAP second assistant secretary-general Tharman Shanmugaratnam believes his team has a "fighting chance" and is committed to pressing home the issue of the WP-led town council's troubled finances.

site_title: Long-time friends may contest a GRC
summary: A group of five long-time friends, including architect Fatimah Akhtar and businessman Eric Seow, plan to contest a group representation constituency as independents in the upcoming election if they find existing party candidates are unqualified. The group collected nomination forms for Tanjong Pagar, Jurong, and Ang Mo Kio GRCs. If successful, they would be the first team of independents to contest a GRC since the scheme began in 1988.

Currently, town councils lack a standardized governance framework, making it difficult for Singaporeans to understand their finances. Desai hopes to bring his finance background to the team and advocate for policies that promote a fair society, strong families, and esteemed people, ultimately making Singapore a better place for all residents.

site_title: Vertical farming invention wins global award
summary: A Singapore-based company, Sky Urban Solutions, has won the prestigious INDEX: Award with its 9m-tall vertical farming system, which can grow 10 times more vegetables than traditional methods over the same area. The system, which uses rainwater and a water-pulley system, has been recognized for its innovative design and potential to increase food production in Singapore, a country with limited land resources. The $158,000 prize money will be used for research and development and farm expansion, with plans to increase daily production to five tonnes in two years.

site_title: The changing face of PAP's new candidates
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its 2015 slate for the General Election, featuring 24 new candidates, the oldest group of newbies in over 30 years, with a median age of 42.3 years. The slate is more heavily weighted towards private-sector backgrounds, with 15 candidates from the private sector, compared to 8 in 2011. The PAP has also maintained a lower number of women and Indian candidates, with only five new women candidates and one new Indian candidate. The party is emphasizing leadership renewal, with only two high-profile candidates of ministerial calibre, former top civil servant Chee Hong Tat and former defence chief Ng Chee Meng.

site_title: Lawyer's late father was a political detainee
summary: Lawyer K. Muralidharan Pillai, a candidate for the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), has a left-leaning father who was a former political detainee. His late father, P.K. Pillai, was a unionist who opposed the merger with Malaya and was detained during the Coldstore operation in 1963. Despite this, Pillai's father credited the PAP government with Singapore's prosperity and encouraged his son to join the party. Pillai, who has a 34-year-old son, was introduced as a PAP candidate for Aljunied GRC, citing his commitment to serving the community and not being swayed by odds.

site_title: Jailed for beating up football referee
summary: Muhammad Maziz Abdul Rahman, 29, was jailed for 10 months for causing grievous hurt to referee Mr Mohd Asadullah, 35, during a PSA inter-departmental football match in December last year. Maziz attacked the referee after being sent off, landing several blows and kicking him in the head. He also suffered a broken nose and was ordered to pay $2,000 in compensation. Maziz's lawyer cited his emotional state, but the judge deemed his response disproportionate and showed a "hooligan tendency".

summary: The Workers' Party (WP) will maintain its existing Aljunied GRC team for the Sept 11 polls, despite the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) unveiling its own team led by four-term MP Yeo Guat Kwang. WP chairman Sylvia Lim stated that her team "owes a debt" to the Aljunied residents who have supported them and will work hard to defend their turf. She acknowledged that the PAP is a formidable opponent, but the WP is committed to seeking the mandate of the residents for the next term.

site_title: Home briefs: Brothers fined over kickbacks scam
summary: Two brothers, Lim Boon Hwa and Lim Boon Hong, were fined $180,000 each for collecting kickbacks from foreign construction workers. The scam involved Kathamuthu Chelladurai, a construction firm supervisor, and collected nearly $418,000 from 13 workers to renew their work permits. The brothers' company, Lexley Management Services, was found guilty of the offense.

site_title: Suspense retained till the last minute
summary: The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) in Singapore announced its slate for the Aljunied GRC, a constituency it lost to the Workers' Party in the 2015 general election, just hours before the Nomination Day deadline. The new lineup includes four-term MP Yeo Guat Kwang and four new faces: Victor Lye, K. Muralidharan Pillai, Chua Eng Leong, and Shamsul Kamar. Former party chairman Lim Boon Heng stated that the selection process was thorough, with a 360-degree assessment of candidates to ensure they fit the constituency. The lineup replaces two previously announced candidates, Ms Chan Hui Yuh and Mr Kahar Hassan, who were deemed not suitable due to family commitments and lack of experience, respectively.

site_title: Global engineering firm to conduct check of rail network
summary: International engineering firm Parsons Brinckerhoff has been awarded a $14 million contract to conduct a comprehensive health check on Singapore's rail network, the most detailed assessment since the first MRT line opened in 1987. The deal follows a string of major rail breakdowns, with an average of 2.5 disruptions per month in the first half of this year. The assessment will examine the condition of the operating system and infrastructure, and is expected to take six to 12 months to complete.

site_title: Singapore police warn against illegal assembly supporting Bersih-led rally in Malaysia
summary: The Singapore Police Force has issued a warning against participating in or supporting the Bersih-led rallies in Malaysia this weekend. The police stated that unauthorized public assemblies are illegal under the Public Order Act and can lead to termination of visas or work passes for foreigners. The warning aims to prevent potential disruptions to public order and urged foreigners to respect Singapore's laws. The Bersih-led rallies in Malaysia are calling for the resignation of Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Food poisoning victim's feet amputated
summary: A 51-year-old Singaporean man, Tan Whee Boon, underwent amputation of his feet after developing gangrenous hands due to food poisoning. He had his hands removed last Friday, and his feet were amputated on Thursday, a week earlier than expected. The cause of the infection is linked to raw fish consumption, and Tan is recovering well, with his wife planning to focus on her future, including finding a job to care for him. Public donations have exceeded $100,000.

site_title: New system helps library users find popular books
summary: Sembawang Public Library has introduced a new system using data analytics to help users find popular books. The AutoSorter, a conveyor belt that scans RFID tags, sorts 3,000 items daily into seven categories, making it easier for patrons to find popular titles. Other high-tech features include e-book scanning and lockers for reserved items. The library aims to increase productivity and efficiency, allowing patrons to get books faster. The AutoSorter will be introduced in libraries slated for upgrading, with the National Library Board planning to roll it out nationwide.

site_title: P1 registration: 4 reports lodged over lying about address last year
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has lodged four police reports against parents suspected of lying about their addresses in last year's Primary 1 registration exercise. A 35-year-old man was fined $5,000 after pleading guilty to faking his address to get his daughter into a top primary school. The man had claimed to live within 1km to 2km of the school, but actually lived in a different area. The MOE's policy requires those who gain admission through the home-school distance priority scheme to live at the address for at least 30 months.

site_title: Old Singapore Poly home may be conserved
summary: A 1958 modernist building in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar district, once housing the country's first architecture school, may be conserved after the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Singapore Land Authority (SLA) announced plans to study its preservation. The Bestway Building, designed by colonial architecture firm Swan and Maclaren, is set to be returned to the State after its lease expires in November. Architects and heritage experts have called for its conservation, citing its historical significance and architectural value.

site_title: 'Legwork crucial' for active ageing scheme to succeed
summary: Singapore's $3 billion Action Plan for Successful Ageing aims to engage seniors through active ageing hubs and eldercare centres, but social service professionals emphasize the need for legwork to involve those who are socially isolated, have little education, or lack Internet access. They suggest offering incentives, such as membership fee rebates, and providing personalized services to motivate seniors to participate in activities. Efforts must also be made to reach out to seniors who may not be aware of available programs, with volunteers playing a crucial role in befriending and engaging them.

site_title: Up close with Ela Gandhi
summary: Ela Gandhi, the 75-year-old granddaughter of Indian independence leader Mahatma Gandhi, spoke at the Global Indian International School about her experience fighting apartheid alongside Nelson Mandela in South Africa. Gandhi endured nine years of house arrest and lost a son during the struggle. She served as an MP in South Africa from 1994 to 2004 and received awards, including the Pravasi Bharatiya Samman. Gandhi's talk was broadcast live to 20 other schools in Singapore, Malaysia, Japan, and India, highlighting her grandfather's principles and her own contributions to the fight against apartheid.

site_title: Hoping to meet the needs of residents
summary: Jesse Loo, a 52-year-old former bank manager, has announced his candidacy for the Ang Mo Kio GRC (constituency) seat in Singapore. Loo, who holds a Bachelor of Business degree from Swinburne University of Technology, aims to address issues such as minimum wage, inflation, and overcrowding. He is a self-proclaimed advocate for the working class and plans to use his skills as a PMET (professionals, managers, executives, and technicians) to represent residents' needs.

site_title: Smoother drive home on TPE soon
summary: Singapore residents heading home via the Tampines Expressway (TPE) will experience a smoother drive starting next month. The Land Transport Authority has made changes to the existing lanes at the TPE exit towards Seletar Expressway, allowing motorists to use the outer of two bus lanes while giving way to public buses. The lane will be painted yellow and have road markings to remind users to yield to buses. The changes aim to improve traffic flow into Punggol and Sengkang towns and reduce congestion.

site_title: Handcycling 50 hours non-stop for charity
summary: Dr. William Tan, a 58-year-old Paralympics athlete, embarked on a 50-hour handcycling feat for charity, aiming to raise $50,000 for needy children. Diagnosed with end-stage leukemia in 2009, Tan has since become a cancer survivor. The event began on August 29, 2015, at the Temasek Junior College track, with Tan surviving solely on electrolyte drinks and taking short toilet breaks. The funds will be donated to The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, Rotary Club of Bugis Junction, and Care Corner Orphanage Foundation.

summary: Workers' Party (WP) candidate Dr Daniel Goh issued a public statement denying allegations of an extra-marital affair after Chinese daily Lianhe Zaobao published an anonymous poison pen letter. The letter, sent by "Max Chan", claimed Dr Goh had an affair with an NUS postgraduate student in 2008. Dr Goh stated he was given a deadline to refute the allegations by Lianhe Zaobao and issued his statement before the story was published. The WP has welcomed scrutiny of its candidates, but emphasized the need for evidence and responsible media reporting.

site_title: SingFirst to fight for 'social justice'
summary: Singaporeans First (SingFirst) party chief Tan Jee Say announced his party will campaign for "social justice" in the upcoming general election, criticizing the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) government's liberal immigration policies. The party introduced its first batch of candidates, including market risk manager Chirag Desai and IT consultant Wong Chee Wai, who will contest in either Tanjong Pagar GRC or Jurong GRC. If elected, SingFirst will push for monthly cash allowances for children and the elderly, subsidizing healthcare, transport, and childcare fees, and rooting for a minimum wage and abolishing certificates of entitlement for vehicle ownership.

Abas also raised concerns about the SAF's cautious approach to placing Malays in certain vocations and the issue of Muslim women wearing the headscarf in the workplace. The SDP has introduced eight of its 11 candidates, including Abas and manager Bryan Lim Boon Heng, who plans to campaign on issues like population, housing, and education.

site_title: Satellite images confirm Palmyra temple destruction: UN
summary: Satellite images confirm the destruction of the Baal Shamin temple in Syria's Palmyra, a UNESCO World Heritage site, according to the UN. The temple, considered the second-most significant in ancient Palmyra, was reportedly blown up last Sunday by ISIS fighters, sparking widespread outrage and condemnation. The UN has labeled the destruction a "war crime." The images show the temple's main building destroyed, with surrounding columns less affected, and a large explosion apparently causing the damage. The destruction raises concerns for the rest of the Unesco World Heritage site.

The photo was shared on social media by a Norwegian campaigner, Gissur Simonarson, who founded Conflict News, and an online fund-raiser was launched to help Abdul, a single father of two, who fled Syria four years ago and now struggles to provide for his children. The funds will be used to support Abdul's education and a better life for his family.

This killing is the second major strike against a senior ISIS leader in the past 10 days. The strike demonstrates the US's focus on targeting ISIS's cyber and social media operations.

site_title: Steve Jobs seen as brilliant and brutal in Gibney documentary
summary: A new documentary, Steve Jobs: The Man In The Machine, examines the life and career of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, four years after his death. Director Alex Gibney portrays Jobs as a brilliant and brutal individual who revolutionized communication but also had a troubled personal life and a questionable business ethic. The documentary contrasts Jobs' aspirations as a Buddhist monk with his treatment of friends and family, and critiques the company's philanthropic programs and labor practices. The film, released on September 4, features archival footage and interviews with journalists and former employees.

The discovery has sparked a gold rush, with two anonymous individuals claiming a 10% finder's fee for their role in finding the train, which could potentially contain valuable objects such as artwork, documents, or treasures.

site_title: Syria refugee numbers approach 20 per cent of pre-war population
summary: Syria's four-and-a-half-year conflict has driven half of the country's population to flee, with 7.6 million displaced within the country and over 4 million becoming refugees. The number of refugees approaches 20% of the pre-war population, with Turkey, Lebanon, and Jordan taking in the largest numbers. Refugees face dire conditions, poverty, and health problems, with the UN appealing for funding to provide aid. The conflict has resulted in over 240,000 deaths, making it the largest refugee population from a single conflict in a generation.

site_title: Hungary razor wire no hurdle for hardened migrants
summary: Hungary's razor-wire fence along its border with Serbia has failed to deter tens of thousands of migrants, who are continuing to cross into the country. Despite the fence, many migrants, including Syrian and Afghan families, are using it as a means to get closer to western Europe, with the majority aiming to reach Germany. The migrants, who have faced extreme hardships in their home countries, are unfazed by the fence and instead prioritize avoiding police and deportation. Over 140,000 migrants have crossed into Hungary this year, with a record 3,000 registered on one day alone.

The Fed is still expected to increase interest rates for the first time in nine years, with a focus on labor market strengthening and the August jobs report.

site_title: Italy arrests 10 traffickers over migrant boat deaths
summary: Italian authorities arrested 10 suspected traffickers in connection with the deaths of 52 migrants who suffocated in the hold of an overcrowded boat in the Mediterranean. The victims, who were among nearly 500 on board, were forced to stay below deck in "awful conditions." Survivors described the horrific scene, and a Canadian doctor who participated in the rescue said he found 24 people without signs of life. The arrests follow statements from survivors taken to Palermo, Sicily, and are part of an ongoing investigation.

site_title: Athletics: Schippers scorches Beijing, Merritt misses golden send-off
summary: Dutch sprinter Dafne Schippers won the women's 200m final at the Beijing track and field championships, clocking a world-leading 21.63 seconds. This achievement eclipsed the European record and matched the fifth-fastest time in history. Schippers also won the 100m silver medal earlier in the competition. In contrast, American Aries Merritt finished third in the men's 110m hurdles before undergoing a kidney transplant next week. Schippers was quick to distance herself from doping allegations, stating she is clean and works hard for her results.

site_title: US teen jailed more than 11 years for ISIS conviction
summary: A US teenager, Ali Shukri Amin, 17, from Virginia, was sentenced to 11 years and four months in prison for conspiring to provide material support to the Islamic State (ISIS) extremist group. Amin, a prolific Twitter user, pleaded guilty in June for sending over 7,000 messages supporting ISIS and providing instructions on using Bitcoin to conceal donations. He also advised sympathizers on traveling to Syria to fight with ISIS, including another Virginia teen. The sentence marks the first conviction of a minor in the US for providing material aid to the group.

site_title: Austria truck death suspects to appear in court
summary: Austria arrested four suspects after discovering 71 decomposing migrant bodies in a truck, highlighting the dangers faced by refugees fleeing conflict and hardship in the Middle East and Africa. The victims, believed to be fleeing Syria, included a toddler and three young boys, and were likely victims of human trafficking. The suspects, three Bulgarians and an Afghan, will appear in court in Hungary to determine if they can be detained beyond the initial 72-hour period. The discovery sparked outrage across Europe, with the United Nations estimating 2,500 migrants have died in attempts to reach Europe this year.

Candidates must obtain the certificate to contest the election, and groups must also obtain a Certificate of the Malay Community Committee or the Indian and Other Minority Communities Committee. site_title: Indonesia central bank tightens rules for domestic dollar purchase
summary: Indonesia's central bank has tightened its rules for domestic dollar purchases, requiring a document for transactions above $25,000. The move aims to bolster the fragile rupiah, which has lost nearly 12% this year and hit a 17-year low. The currency strengthened slightly after the central bank's direct intervention, closing at 13,980 per dollar on Friday. The new regulation aims to make the domestic foreign exchange market more stable and reflect real demand for foreign exchange.

site_title: Send me your songs, says Celine Dion eyeing new albums
summary: Celine Dion is seeking submissions for her next two albums, inviting artists and composers to send her their songs. The 47-year-old singer, who took a hiatus to care for her husband's throat cancer, aims to release the first album in French next year and the second in English in 2017. Dion stated that the songs can be for personal or professional growth, and she plans to collaborate with new artists, but has not revealed any specific details.

site_title: Fed officials pushing for rate hike unfazed by market turmoil
summary: US Federal Reserve officials, including St. Louis Fed President James Bullard, are pushing for a rate hike in mid-September despite market turmoil, citing a solid US economy that can handle modest rate increases. Bullard stated that recent market volatility, including concerns over China's economic slowdown, has not altered the US outlook, and he prefers to hike rates sooner but gradually. Other Fed policymakers, including Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester and Minneapolis Fed President Narayana Kocherlakota, have also expressed support for rate hikes, with varying degrees of caution, amid ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: GE2015: A look back at the last 5 general elections from 1991 to 2011
summary: Singapore's 12th general election, set for September 11, is likely to see the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) challenged in all 89 seats. In the last five general elections, opposition parties have made significant gains, with the Workers' Party (WP) winning Aljunied GRC in 2011, and the Singapore Democratic Alliance (SDA) winning three seats in 1991. Key issues have included the cost of living, housing prices, and the impact of foreign workers on the economy. The opposition has also focused on increasing representation in Parliament and addressing concerns over safety and security.

site_title: Top 5 things about PAP's Aljunied GRC team
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) unveiled its Aljunied GRC team ahead of the general election. Key facts include: the team's unveiling took place at a press conference on a Friday morning. The unveiling marks an early move by the PAP in the general election campaign.

site_title: Malaysia bans yellow Bersih 4 t-shirts, materials on rally
summary: The Malaysian Home Ministry has issued a ban order, effective August 27, 2015, prohibiting the sale, distribution, and possession of publications related to the Bersih 4 rally, including yellow t-shirts and materials with the words "Bersih 4". The order, signed by Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, aims to prevent publications deemed prejudicial to public order and security. The ban applies to any printed materials leading to the rally, and is enforced under the Printing Presses and Publications (Control of Undesirable Publications) (No 22) Order 2015.

site_title: Protester's death fuels fresh tension in India state
summary: A court in Gujarat, India ordered an inquiry into the death of 28-year-old protester Shwetang Patel, who died in police custody after a violent rally. Patel's family claims he suffered a brain hemorrhage due to head injuries, contradicting police's account. The court demanded an investigation and action against officers who harmed innocent people and damaged property. The protest, led by the Patidar caste, demanded equal treatment on government jobs and university places, sparking tensions between police and the community. At least 10 people died in clashes, and authorities have deployed troops to maintain order.

The first 50 customers will receive the device at 50% off the retail price of $1,088, while 10 customers who own all four previous devices will also receive a free Montblanc screenwriter case.

site_title: Police issue advisory against carrying out Bersih-related protests in Singapore
summary: The Singapore Police Force has issued an advisory warning against carrying out Bersih-related protests in Singapore, citing the risk of disturbing public order. The police stated that public assemblies without a permit are illegal and can result in visa termination for foreigners. The advisory urges foreigners to abide by Singapore's laws and not bring external issues into the country.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Unseen security footage underscores patchy probe

Despite reviewing the footage, police have yet to identify the suspect, raising questions about the effectiveness of their investigation.

site_title: Japan protests China news agency's call for emperor apology
summary: Japan has formally protested China's official state news agency Xinhua for calling on Emperor Akihito to apologize for Japan's past military aggression. The Xinhua commentary, published on Tuesday, criticized Hirohito, Akihito's father, for his role in World War II and urged his son to apologize and seek forgiveness. Japan's government has lodged a formal protest, citing that the commentary was "seriously discourteous" and could harm Japan-China relations, which have been improving. The protests come amid strained relations due to territorial disputes and Japan's occupation of parts of China from the 1930s.

site_title: Three Islamic militants killed in Philippine military clash
summary: Three Islamic militants were killed in a Philippine military clash with Abu Sayyaf rebels on the island of Jolo. The operation, launched to rescue hostages, resulted in 300 Abu Sayyaf fighters retreating and 10 Philippine soldiers being wounded. The military did not confirm if any hostages were freed or injured. The Abu Sayyaf group, linked to Al-Qaeda, has been involved in kidnappings, beheadings, and bombings, including the 2004 ferry attack that killed over 100 people. The group has since split into smaller factions, each holding hostages.

summary: A rare grey pearl necklace once owned by British aristocrat Viscountess Cowdray is expected to fetch up to $7 million at an auction in Hong Kong in October. The necklace, featuring 42 natural grey saltwater pearls, holds the world record for a natural grey pearl necklace sold at auction after previously selling for $3.35 million in 2012. It will be exhibited in several cities before the sale, including New York, London, and Singapore, and is described as "one of the finest and rarest grey pearl necklaces known".

summary: A 22-year-old student, Loh Wei Quan, was jailed for 32 weeks for secretly filming women changing in Cotton On shops across Singapore since February last year. He was caught at Bedok Mall in November and admitted to 16 of 50 charges, including insulting modesty. Loh used his iPhone to film women in fitting rooms, deleting clips if they were male, and felt a sense of accomplishment after recording each video. The court's decision reflects the severity of the offense, with Loh facing up to one year in prison and/or fines for his actions.

summary: Euro zone sentiment reached a four-year high in August, increasing to 104.2, as domestic demand outpaced a decline in export prospects. The European Commission's economic sentiment indicator suggests the euro zone economy remains resilient, but uncertainty remains for industry due to the euro's appreciation and concerns about China's slowdown. Consumer inflation expectations and industry selling price expectations also declined to four-month lows.

summary: A Singaporean encountered difficulties using Brunei currency at hawker centres and noodle stalls, with some vendors rejecting the notes despite them having the same value as Singapore dollars. Authorities are urged to educate stall operators and businesses on the use of Brunei currency to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Sugar Daddy sites a step backwards for our society
summary: Dating websites pairing young women with rich older men for companionship are plagued by problems and promote disparate agendas. These relationships can perpetuate negative stereotypes of women, damaging self-image and capacity for love. For men, such arrangements often involve infidelity and a lack of deep connections, with money being the only currency they can offer. This can lead to a slippery slope of affairs and divorce, negatively affecting society. Experts warn of a step backwards for society, highlighting the importance of considering the impact of these relationships on individuals and the community.

site_title: Ringgit's down but why aren't Malaysian goods cheaper?
summary: Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, has fallen significantly over the past six months, reaching new lows. Despite this, prices of imported goods, such as vegetables, from Malaysia remain unchanged in local supermarkets. This has raised concerns among consumers, who expect cheaper prices due to the weakened currency. The lack of price reduction may be attributed to various factors, including import tariffs, taxes, and logistical costs that are not directly affected by the currency's value.

site_title: Time to raise awareness of sexual crimes
summary: A recent article by The Straits Times highlights the rising trend of sexual crimes over the last four years, prompting a call for increased awareness and action. Experts and concerned citizens, such as a Straits Times reader, emphasize the need for parents, schools, and communities to educate themselves and others about sexual abuse. Organized programs and initiatives are suggested to spread awareness and prevent such crimes, particularly in households. The issue demands attention and collective effort to protect vulnerable individuals, especially children.

site_title: Kyrgyzstan hails 'historic' China-financed power line
summary: Kyrgyzstan has inaugurated a Chinese-financed 450km power line, dubbed "historic" by President Almazbek Atambayev, which aims to bring energy independence to the country. The US$390 million project, built by China's Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Company, will save Kyrgyzstan millions in transit fees and eliminate reliance on neighboring countries. The deal marks China's growing economic influence in Central Asia, with the country financing multiple projects in Kyrgyzstan, including a North-South road and a proposed railway linking Xinjiang to Uzbekistan.

Hougang MP Png Eng Huat said the party will not take action on the accusation against sociologist Daniel Goh due to a lack of evidence, as he has lodged a police report. The media is urged to abide by deadlines for interviewee responses and avoid publishing unsubstantiated claims. Four WP candidates, including Dr Goh, have been introduced ahead of the upcoming election.

site_title: Greek economy grew by 0.9% in Q2: official data
summary: Greece's economy grew by 0.9% in Q2, according to official data, surpassing the initial 0.8% figure reported in August. This improvement is seen as a positive sign ahead of early elections next month. The state statistics agency attributed the growth to increased output, which increased by 0.9% compared to the first quarter. The 0.9% growth rate is a slight improvement over the previous quarter's 0.8% growth.

site_title: Football: Sturridge back in training with first team, Markovic may join Fenerbahce on loan
summary: Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge has started training with the first team after hip surgery, marking a step towards his return to action. Meanwhile, midfielder Lazar Markovic is set to join Turkish side Fenerbahce on a season-long loan, with the clubs agreeing terms for the 21-year-old. Markovic's departure would be the fourth player to leave Anfield this summer, following Rickie Lambert, Javier Manquillo, and Mario Balotelli. Sturridge's return and Markovic's loan move could still fit into manager Brendan Rodgers' long-term plans.

site_title: Father who lied about address during Pri 1 registration gets fine instead of jail
summary: A 35-year-old father in Singapore initially sentenced to two weeks' jail for lying about his address to get his daughter into a prestigious primary school was fined $5,000 instead after appealing to the High Court. He had registered his daughter under Phase 2C of the Primary 1 registration exercise in 2013, claiming his address was within 1km to 2km of the school, when in fact it was 2km away. This was a similar case to four others between 1995 and 2004, where lying parents were given the maximum fine of $5,000.

summary: Former Polish Archbishop Jozef Wesolowski, 67, died overnight ahead of his trial on paedophile charges. He was set to be the first high-ranking church official to face trial under a Vatican justice system revamped by Pope Francis. Wesolowski's trial, which was postponed due to health issues, was expected to be a significant milestone in addressing widespread accusations of child abuse by priests.

summary: The Reform Party (RP) has unveiled its final slate of candidates for the 2015 general election, including blogger Roy Ngerng and his lawyer M. Ravi, who will lead the Ang Mo Kio GRC team. The six-man group also includes Osman Sulaiman, Gilbert Goh, Siva Chandran, and Jesse Loo. The RP is campaigning on issues such as financial transparency, a cap on foreign workers, and a minimum wage, with its candidates set to contest 11 seats nationwide.

site_title: China's stock rout to resume as intervention ends, says BofA
summary: China's stock market is expected to resume its decline after a brief rebound, as the government's intervention is set to end. Bank of America's China equity strategist, David Cui, predicts the Shanghai Composite Index will need to fall another 35% for shares to become attractive. The index has rallied in recent days amid speculation of government support, but valuations are not justified given China's slowing economy. China's state agency, China Securities Finance Corp., is likely to end direct market purchases within the next month or two, exacerbating the decline.

summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' leftist Syriza party leads in a major opinion poll with 23% support, ahead of the conservative New Democracy party on 19.5%. However, most voters (64%) believe Tsipras' decision to seek a fresh mandate through snap polls was wrong. The poll also shows that 68% of Greeks agree Greece must stay in the euro zone at any cost, despite further austerity. Syriza's popularity has declined since the previous poll in July, and the party's disaffected members have formed a new party, Popular Unity, which has gained 3.5% support.

site_title: Two brothers fined $180k each for collecting $418k in kickbacks from construction workers
summary: Two Singaporean brothers, Lim Boon Hwa and Lim Boon Hong, have been fined $180,000 each for collecting $418,000 in kickbacks from foreign construction workers. The scam, which involved collecting money to renew work permits, was uncovered by the Ministry of Manpower after a tip-off. The brothers, who worked for a management services company, split the money with Kathamuthu Chelladurai, a Straits Construction supervisor, without the company's knowledge. The older brother has returned the money to the affected workers, while Kathamuthu is wanted by authorities.

site_title: 71 migrants perish in Austria truck tragedy, 76 off Libya
summary: Austrian police have confirmed 71 migrant bodies found in a refrigerated truck on a motorway, with forensic experts suggesting the group likely consisted of Syrians. The victims, including a toddler and three young boys, were likely suffocated. Hungarian police have arrested three Bulgarians, including the vehicle's owner, in connection with the incident. Meanwhile, 76 bodies were recovered from a capsized boat off the coast of Libya, bringing the total number of migrant deaths in the Mediterranean to over 300,000 this year. European leaders are calling for a special summit to address the migrant crisis.

site_title: US and South Korea troops stage massive live fire drill
summary: South Korean and US troops staged their largest-ever joint live fire drill on August 28, 2015, near the DMZ, involving 3,000 soldiers, 100 tanks, and 120 heavy guns. The exercise simulated a North Korean provocation, followed by a clash and a counter-attack, after a recent surge in tensions was de-escalated. The drill was held days after a military standoff between the two Koreas ended, with President Park Geun-Hye and senior US and South Korean military officials in attendance. It marked the largest live-fire exercise South Korean troops have ever staged.

site_title: Thailand's opposition slams draft constitution week before vote
summary: Thailand's main opposition party strongly denounces a military-backed draft constitution, calling it "totally disregarding the sovereignty of the Thai people." The Puea Thai Party claims the charter disregards checks and balances, favoring the junta's power. The National Reform Council is set to vote on the draft on September 6, with a referendum planned for January. Many politicians expect the charter to pass but be rejected, delaying a promised election. Critics have also raised concerns over the handling of Thailand's economy and a recent bomb attack investigation.

site_title: Recreational football player jailed for attacking referee during match
summary: A Singapore court sentenced 29-year-old Muhammad Maziz Abdul Rahman, a former container handling specialist, to 10 months in jail for attacking a referee during a football match in December 2014. Maziz lunged at the referee with his boot, punched his face twice, and kicked his head, causing serious injuries. He was also ordered to pay $2,000 compensation to the victim. The court found Maziz's response to the referee's yellow and red cards to be disproportionate and excessive.

Somasundaram, 52. site_title: Bangkok blast: Police obtain DNA test results from suspect's banknotes and taxi
summary: Thai police have obtained DNA test results from banknotes and a taxi used by the Erawan Shrine bomb suspect, who is believed to have been responsible for the August 17 bombing that killed 20 people. The suspect, who remains at large, allegedly gave the banknotes to a tuk-tuk driver and travelled in the taxi before the attack. Police are still investigating and have not disclosed details of the DNA test results, but are working to identify potential suspects and have received reports linking the attack to the Grey Wolves, a right-wing Turkish organization.

site_title: Singapore IT professionals saw 10-15% rise in salaries, strong hiring this year
summary: Singapore IT professionals saw a 10-15% rise in salaries this year, driven by strong hiring in areas like cloud computing, mobile applications, business intelligence, data analytics, and cyber security. Recruitment firm ZW HR Consulting attributes this trend to the increasing demand for IT professionals in Singapore, fueled by the country's position as Southeast Asia's gateway to business and growing concerns over data protection and regulation. This has given experienced IT workers a significant advantage, with many expected to see salary hikes.

The cards were redesigned after input from various parties, and Hatano's image will be used in a charity series. The move has sparked controversy, with Taipei mayor Ko Wen-je expressing surprise at the decision, and concerns about the country's liberal attitudes towards pornography.

He and fellow protester Nathan Law were charged with obstructing police at a June protest against China's control over the semi-autonomous city. Wong faces further charges over a democracy rally in November and plans to announce a new strategy for his campaign group, Scholarism, in September.

site_title: Taiwan military tells veterans to avoid China's World War II parade
summary: Taiwan's military has urged war veterans to avoid attending a World War II victory parade in Beijing, China, due to the Nationalist government's wartime contribution being downplayed by China. Taiwan's defense ministry stated that Nationalist forces led the war, contradicting China's focus on Communist forces. This move has upset the Taiwanese government, where the same nationalist party now governs, and has sparked criticism from some in Taiwan who remain wary of China's claims to the island. Former Taiwan president Lee Teng-hui's comments on the topic have also been reported.

site_title: Olam deal at premium sends Noble Group shares toward first monthly rise since Nov
summary: Shares of Noble Group rose 5.8% to 54.5 cents on Friday after Mitsubishi Corp. agreed to pay a 44% premium to buy a 20% stake in Olam International for $1.53 billion. This deal has lifted Noble's shares 19% for the month, their first monthly gain since November. Analysts believe that the deal validates Noble's worth, as supply chain managers should be valued better, with Mitsubishi's willingness to pay a premium for Olam's stake.

site_title: The extraordinary Margaret Leng Tan unveils a cabinet of musical curiosities
summary: Margaret Leng Tan, a renowned Singaporean pianist, presented a unique musical performance at the Singapore International Festival of Arts, marking her 70th birthday. The "Cabinet of Curiosities" program featured Tan playing various toy pianos, percussion instruments, and even a clown's nose, while donning several masks. The performance combined music, theatre, and visual elements, showcasing Tan's versatility and talent. The show was well-received, with critics praising Tan's ability to coax beautiful music from unconventional instruments and maintain high artistic standards.

site_title: Savannah State University locked down for several hours after gunfire reports
summary: Reports of gunfire at Savannah State University in Georgia led to a campus lockdown on Thursday, lasting over two hours. One person was hospitalized after being shot near the student union. The lockdown was lifted at midnight, with police securing the area. There was no active shooter, and an investigation into the incident is ongoing. The university encouraged residential students to remain in their rooms until further notice. The incident occurred in the aftermath of recent high-profile shootings in Virginia and South Carolina.

site_title: Fuss-free access to Netflix, Hulu Plus extended to all broadband users in Singapore
summary: Broadband users in Singapore can now access overseas movie streaming services like Netflix and Hulu Plus without restrictions, thanks to a new set-top box developed by ViewQwest. The box, launched on Friday, allows users to stream content from various apps, including BBC iPlayer, without needing a VPN. The service costs $10.70 a month after the first year, and users must also subscribe to Netflix and Hulu Plus, with monthly fees starting at $8. This expansion makes fuss-free access to overseas content available to all broadband users, including those from Singtel, StarHub, and M1.

site_title: Manspreading, hangry, Grexit join Oxford online dictionary
summary: OxfordDictionaries.com has added 7 slang terms, including "Manspreading," "Hangry," and "Grexit," to its online dictionary. Manspreading refers to men taking up extra space on public transport, hangry describes a bad mood due to hunger, and Grexit refers to a potential Greek exit from the Eurozone. Other new terms include "awesomesauce," "manic pixie dream girl," "wine o'clock," and "Ragequit." These additions reflect popular phrases and expressions in modern language, offering a snapshot of contemporary culture and communication.

site_title: China eases foreign purchase rules for property after yuan depreciation
summary: China has relaxed rules for foreign property purchases, allowing overseas companies' Chinese units and foreign nationals to buy properties for personal use that meet "real needs." The move follows China's yuan depreciation, which reduced the appeal of Chinese property assets. The relaxation of restrictions aims to promote "stable and healthy" growth of the property market. The changes remove requirements for foreign investors to have paid their registered capital in full before borrowing local loans, and non-Chinese homebuyers accounted for only 0.5% of existing-home transactions in Shanghai last year.

summary: Resale prices of private homes in Singapore remained flat in July, according to the Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI).
