site_title: Japanese toilet giant flips open lid on new museum
summary: Japan's toilet giant Toto has opened a new museum in Kitakyushu, showcasing its century-long history of innovative toilets, from the first water flushing model in 1914 to its cutting-edge designs featuring odour-neutralisers and variable water jets. The museum, operated by Toto, offers free admission and features replicas of its historic toilets, including those supplied to major buildings like the State Guest House in Tokyo. The museum highlights Japan's reputation for advanced toilet technology, which has gained international praise from celebrities like Madonna and Will Smith.

site_title: Malaysia braces for anti-Najib Bersih rally in latest test for premier
summary: Malaysia is bracing for a massive anti-Najib Bersih rally in Kuala Lumpur, with an estimated 200,000 protesters demanding Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation. The rally, which has been deemed illegal by the police, aims to pressure Najib to reform institutions and call an election. The protests, which are part of a global movement, are expected to escalate public dissatisfaction with Najib's leadership, which has been marred by corruption allegations and a slowing economy. The rally marks a significant challenge to Najib's grip on power, with analysts predicting a large turnout of ethnic Malays, who are the backbone of support for his ruling party.

site_title: Bus services to be diverted from Orchard Road during Pedestrian Night
summary: Several bus services along Orchard Road will be diverted on the first Saturday of each month for four months due to Pedestrian Night. From 6pm to 11pm, SMRT bus services 77, 106, 167, 171, 190, 700A, and 972 will be temporarily rerouted. The closure, which runs from October to December, allows pedestrians to walk on the 660m stretch of road and participate in activities. Passengers can find alternative routes and more information on the SMRT website or hotline.

site_title: 1MDB mess gives Abu Dhabi state investor IPIC no good options
summary: Abu Dhabi's state investor IPIC is stuck with 1MDB's debt of almost US$5 billion, as the Malaysian fund denies allegations of mismanagement and graft involving Prime Minister Najib Razak. IPIC had provided crucial funding to 1MDB, but its involvement has become an embarrassment due to Najib's alleged corruption. Despite efforts to draw a line under their relationship, IPIC may be forced to share 1MDB's financial pain if Najib is forced out of power.

site_title: China markets rally on speculated govt suppport as Beijing prepares for WWII parade
summary: Chinese stocks rallied for a second day, with the Shanghai Composite Index climbing 2.5% to 3,160.31, amid speculation that the government is propping up markets before President Xi Jinping's World War II victory parade on September 3. The yuan gained 0.23% to its strongest level since April 28, as the People's Bank of China strengthened the reference rate by 0.15%. Authorities are trying to "save face" before the parade, which will showcase China's rising military and political might.

site_title: Myanmar democracy on hold as parties scramble for power: The Nation
summary: Myanmar's main opposition party, the National League for Democracy, is facing internal revolt after sidelining democratic allies ahead of November's general election. The ruling Union Solidarity and Development Party's candidate for president has been nominated by the military, sparking concern over the country's democratic future. The opposition's decision to choose unendorsed candidates has led to protests and resignations, and a third party is planning to form in response. The election, seen as a milestone for democracy, may instead lead to a compromise with the military, undermining democratic principles.

site_title: China's banking giants: Zero profit growth, more bad loans
summary: China's two largest banking giants, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Agricultural Bank of China (ABC), reported zero profit growth in the first half of the year due to rising bad loans. ICBC's nonperforming loans increased 31% to 163.5 billion yuan, while ABC's bad loans jumped 28% to 159.5 billion yuan. The banks' earnings growth may be hindered by the economic slowdown and US$5 trillion stock-market slump, with ICBC's president indicating the lender may abandon its nonperforming loan ratio target.

site_title: Make the Japanese take on an American favourite: hamburger steak
summary: In Japan, hamburger steak is a popular dish among children, often served as part of the "okosama lunch" meal at department stores and eateries. The dish typically features a ground beef and pork patty, onions, bread crumbs, eggs, and vegetables, served with rice and ketchup. To entice children to eat vegetables, parents sometimes hide them in the patties. The recipe, which serves four, involves mixing ground meat with various ingredients and forming patties, which are then cooked and served with a sauce made from red wine, tomato ketchup, and Worcestershire sauce.

Additionally, the magazine showcases the collections of three art collectors and reviews a new restaurant, Beni, at Mandarin Gallery.

site_title: China July industrial profits slip 2.9%, underlining economy's weakness
summary: China's industrial profits declined 2.9% in July from a year ago, marking the second-largest drop since a 4.2% decrease in January-February. This underlines the weakness in the country's economy, which has seen profits decline 1% in the first seven months of the year compared to the same period last year. The decline in industrial profits is a concern for the country's economic growth.

site_title: South Korea Red Cross invites North for family reunion talks
summary: The South Korean Red Cross has proposed talks with its North Korean counterpart to arrange a family reunion for separated families, following an inter-Korean agreement reached earlier this week. The talks are set to begin on September 7 at Panmunjom, and the reunion is expected to take place around the Chuseok harvest festival holiday on September 27. This would be the first reunion since 2014, and is seen as a step towards reducing military tensions between the two countries. Approximately 66,000 South Koreans are currently wait-listed for the reunion.

site_title: GE2015: PAP unveils its Aljunied GRC team
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its team for the Aljunied Group Representation Constituency (GRC), facing off against the incumbent Workers' Party (WP). The five-member team includes veteran MP Yeo Guat Kwang and four new faces, including former Cabinet Minister Lim Boon Heng, who has been active on the ground since his retirement in 2011. The PAP team emphasizes their commitment to serving the residents of Aljunied, with Lim describing them as "men of courage" who are dedicated to proving their worth and serving the community better.

site_title: Stiffer US gun control? Not any time soon, say experts
summary: A mass shooting at a US television station has renewed calls for stricter gun control, but experts say such measures are unlikely to be implemented. The Supreme Court's 2008 ruling on gun ownership has led to a loosening of gun controls, despite increased calls for stricter laws following mass shootings. The Republican party's alignment with gun rights supporters and the gun lobby's effective lobbying efforts have hindered efforts to tighten gun laws. While many Americans support background checks and other measures, the "intensity gap" between gun rights advocates and those pushing for stricter laws remains significant.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.27% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 1.27% to 2,982.76 in early trade on Friday, driven by 37.33-point gains. Around 111.7 million shares were exchanged, with 168 gainers outnumbering 17 losers. The market opened higher, with the index initially at 2,982.76.

site_title: Oil extends gains, after soaring over 10% on Thursday in biggest one-day climb in 6 years
summary: Oil prices surged over 10% on Thursday, the largest one-day gain in six years, driven by recovering stock markets and diminished crude supplies. US crude futures are on track for their first weekly gains in 11 weeks, while Brent crude is poised for its first weekly gain in two weeks. The rally follows strong US economic data and a decline in China's auto sales, which has raised concerns about the global economy.

site_title: Olam's $915m Mitsubishi cash injection to help with acquisitions, CEO says
summary: Olam International Ltd. has secured a $915 million cash injection from Mitsubishi Corp. through a share purchase deal. The investment will aid the Singaporean commodity trader in funding acquisitions amid a decline in commodity prices. CEO Sunny Verghese stated that the funds will provide growth capital for Olam, enabling it to pursue strategic opportunities. The deal, part of a larger $1.53 billion agreement, sees Mitsubishi acquire a 20% stake in Olam, with the company expecting to use the funds to expand its operations.

site_title: Rigging the weather was the easy part for Communist Party: The China Post
summary: The Chinese Communist Party faces a political challenge rather than an economic one due to the recent stock market turbulence. The Shanghai Stock Exchange Composite Index plummeted over 30% in two months, following a dramatic surge in the past year. The government's encouragement of people to invest in the stock market has created unrealistic expectations, leading to a bursting of a bubble. With Chinese households invested less than 15% of their financial assets in the stock market, the real damage is limited. The CCP's inability to control the market highlights its limitations, posing a threat to its image of omnipotence and its authoritarian rule.

site_title: Queues in Britain as final Pratchett novel goes on sale
summary: Fans of British author Terry Pratchett, many in science-fantasy costumes, queued outside bookshops overnight in London as the final installment in the Discworld series, "The Shepherd's Crown," went on sale. The 41st book, completed last summer, received five-star reviews and is seen as a fitting end to Pratchett's series, which has sold over 85 million copies worldwide. Pratchett, who died in 2015 after a battle with Alzheimer's, wrote the first book in the series in the late 1960s, and the final book marks his move towards moral and social exploration in his writing.

site_title: Long-haul budget airline AirAsia X uncovers RM7m of fake payments
summary: Long-haul budget airline AirAsia X has discovered RM7 million (S$2.33 million) in fake payments made to a service provider between 2010 and 2014. The payments, authorized by a management position, were found to be fictitious during a forensics audit. The company has taken measures to safeguard its assets and interests, including seeking legal advice and lodging a police report. AirAsia X's second-quarter revenue was RM653.03 million, but it made a loss of RM132.94 million, with an unrealized foreign exchange loss on borrowings of RM30.9 million.

site_title: Two men in Malaysia charged over ISIS links
summary: Two Malaysian men, Mohamad Fauzi Misrak, a 35-year-old chef, and Rohaimi Abd Rahim, a 38-year-old financial consultant, have been jointly charged with arranging to facilitate the acquisition and control of property for ISIS. They allegedly committed the offence between December 2013 and July 2014. The charge carries a death sentence or up to 30 years' jail and a fine. No plea was recorded, and the case will be transferred to the High Court. This is part of Malaysia's efforts to arrest over 100 ISIS suspects since last year.

site_title: Iran premieres big-budget epic film Muhammad
summary: Iran has released its most expensive film, Muhammad, a 171-minute epic that chronicles the childhood of the Muslim prophet. Directed by Majid Majidi, the film, which cost around $40 million, aims to reclaim the rightful image of Islam, which he claims has been distorted by extremists. The film has won praise from early audiences and has already sold out many showings in Iran. However, it has triggered controversy in the Sunni world, with some critics labeling it as anti-Islamic.

site_title: North Korea's Kim credits nukes not talks for deal with South Korea
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un credited the country's nuclear deterrent for securing a landmark agreement with South Korea, rather than negotiating skills. The agreement, reached in Panmunjom, ended a tense military standoff and committed both sides to starting an official dialogue. Kim dismissed top officials from the Central Military Commission and appointed new ones, and emphasized the need to strengthen North Korea's military capability. The agreement does not require North Korea to discuss the end of its nuclear weapons program.

site_title: Judo: Trstenjak makes Slovenia history as Japan dominate worlds
summary: Slovenia made history as Tina Trstenjak won the country's first-ever world judo title, defeating France's Clarisse Agbegnenou in the under-63kg final. Japan continued to dominate the championships, with Takanori Nagase winning the men's under-81kg division and securing Japan's first-ever world title in this category. With four gold and nine medals, Japan is virtually assured of finishing top of the medals pile, setting the benchmark ahead of the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

site_title: Asian stocks extend global rally after strong US data sends Wall Street soaring, STI up 1.35%
summary: Asian stocks rose for a third consecutive day, driven by a surge in US economic data that sent Wall Street soaring. The Straits Times Index rose 1.35% and China's Shanghai Composite Index climbed 2.8% amid speculation of government intervention in the equities market. The rally also lifted Japan's Nikkei index 3% and South Korea's Kospi index 1.56%. The strong US data, which showed a 3.7% annualized growth rate, fueled optimism about the US economy's stability and halted a global selloff that began after China's currency devaluation on August 11.

site_title: Olympics: Rio Paralympics toils in face of 'huge job'
summary: Preparations for the Rio Paralympics are on schedule, with 11 days of events set to begin on September 7, 2016. However, making Rio accessible for thousands of disabled athletes and spectators remains a major challenge due to inadequate wheelchair access. Many sidewalks are broken or lack ramps, and access to public transport is spotty. The organizing committee aims to raise awareness and pressure the government to invest in wheelchair-accessible infrastructure, with a goal of creating an accessible city beyond the Paralympics. Despite this, the committee assures that preparations are on track.

A jury previously determined Hayward had tricked Pedroza into signing an agreement cutting her out of royalties. Pedroza's share could reach $10.7 million once settlement and attorney fees are agreed upon.

The tightly bunched leaderboard holds a one-stroke lead over several other players.

summary: Mitsubishi Corp. has agreed to buy a 20% stake in Olam International Ltd. for $1.53 billion in two deals, valuing the company at $7.65 billion. This investment is a sign of confidence in Olam, which was previously fending off attacks from US short-seller Muddy Waters. Mitsubishi will become the second-largest shareholder after Temasek Holdings, controlling 51%. The deal is part of a trend of Asian trading houses investing in agriculture to meet growing demand for food in the region.

Mayweather, who is undefeated with a record of 47-0, cited the wear and tear on his body as the reason for his retirement. He expressed his gratitude for his successful career and his ability to decide when to quit the ring, a choice many in the sport are denied. Mayweather is looking forward to working with up-and-coming fighters and pursuing other interests after his retirement.

site_title: Boat packed with migrants sinks off Libya; up to 200 feared dead
summary: A boat carrying around 400 migrants, mostly from sub-Saharan Africa, Pakistan, Syria, Morocco, and Bangladesh, sank off the Libyan coast, with up to 200 feared dead. The Libyan coast guard rescued 201 people, including 147 brought to a detention facility. The incident is part of the Mediterranean's deadly migrant crisis, with over 2,300 deaths this year and 3,500 last year. Libya's lawlessness and chaos have turned it into a transit route for migrants fleeing conflict and poverty to reach Europe, with many facing poor conditions and limited medical care in overcrowded detention facilities.

site_title: Japan inflation stalls and spending slides, keeps BOJ under pressure
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation remained flat in July, with household spending unexpectedly falling 0.2% year-over-year, casting doubt on the Bank of Japan's forecast of a 2% inflation target. The weak figures will pressure the central bank to expand its stimulus program, despite BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's assurances that the economy will recover. Policymakers are weighing the need for additional stimulus against concerns about Japan's massive public debt and rising costs of existing measures. The BOJ is ready to deploy more stimulus if necessary to reflate the economy, but is cautious of big fiscal spending.

Rice is set to begin a trip to China, marking a significant diplomatic engagement between the two nations.

site_title: Facebook celebrates one billion users in single day
summary: Facebook reached a milestone of 1 billion users in a single day, surpassing the number of people on Earth who use the internet. The milestone was marked by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who stated that the network is "just the beginning of connecting the whole world." The social media platform has seen a surge in monthly active users, with 1.49 billion users, and has also announced new technology to help video creators protect their work from being copied without permission.

site_title: NBA: Former 76ers basketball star Darryl Dawkins dies
summary: Former NBA star Darryl Dawkins, known as "Chocolate Thunder" for his powerful dunks, died at 58 due to a heart attack. Dawkins played 14 seasons in the league, averaging 12 points and 6.1 assists per game, and was known for his flamboyant personality and high-flying game. His legacy was marked by his iconic dunks, which shattered two glass backboards in 1979, leading the NBA to adopt breakaway rims. Dawkins passed away, leaving behind a family and a legacy that will be remembered by fans and the basketball community.

site_title: Cheater website Ashley Madison had few women: Report
summary: A report by Gizmodo analyzed hacked data from Ashley Madison, revealing that the majority of female profiles were fake or created by automated bots. The data showed only 1,492 women checked messages, compared to 20 million men, and 2,409 women logged on for chat. The report suggests that the website, which claims to facilitate extramarital affairs, may have promoted little action and few actual affairs. The findings contradict the site's slogan, "Life is short. Have an affair."

site_title: Nurturing a love for nature
summary: Dr. Wong Poh Poh, a retired associate professor of geography at the National University of Singapore, advocates for Singapore to share more information on coastal vulnerability with its citizens to guard against climate change. He notes that the country's coastal geomorphology is a field he pioneered, studying how human activities like tourism reshape the coastline and influence human activities. Dr. Wong suggests that Singapore should prepare for climate change by deciding what space to give to coastal ecosystems as sea levels rise and retreating further inland, and implementing laws for "managed retreat." He also recommends maintaining Pulau Ubin's rural environment, introducing compulsory gardening in schools, and extending gardening schemes in housing precincts to resuscitate island consciousness and nature awareness.

site_title: About the book
summary: National University of Singapore Emeritus Professor Sit Kim Ping shared a story of resourcefulness in the 1970s, where she improvised using a pestle and drill bit to blend rat livers for research. This anecdote is featured in Dr. Juliana Chan and Dr. Rebecca Tan's new book, "Singapore's Scientific Pioneers", which aims to highlight the contributions of lesser-known individuals who laid the foundations of Singapore's scientific achievements. The book is supported by grants from Nanyang Technological University and the SG50 Celebration Fund, and can be downloaded for free at www.asianscientist.com/pioneers/

site_title: Blazing a path in science
summary: Dr. Gloria Lim, a retired professor of botany, became the first female dean of science at the University of Singapore, which later merged to form the National University of Singapore. Despite having no science background, Lim joined the university in 1949 and went on to publish hundreds of research papers, author books on mycology, and advise the Ministry of Defence on mould problems. Despite her achievements, Lim notes that the Singapore National Academy of Science is comprised entirely of men, highlighting the underrepresentation of women in the field.

site_title: No, you don't have to drink 8 glasses of water a day
summary: A widely-held health myth claims that people should drink eight glasses of water a day, but there is no scientific proof to support this claim. Research has failed to find benefits in drinking extra water for healthy people, and many studies have used arbitrary standards to declare dehydration in otherwise healthy individuals. In reality, the human body is finely tuned to signal thirst, and dehydration is typically only a concern in cases of illness, excessive sweating, or inability to drink. The myth has persisted despite being debunked by multiple studies and experts, with some attributing it to a 1945 Food and Nutrition Board recommendation that was misinterpreted.

images.alt_text: Urine osmolality is rarely used by clinicians as a means to find out if a child is dehydrated or not.

site_title: Founder of cancer registry
summary: Prof Kanagaratnam Shanmugaratnam, 94, established the Singapore Cancer Registry (SCR) in 1967 to collect data on cancer trends in the country. He was largely responsible for developing the World Health Organisation's classification of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Initially, Prof Shanmugaratnam created a card index of histologically diagnosed cancers in Singapore, but later expanded to include cancers diagnosed through other methods, such as radiology. He emphasizes the importance of cancer registries in tracking rapidly changing disease patterns, stating that trends may not be representative of the past.

images.alt_text: Prof Shanmugaratnam, who is the father of Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, still conducts fortnightly seminars for trainee doctors, and consults on difficult cases referred to him by colleagues from public and private hospitals.

site_title: S'pore has major role in advancing medical research
summary: Singapore plays a significant role in advancing medical research, with its environment and policies fostering innovation-dependent industries. The country's collaboration with researchers, academia, and private companies has led to the development of new medicines, such as treatments for hepatitis C, offering cure rates of 90% or more. This open-innovation approach, which involves partnerships between governments, universities, and companies, is crucial for driving medical research forward. With its unique blend of a dynamic pool of researchers, a broad-based R&D ecosystem, and a public policy framework that encourages international collaboration, Singapore is well-positioned to take a leading role in the development of new medical advances.

summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has unveiled six candidates for the upcoming polls, including social psychologist John Tan Liang Joo and compliance auditor Sidek Mallek, both of whom aim to address socioeconomic issues and help low-income families. Tan wants to raise the issue of a minimum wage, while Sidek focuses on cutting red tape and providing assistance to needy citizens. The SDP will contest several constituencies, including Marsiling-Yew Tee, Holland-Bukit Timah, and single-seat wards. The party's leader, Chee Soon Juan, believes the slate of candidates is credible and will give Singaporeans a serious option to consider.

site_title: Keen to shape a bright future for children
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has introduced eight candidates for the upcoming election, including Terence Tan Li-Chern, Firuz Khan, Cheryl Denise Loh Xiu Wen, and Luke Koh Tiong Yee. The candidates aim to shape a bright future for Singapore's children, focusing on issues such as education, healthcare, and income inequality. Tan, a lawyer, and Khan, a chocolate factory owner, have personal experiences that motivated them to join politics, while Loh, a sales consultant, wants to serve the elderly and Koh, a managing partner, aims to address the ageing crisis and extend compulsory education.

site_title: Charles Chong to take on WP in Punggol East SMC
summary: PAP veteran Charles Chong, 62, has been confirmed as the candidate for Punggol East Single-Member Constituency (SMC), challenging Workers' Party's (WP) Ms Lee Li Lian. This is Chong's first contest in opposition territory, following WP's 2013 by-election win. Chong, who has fought in six general elections since 1988, acknowledges the challenge but believes Punggol East residents are getting a raw deal due to the town council's financial issues. He is confident of a 50-50 chance of winning, citing increased Meet-the-People sessions turnout.

summary: The Reform Party has unveiled its first batch of candidates for the upcoming election, contesting West Coast GRC and Radin Mas SMC. The party also pledged to cap the number of foreign workers and hold the government accountable. The candidates include property agents Darren Soh and Andy Zhu, former Democratic People's Party member Noraini Yunus, and director of an oil and gas company, Kumar Appavoo.

site_title: Let S'poreans run things themselves, says Sylvia Lim
summary: Singaporean politician Sylvia Lim suggests the government should not "infiltrate every aspect of life" and instead allow private sector talent to steer movements. She advocates for giving people more opportunities to run things themselves, aligning with the Workers' Party's "Empower Your Future" slogan. Lim believes an entrenched opposition presence in Parliament will make the government more responsive, and that responsiveness stems from Singaporeans' signals through their votes. The Workers' Party is fielding 28 candidates in the upcoming elections.

site_title: Singapore won’t pay tax on its Johor waterworks: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore will not pay the raised land assessment tax on its Johor waterworks as it is not obliged to under the 1962 Water Agreement, which is valid till 2061 and is guaranteed by both Singapore and Malaysia governments. The tax was sought by Kota Tinggi district authorities to double the tax rate on the Johor River Waterworks, owned by PUB. Minister for Foreign Affairs and Law K. Shanmugam stated that if the issue is not resolved, Malaysia may seek to levy execution on the waterworks.

site_title: Ask the expert
summary: Scientists have found that people who recall their dreams more often, or "high recallers," tend to wake up more frequently and respond more actively to complex sounds during wakefulness. Research in rats suggests that memory-consolidating activity during REM sleep decreases in high recallers, making it harder to remember dreams. This difference in brain activity may explain why dreams are difficult to recall, and why some people are more likely to remember them than others. The discovery could provide insight into the physiological basis of dream recall.

site_title: Ex-director of defunct travel agency sued over photocopiers
summary: A founding director of defunct travel agency Five Stars Tours, Johnny Lim Cheng Onn, is facing a lawsuit over $770,000 in unpaid lease for nine photocopying machines. Lim claims he didn't read the document before signing a personal guarantee and only discovered the true extent of the debt after receiving a letter from Orix Leasing. He argues that the guarantee should be limited to the purchase price of the machines, $152,000, and is resisting the claim in a two-day trial in the High Court.

site_title: Transport Minister's a thankless job, Mr Lee told Raymond Lim
summary: Former Transport Minister Raymond Lim was told by founding Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew that helming the transport portfolio was a "thankless job," but someone had to do it. Lim, who is retiring from politics, recounted the encounter at the introduction of the PAP's East Coast GRC slate. He praised his successor, Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew, saying each minister tries their best to deal with the issues, including crowded trains and train reliability. Lim expressed his gratitude to his colleagues, including Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say, and said serving his country and people has been his greatest cause.

images.alt_text: Mr Raymond Lim (left) and Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say hugging each other yesterday.

site_title: Leaked poster shows possible SPP-DPP team
summary: A leaked poster of the joint Singapore People's Party-Democratic Progressive Party Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC team has revealed possible candidates, including DPP's Benjamin Pwee and SPP's Law Kim Hwee, Abdillah Zamzuri, and Bryan Long. The team's election slogan is "We hear you. We speak for you." Despite neither party confirming the poster's contents, SPP chairman Lina Chiam said her team is "as strong as can be" and will reveal the final team on Nomination Day. The joint team was formed after a reconciliation between the parties, but cracks have since appeared, with the DPP introducing five possible candidates.

images.alt_text: A mock-up of an election poster shows (from left) SPP's Law Kim Hwee, 55, SPP's Abdillah Zamzuri, 31, DPP's Hamim Aliyas, 50, SPP's Bryan Long, 37, and DPP's Benjamin Pwee, 47. However, neither party has confirmed the contents of the poster.

site_title: Singapore cannot exist in a cocoon: Minister
summary: Singapore Foreign Minister K. Shanmugam warned that the country cannot exist in a "cocoon" and is affected by trends in neighboring Malaysia and Indonesia. He highlighted Malaysia's economic struggles, racial and religious polarisation, and potential for rising Islamisation, which could impact Singapore's economy and social cohesion. Shanmugam also expressed concerns over Indonesia's underperforming economy and rising nationalism, which could affect economic cooperation and Singapore's reputation as a haven for foreign investment.

images.alt_text: Mr Patrick Daniel (at far left), editor-in- chief of Singapore Press Holdings' English/Malay/Tamil Media Group, moderated the session featuring Foreign Minister K. Shanmugam, who highlighted some challenges faced by Singapore.

site_title: Airport tech officer jailed 15 months for corruption
summary: A former technical officer at Changi Airport, Henry Goh Keng Hwee, was jailed 15 months for corruption after accepting over $40,000 in bribes in exchange for awarding contracts to a company. Goh, who worked for the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore and later became an associate engineer with Changi Airport Group, built bribes into the contract price, earning secret profits from his employer. He pleaded guilty to nine charges and has paid back $36,000 to his former employer.

site_title: Science Briefs  : Science sector celebrates SG50
summary: Singapore is celebrating its 50th birthday with a year-long series of science events, including exhibitions, lab tours, and performances. The events, organized by A*Star and universities, aim to engage the public and scientific community. Meanwhile, a book on sudden cardiac death was launched, highlighting the importance of awareness and prevention. Research also found that urban heat-island effect can be mitigated by the presence of greenery, with a study published by NASA revealing a significant temperature difference between urban and rural areas.

site_title: Adultery site leak: More than meets the eye
summary: Singapore users of Ashley Madison, an adultery website, are at risk of losing their careers and being blackmailed or scammed after more than 32 million members' data was leaked online by hackers. Over 4,000 e-mail addresses with ".sg" suffix were found, including those of public servants and business e-mail addresses. Experts warn that using work e-mail addresses for personal reasons is a bad practice, and not verifying e-mail addresses on websites poses security issues.

site_title: Some in S'pore 'could be influenced by other countries'
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister K. Shanmugam warns that some sections of the population could be influenced by foreign countries, potentially affecting domestic constituency opinions. This could impact foreign policy decisions, as domestic interests may not align with those of small groups. Shanmugam cited the World War II History Research Association's event, which sparked controversy, and noted that Singapore's position on issues like Japan's pacifist Constitution and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict remains neutral. He cautions that ethnic groups, such as the Chinese and Indians, may be susceptible to foreign influence, especially with the rise of the internet.

site_title: What it should have been
summary: The Jurong Region Line may have been mistakenly estimated to have 16 stations, with the actual number likely to be lower, based on the North-East MRT line's station count.

site_title: MOH helps doctors pick up geriatric, family medicine skills
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) has expanded its Community Care - GP Partnership Training Award to include geriatric and family medicine courses. This move aims to enhance the skills of general practitioners in caring for patients with complex medical needs. The award, which covers 70% of course fees, is open to doctors sponsored by government institutions or voluntary welfare organizations. The addition of these courses is part of MOH's efforts to develop the community care sector and provide higher standards of care, with the goal of recruiting more staff and enhancing their quality.

site_title: Lessons learnt from close fight: Swee Say
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has learned lessons from its 9-percentage-point drop in vote share in the 2011 General Election and is heading into the upcoming polls "fighting to win". PAP East Coast GRC candidates, including anchor minister Lim Swee Say, are emphasizing their commitment to understanding voters' concerns and addressing them. The team has engaged in "deep engagement" with residents over the past four years, aiming to build connections and win votes. The PAP is seeking to capitalize on the significance of the general election, which is taking place amid a transition in Singapore's workforce, population, and aging population.

site_title: Cloud-seeding operations in 3 Indonesian provinces
summary: Indonesia has begun cloud-seeding and water-bombing operations in Riau, South Sumatra, and West Kalimantan to curb haze-causing fires. Four aircraft and eight helicopters have been deployed by the National Disaster Mitigation Agency and National Technology and Applied Science Agency until at least November. Despite Jambi province recording 130 hot spots, it has been excluded from the operations due to regional government consent requirements under Indonesia's 1999 decentralization law. The haze has caused acute respiratory infections, with the most affected areas being Jambi city and surrounding regencies.

site_title: Tree cutter killed by falling branch
summary: A 45-year-old Indian national, Mr Ganesan, was killed in a workplace accident while cutting trees in a forested area in Singapore. He was struck by a falling branch while sitting on a 10m high branch, leaving him suspended by his safety harness. Despite being lowered to the ground by his co-workers, he was found unresponsive and pronounced dead by paramedics at 4:30pm. The police have classified the incident as an unnatural death, and the victim had been working in Singapore for the past six years.

images.alt_text: The tree cutter was working in a forested area behind Kheam Hock Road when he was struck. The police have classified the case as an unnatural death.

site_title: Home briefs : Under probe for illegal import of animals
summary: Two Singaporean men, aged 20 and 44, are being investigated for importing animals without a valid permit. Two spotted doves and three sugar gliders were found in their car at Tuas Checkpoint. The men could face fines of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to a year if convicted. The incident highlights the strict regulations on importing live animals and birds in Singapore.

summary: The People's Association (PA) has announced 10 new partners joining the Senior Academy Golden Work Series, doubling the total job opportunities to 200. The programme, launched in April, offers workshops to train seniors in job skills, internships, and part-time work opportunities. Since its launch, 560 residents have signed up, with 20% of available job opportunities taken up. New partners include POSB bank, Yoshinoya, and Pet Lovers Centre, offering jobs at $5-$8 per hour.

site_title: Would you like some cooking oil with that dress?
summary: Jurong Point Shopping Centre, a suburban mall in Singapore, is offering free grocery items to shoppers who spend at least $80 at its 130 fashion stores until September 27. The campaign, a tie-up with food manufacturer Lam Soon, aims to boost sales amid declining foot traffic and competition from new malls and online retailers. So far, about 3,000 items have been given out, but some customers have expressed skepticism about the offer, saying it won't encourage them to buy more fashion items. The mall has also introduced other measures, including a new overhead bridge and employee training, to improve the shopping experience.

site_title: Jailed 11 months for pocketing over $100k
summary: A Singaporean man, Lim Sim Hong, was jailed 11 months for breaching his trust with a woman he met online, Laura Smith. He received $109,160 from her in 2012, claiming it was for an art gallery, but instead used it for personal investments and expenses. When questioned, Lim admitted to misusing the funds and producing false documents. He was initially charged with up to seven years in prison, but received a reduced sentence due to his infatuation with Laura and subsequent devastation when she failed to visit.

site_title: 'No change' in travel plans of visitors from Singapore
summary: A planned rally by Malaysia's electoral reform group Bersih in Kuala Lumpur did not deter visitors from Singapore from traveling to the city. Travel agencies and coach companies reported no concerns about the rally, and the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued no notice against travel to Kuala Lumpur. The rally's location, away from Merdeka Square, also reduced the risk of disruptions, and the Hungry Ghost month is typically a lull season for travel. Flight bookings to Kuala Lumpur remained unaffected, according to ASA Holidays.

site_title: Tap-in to use toilet for the disabled
summary: Jurong Point Shopping Centre has introduced a tap-in system to limit access to its toilets for the disabled to those with validated Cepas passes, aiming to curb abuse by able-bodied individuals. The system, set to be rolled out across all 10 toilets in three months, requires users to tap their cards on a sensor pad before entry. The mall's management will monitor users via CCTV and provide assistance for first-time users who forget their cards. The move is in response to complaints of misuse, including smoking and hogging by non-disabled individuals.

site_title: Ex-tour guide crafted 'web of deceit': Judge
summary: A former China tour guide, Yang Yin, is accused of crafting a "web of deceit" to gain control of a $35 million fortune from a 88-year-old widow, Madam Chung Khin Chun. Yang moved into Madam Chung's home, cut her off from friends and family, and manipulated her into changing her will to leave him as the sole beneficiary. The judge's decision to throw out the original will and replace it with a new one, leaving nearly all of Madam Chung's assets to charitable causes, was based on testimony from Madam Chung's friends and former employees, who described Yang's controlling behavior and financial manipulation.

site_title: S'pore faces challenge of 'three peaks': Swee Say
summary: Singapore is facing challenges of a "three peaks" - a growing workforce, increasing population, and an aging elderly population. Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say emphasized the need for effective strategies to address these issues, which are unsustainable for the past decade and beyond. The upcoming General Election will determine the leaders who will tackle these challenges, with voters urged to support candidates who can serve the community and lead the country forward over the next 50 years.

site_title: The bonds that bind military veterans
summary: A group of former members of the British Royal Air Force's 81 Squadron gathered for a reunion in Singapore, rekindling bonds and sharing stories of their time in service. The squadron, known for its role in World War II and later in post-war Singapore, has an impressive history of aerial photography. The reunions, started by Al Taylor, have helped preserve the squadron's legacy through the preservation of over 450,000 aerial photos, now available at the National Archives of Singapore.

site_title: Unforgettable images of World War II
summary: Major (Retired) Ishwar Lall Singh and other World War II survivors shared memories at a ceremony in Singapore to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the war's end. The event included a poem by Professor Edwin Thumboo and a minute's silence. Singh recalled the shrill whistle of Japanese bombs, the sight of dead bodies, and the hardship of living under Japanese occupation. The ceremony was officiated by Minister Lawrence Wong, who emphasized the importance of peace and stability between nations.

site_title: No link between GBS infection and eating sashimi, says MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has found no link between Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection and the consumption of sashimi. The investigation found an association between GBS infection and "yusheng-style" raw fish sold at food stalls, but not with Japanese raw meat or fish dish sashimi. The number of GBS cases has decreased significantly since mid-August, when licensed food sellers were advised to stop selling raw fish dishes using certain types of fish.

images.alt_text: The ministry found no links between GBS infection and consumption of sashimi (left). Its probe found only an association between the disease and eating "yusheng-style" raw fish sold at food stalls (right).

site_title: Scientists solve mystery of polar bear Knut's death
summary: Scientists have solved the mystery of polar bear Knut's death, attributing his 2011 drowning to a rare condition called anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, found in humans. The condition, which affects 200,000 people annually, was identified through analysis of Knut's brain samples. The inflammation caused by the condition led to motor control loss and ultimately resulted in his death. This is the first-ever diagnosis of the condition in an animal, and researchers believe that bears can live longer in captivity, with Knut's mother surviving to nearly 30 years old.

summary: Half of Singaporeans, approximately 500,000 people, watched the National Day Rally Speech last Sunday, according to a YouGov poll. Those aged over 55 generally liked the speech best, with 68-72% agreeing on its relevance, convincingness, and other traits. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong spoke on housing, childcare, and re-employment age, hinting at the upcoming general election. The majority of respondents (around 4 in 10) felt proud and confident about Singapore's future after the speech, while a quarter were happy with it.

site_title: Tennis: Serena faces strong home challenge at US Open
summary: Top-seeded Serena Williams faces a tough challenge at the US Open, with a quarter that includes nine American players, including sister Venus. summary: Barcelona and Manchester United were drawn into favorable groups in the Champions League, with Barcelona paired with Bayer Leverkusen, Roma, and BATE Borisov, and United facing PSV Eindhoven, CSKA Moscow, and Wolfsburg. Chelsea returns to FC Porto, while Arsenal faces Bayern Munich in Group F. PSG, looking to add a European crown, is drawn with Real Madrid, while debutants Astana, Atletico Madrid, and Galatasaray join Benfica in Group C. The first round begins on September 15, and the competition concludes next May.

site_title: Student threatened to kill self, others at Mississippi State University
summary: A Mississippi State University student, Fhu-Qui Kong "Bill" Nguyen, was arrested after threatening to harm himself and others, prompting campus lockdown and active shooter alerts. Despite initial warnings of a potential shooter, university officials later determined Nguyen did not have a gun. Nguyen, a freshman, was taken into custody within minutes, and students were eventually cleared to resume normal activities. The incident did not result in any reported shots fired or injuries. Charges against Nguyen were not immediately known.

site_title: Football: Messi, Sasic voted UEFA's best players of 2014-2015
summary: Lionel Messi was voted UEFA's best player in Europe for the 2014-2015 season, claiming his second award after winning the Champions League, La Liga, and Spanish Cup with Barcelona. Germany's Celia Sasic won the women's award, beating Amandine Henry and Dzsenifer Marozsan. Messi thanked his teammates for their contribution, while Sasic, a top scorer in the Champions League and Women's World Cup, retired last month. Messi succeeds Cristiano Ronaldo, who won the award last year.

site_title: Qatar Airways 'shamed' into action over pregnancy, marriage
summary: Qatar Airways has relaxed its policy of sacking cabin crew for getting pregnant or marrying in their first five years of employment, a move welcomed by the International Transport Workers Federation. The airline had previously phased out the restrictions over six months, offering temporary ground jobs to pregnant women and allowing staff to marry after notification. The change comes after the UN's International Labour Organisation called on the airline to scrap rules on pregnancy, citing them as discriminatory. The ITF considers the move a "tremendous advance" for staff rights.

site_title: Mers virus kills 19 in week in Saudi: Ministry
summary: Saudi Arabia has reported 19 deaths from the Mers coronavirus in a week, bringing the total fatalities to 502 since 2012. The number of infections has surged to 1,171 cases, with health authorities forced to shut a hospital ward due to the outbreak. With over two million pilgrims expected for the haj pilgrimage, Saudi Arabia is the country worst hit by the virus, which is considered a deadlier but less infectious cousin of Sars.

site_title: Father of Virginia TV reporter slain on air vows to fight for gun control
summary: A father of a Virginia TV reporter killed in an on-air shooting vowed to fight for gun control, urging lawmakers to take action to prevent similar tragedies. The shooting, which also killed a cameraman, occurred during a live interview by a disgruntled former employee. Despite President Barack Obama's frustration over gun violence, federal legislation on the issue remains unlikely, with some states passing gun control measures instead.

site_title: Stench of death as Austria finds truck loaded with migrant bodies
summary: Austrian police discovered up to 50 decomposing migrant bodies in an abandoned truck on a highway near the Hungarian border. The grim discovery has sparked outrage and calls for a "fresh" and "quick" response to the European migrant crisis. European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, expressed shock and vowed to tackle the issue of human trafficking. The incident is the latest tragedy in the Mediterranean, where over 2,300 migrants have drowned this year, and highlights the dangers of the land journey for migrants through eastern and southeastern Europe.

site_title: Saudi king to visit White House in September
summary: Saudi King Salman will visit the White House on September 4th, marking his first visit to the US since becoming king in January. The meeting with President Barack Obama will focus on strengthening bilateral relations, counter-terrorism efforts, and regional issues such as the conflicts in Yemen and Syria. This visit underscores the strategic partnership between the US and Saudi Arabia, following the king's absence from a Gulf leaders' summit in May due to concerns over Iran's growing influence.

Despite a third bid of £30 million from Chelsea, Everton will not sell Stones, who is considered a prized asset for the club's future. Martinez maintains that he has big plans for Stones and will keep him as a key player.

site_title: Thai court issues arrest warrant for suspect over second blast near pier
summary: A Thai court issued an arrest warrant for a suspect over a blast near a Bangkok pier, where no injuries were reported. The blast occurred just days after a deadly shrine bombing in downtown Bangkok that killed 20 people. The suspect, of unknown nationality, is accused of "illegal possession of an explosive device" and is linked to a similar blast at a canal near Saphorn Pier. Police have not yet confirmed a link between the two blasts, but an arrest warrant has been issued for the suspect seen in CCTV footage.

site_title: Tesla car gets best-ever rating from Consumer Reports
summary: Tesla's new Model S P85D electric vehicle has received the best-ever 100/100 rating from Consumer Reports, outperforming any other car in the group's tests. The four-wheel drive P85D boasts impressive energy efficiency, safety, and performance, with instant acceleration reaching 60 miles per hour in 3.5 seconds. The high-end vehicle, priced upwards of $125,000, is seen as a breakthrough model pushing the boundaries of performance and fuel efficiency, with Tesla expected to introduce more affordable models in the future, including the Model 3, estimated to start at around $35,000.

site_title: Australian man dies surfing in Indonesia: Police
summary: An Australian surfer, Ronald Stephen Schneider, 54, died while surfing in Indonesia's Mentawai islands, a world-famous surf spot off Sumatra's west coast. Schneider fell off his board onto a shallow reef, and his friends found his body with severe injuries, including bleeding from his head and torso. The cause of death was a result of being smashed by heavy waves onto rocks. A consular assistance team from the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is providing support to his family.

site_title: World's fastest man Usain Bolt knocked down by runaway Segway after 200m race
summary: Usain Bolt, the world's fastest man, was knocked down by a runaway Segway after winning the 200m gold at the 15th IAAF World Championships in Beijing. A cameraman on the Segway failed to notice a loose wheel and it careened out of control, hitting Bolt as he celebrated his victory. Bolt escaped injury and laughed off the incident, continuing his victory lap.

site_title: Wall St extends gains, helped by GDP data
summary: US stocks rose sharply on Thursday, driven by revised GDP data showing the US economy grew faster than initially thought, at 3.7% annual growth. Jobless claims fell more than expected, pointing to a firming labor market. Despite strong data, some investors believe the recent market volatility could force the US Federal Reserve to hold back on a rate hike in September, citing China's economic slowdown.

site_title: Housing, healthcare top issues at National Day Rally 2015 Public Forum
summary: The National Day Rally 2015 Public Forum in Singapore focused on housing and healthcare issues, with 140 public members providing feedback. Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Dr Vivian Balakrishnan and Senior Minister of State for Health and Manpower Dr Amy Khor chaired the session. Participants discussed topics such as housing subsidies, affordable healthcare, and the re-employment age increase to 67. The forum aimed to gather public feedback on the National Day Rally, with responses largely positive, particularly on parenthood measures and housing policies.

site_title: Mamma Mia! Abba's piano up for auction
summary: The piano used by Abba in their most celebrated songs is up for auction at Sotheby's in London on September 29, with an estimated value of £600,000-£800,000. The piano, built by Swedish instrument designer Georg Bolin, was used in hits like "Dancing Queen" and "Mamma Mia" between 1973 and 1977. The instrument was originally purchased by Metronome Studios in 1967 and later by Atlantis Grammofon, the current seller. The auction follows previous sales of famous pianos, including John Lennon's Steinway upright piano for £1.67 million in 2000.

site_title: US TV anchor recalls horror of colleagues' on-air murder
summary: US TV anchor Kimberly McBroom recalls the horror of on-air murder of her colleagues Alison Parker, 24, and Adam Ward, 27, during a live interview on WDBJ7-TV. Despite hearing "popping sounds," McBroom initially believed the situation was not dire, but after a voice on the live audio feed said "three down," the reality set in. Vester Lee Flanagan, a former reporter fired in 2013, killed Parker and Ward before fatally shooting himself. McBroom, a mother of two, struggled to come to work on Thursday, but chose to honor her colleagues' memory by continuing to do her job.

site_title: Swimming: Canada's mixed 4x100m freestyle team break world junior record
summary: Canada's mixed 4x100m freestyle team broke the world junior record with a time of 3min 27.71sec, beating the previous record of 3:28.74 set by Australia in 2013. This achievement came on the same day that Canadian Taylor Ruck won the women's 100m freestyle in a championship record of 53.92sec. Australia remains in the lead of the medal table with five golds, while Canada secured its second gold of the meet.

Goh noted that his normal reality is the heartland, where he interacts with people daily, and that introducing him as a candidate in a coffee shop would be out of place.

site_title: Greece names top judge as caretaker PM ahead of snap vote
summary: Greece's President Prokopis Pavlopoulos named Supreme Court judge Vassiliki Thanou as caretaker prime minister, the first woman to hold the position, ahead of a snap vote expected next month. The move comes after outgoing Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras resigned following a major rebellion in his Syriza party. Thanou, 65, will lead a caretaker administration until the election date is officially announced, likely September 20. Tsipras has ruled out forming a national unity government if he fails to win an outright majority.

site_title: Singapore shares up over fresh China stimulus, Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index surged 2.52% to 2,945.43 points, driven by a Wall Street rally, fresh Chinese stimulus, and potential delays in the Fed rate hike. Banking counters led the gains, with OCBC, DBS, and UOB rising 3.2%, 2.5%, and 2% respectively. Shanghai also jumped 5.4%, following China's injection of 140 billion yuan and potential interest rate cuts.

site_title: Mitsubishi Corp to buy at least 10% in Olam from Temasek-sources
summary: Mitsubishi Corp agreed to purchase at least a 10% stake in Olam International Ltd from Singapore state investor Temasek in a deal valued at at least $500 million. The deal, which was confirmed by people familiar with the matter, follows a halt in Olam's trading and a reported strategic partnership with a Japanese peer. Mitsubishi had conducted extensive due diligence and considered other investments before choosing Olam. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of 2015.

site_title: Philippines says it accepts Singapore's sedition ruling on Filipino nurse: Media
summary: The Philippines has accepted a Singapore court's ruling convicting a Filipino nurse, Ed Mundsel Bello Ello, of sedition for posting inflammatory comments on Facebook. Ello, 29, pleaded guilty to publishing a seditious comment and two counts of lying to police. The prosecution is seeking a 20-week jail sentence. The Philippine authorities respect the court's decision, urging overseas Filipinos to follow host country laws.

site_title: Athletics: Usain Bolt beats Justin Gatlin to 200m gold, claims sprint double at World C'ships
summary: Usain Bolt won the 200m gold at the Athletics World Championships in Beijing, beating Justin Gatlin with a time of 19.55 seconds. This marks Bolt's second gold of the meet, following his 100m win on Tuesday. Bolt secured the sprint double, solidifying his dominance in the 100m and 200m events.

site_title: Medical advances offer new definition of death
summary: Medical advances have led to a reevaluation of the definition of death, shifting from solely cardio-respiratory function to brain death. This change was driven by improvements in medical care, enabling resuscitation of previously deceased patients and creating scenarios where individuals have a heartbeat but no brain function. The introduction of brain death was not solely for economic reasons, but to bring clarity to grieving families and to accommodate modern medical realities, highlighting the need for a more robust definition of death.

site_title: McDonald's is not quite lovin' Burger King's 'McWhopper' plan
summary: Burger King proposed a "McWhopper" sandwich, a hybrid of its Whopper and McDonald's Big Mac, to be sold at a pop-up restaurant in Atlanta for charity. The proceeds would benefit Peace One Day, aiming to make World Peace Day (Sept 21) an annual day of global unity. McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook rejected the idea, suggesting the companies could do more to make a difference and instead proposed a global awareness campaign. Burger King took out full-page ads in major newspapers to promote the idea, but McDonald's remained unresponsive.

site_title: Python versus king cobra in a battle at NTU campus
summary: A rare and intense battle between a king cobra and a reticulated python was witnessed on the grounds of Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore on August 27, 2015. The fight, which lasted around 20 minutes, was captured on photos by a graduate student, who estimated the king cobra to be 10-12 feet long. The python, estimated to be 5-6 feet long, was eventually captured by pest controllers after the cobra escaped into the bushes twice. The incident highlights the importance of snake safety and coexistence with wildlife.

site_title: War veterans commemorate 70th anniversary of the end of World War II
summary: Singapore commemorated the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II with an event attended by war survivors, veterans, and Inter-Religious Organisation representatives. Retired Major Ishwar Lall Singh shared his experiences of the war, describing the harsh conditions and common ailments faced by the population. Cultural Medallion recipient Professor Edwin Thumboo read a poem about growing up during the war, and a minute of silence was observed. The event highlighted the importance of peace and stability across nations, with Minister of Culture, Community and Youth Lawrence Wong emphasizing strong bilateral ties between Singapore and Japan today.

site_title: Car knocks down three motorcycles and dents two cars in carpark accident
summary: A 69-year-old driver of a red car crashed into three motorcycles and two cars at a Bedok North carpark in Singapore on August 27, 2015. The incident occurred when the driver backed into another white car after hitting a silver car and three motorcycles. Two cars, including one belonging to a witness, were damaged in the accident. The driver of the red car was not reached for comment, and the incident is the second reported collision involving the same driver at the same carpark in six months.

site_title: Two men being investigated for importing live animals
summary: Two Singaporean men are under investigation by the Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority for importing live animals, including two spotted doves and three sugar gliders, without a valid permit. The men, aged 20 and 44, were stopped at Tuas Checkpoint on Tuesday and had the animals hidden in various parts of their car. Anyone found importing live animals without a permit can face fines of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to a year.

site_title: US TV gunman warned he was 'human powder keg'
summary: Vester Lee Flanagan, 41, known as Bryce Williams, shot and killed two journalists, Alison Parker, 24, and Adam Ward, 27, during a live US broadcast in Roanoke, Virginia. Flanagan posted chilling footage of the incident online, warning he was a "human powder keg... just waiting to go BOOM." The killing raised questions about gun laws and the internet's role in spreading unfiltered content. Flanagan had bought his gun legally and had a history of anger issues, but no record of prior mental health concerns.

site_title: US economy grew 3.7% in second quarter
summary: The US economy grew 3.7% in the second quarter, surpassing the initial estimate of 2.3% and beating analysts' expectations of a 3.1% pace. The upward revision was primarily due to increased investment, state and local government spending, and consumer spending. This marks a significant improvement from the 0.6% growth in the first quarter, which was impacted by winter weather and port strikes. The revised GDP report indicates a strong rebound in the economy.

site_title: Good Samaritan returned lost car key
summary: A man parked his car at Chinatown Point on August 16 and later discovered his lost car key was missing. However, when he sought help at the information counter, he found that a good Samaritan had found and returned the key. The man expressed gratitude for the stranger's kindness and praised Chinatown Point for providing such a service, although the identity of the good Samaritan remains unknown.

site_title: Up to 50 migrants found dead in truck on Austria highway
summary: Austrian police discovered up to 50 migrant bodies in an abandoned truck on a highway, sparking a cross-border hunt for people-smugglers. The gruesome find comes amid Europe's migrant crisis, with over 2,300 people drowning in the Mediterranean this year. European leaders are meeting to find ways to handle the crisis, with some calling for a more coordinated response and others advocating for stricter border controls. The tragedy highlights the dangers of the land journey for migrants through eastern and south-eastern Europe.

site_title: Leave for caregivers of elderly parents
summary: Singaporean caregivers of elderly parents are seeking support as they often take time off work to care for their loved ones. In response to this, Tan Hon Yee suggests mandating parental care leave, a one-week to two-week annual leave for caregivers. This measure could help alleviate the burden of caregiving and allow caregivers to balance their work and family responsibilities. The suggestion comes after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's National Day Rally speech, which did not mention supporting caregivers.

site_title: Stream of people collecting forms at Elections Dept on second day after Writ of Election issued
summary: Candidates from various parties, including the People's Action Party (PAP), Singapore People's Party (SPP), and Reform Party (RP), submitted forms at the Election Department in Singapore on the second day after the writ of election was issued. The candidates, including PAP members Alex Yam and Christopher De Souza, submitted political donation and minority community committee certificates for the upcoming general election. The deadline for submission is on Friday, with nomination day set for September 1 and polling day for September 11.

site_title: Raffles Education Corp's FY2015 earnings plunge 69%
summary: Raffles Education Corp reported a 69% decline in FY2015 earnings to S$17 million, down from S$85.4 million in FY2014. Revenue fell 4% to S$120 million, excluding a one-time gain of S$7.3 million. Earnings per share dropped to 1.68 cents, and net asset value per share rose to 57.1 cents. The company attributed the decline to macroeconomic slowdown, currency volatility, and impending interest rate hikes.

site_title: Special education teachers deserve a raise too
summary: A Singaporean special education teacher expresses concern over the lack of a pay raise for special education teachers, despite the government's 4-9% pay increase for general teachers. The teacher notes that these educators face physical and emotional challenges while caring for children with special needs and are at risk of injury. High staff turnover in these schools is a result of underpaid staff, who are often driven by a passion for helping these children rather than financial gain. The teacher argues that these educators should receive commensurate pay increases to reflect their challenging and selfless work.

site_title: Malaysia's anti-Bersih 'Red shirts' make U-turn, defer rally
summary: Malaysia's anti-Bersih "Red shirts" group has postponed its protest, deferring the rally from its original date to avoid conflicting with the Bersih 4.0 rally. The group's spokesman, Datuk Jamal Yunus, said they would hold a new rally in one or two weeks' time to voice dissatisfaction over Bersih 4. The decision came after a meeting with police officials, who advised against holding the rally on the same day. The group had planned a counter gathering with 30,000 members, but will now follow the law and hold a rally at a suitable venue.

summary: The Ministry of Health has clarified that there is no link between consuming sashimi and the Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection. The Aussie dollar hit a record low against the Singdollar at 1.0017 per SGD. Wildlife Reserves Singapore is offering free admission to kids at the Panda Party to celebrate the third anniversary of the giant pandas' stay in Singapore.

site_title: Ex-Girls' Generation member Jessica Jung's fashion label inspired by her mother
summary: Former Girls' Generation member Jessica Jung, now based in Korea, has been promoting her fashion label Blanc & Eclare. Jung, 26, credits her travels and mother for inspiring her designs. She officially parted ways with talent agency SM Entertainment earlier this month and has been busy with her fashion brand. Jung held a media session at a Singapore store, where fans could meet her for a signing session after spending $350 or more. Her fashion label aims to capture distinct cultural colors and elegance, reflecting her mother's style.

summary: FJ Benjamin Holdings reported a 23% improvement in net loss for the full year, with a net loss of S$17 million and revenue falling 20% to S$293.4 million. Loss per share improved to 2.99 cents, while net asset value per share decreased to 14.94 cents. The firm attributed the results to a difficult year with reduced business in North Asia, declining tourist arrivals, and currency depreciation. Proactive action included store closures and cost-cutting measures, yielding significant improvements in store productivity.

site_title: Philippines seeks 'real-time' US help in disputed South China Sea
summary: The Philippines has requested the US to provide real-time surveillance and reconnaissance in the disputed South China Sea, amid China's rapid expansion in the area. The request was made after China blocks Philippine civilian ships from delivering supplies to a ship stranded in the area. US Pacific Command Chief Admiral Harry Harris promised to help the Philippines, while also preventing conflict from erupting. This move comes as China claims most of the South China Sea, through which $5 trillion in trade passes annually, and the Philippines, along with other countries, has overlapping claims.

site_title: China sentences 45 in Xinjiang in illegal border crossing cases
summary: China has sentenced 45 people in the Xinjiang region to prison for cases involving illegal border crossings, with many believed to be Uighurs seeking to join militant groups in Turkey. The cases involve organizing or funding "terrorist groups" and seeking "holy war". Authorities claim that some individuals are trafficked across the border to fight for groups like Islamic State, while rights advocates argue that China's policies are driving Uighurs to seek security through illegal immigration.

site_title: Have a safe fund transfer option
summary: Banks are considering a safe fund transfer option to prevent mistaken wire transfers. The proposed solution involves requiring recipients to input a numerical code before transactions are completed, which can then be sent to the recipient via SMS, email, or phone call. This would allow banks to verify the recipient's identity and prevent unauthorized transfers. The introduction of such a system could reduce the number of cases where funds are transferred to the wrong parties.

site_title: Rowsley to invest in real estate and hospitality businesses in Manchester
summary: Singapore-listed real estate company Rowsley is investing £200 million in a £200 million project in Manchester, acquiring a 75% stake in St Michael's, a five-star hotel and luxury apartments development. Construction will start in 2026, with completion expected in three years. Rowsley will partner with Beijing Construction Engineering Group and Manchester United legends Gary Neville and Ryan Giggs, who will own 2% each. The investment aims to tap into Manchester's growth and vibrancy, with Rowsley leveraging the city's hospitality sector.

site_title: Football: Balotelli vows to clean up his act and fulfil late father's wish
summary: Mario Balotelli, the 25-year-old Liverpool misfit, has vowed to clean up his act and fulfill his late father's wish of playing for Italy again. The striker has returned to AC Milan on a one-season loan deal, following a tumultuous period at Liverpool. Balotelli has promised to knuckle down and play with discipline, after being given a second chance by coach Sinisa Mihajlovic and the club. The move comes after Balotelli's adoptive father, Francesco, died last month, leaving Balotelli determined to make his father proud.

site_title: School sports: St Andrew's win C Division rugby crown, deny ACS (I) title treble
summary: St Andrew's Secondary won the Schools National C Division rugby title by defeating Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) 18-15 in the final. This marks their first title since 2013, and they also denied ACS(I) the treble of all three divisional titles. St Andrew's trailed 13-15 with 11 minutes left but staged a comeback, with flanker James Leow scoring the winning try in the 52nd minute. The victory is attributed to the team's perseverance and hard work over the past year.

site_title: Sacked Singaporean legal officer in 1MDB probe thanks Malaysia for not revoking her PR
summary: A Singaporean legal officer, Jessica Gurmeet Kaur, involved in the 1MDB probe, expressed gratitude to Malaysia for not revoking her permanent residency. Kaur, who has lived in Malaysia for over 20 years, had been under investigation for a purported leak. After being released on police bail, she thanked Immigration officials for confirming her PR status was not revoked, allowing her to move on peacefully. Kaur also thanked her lawyers for their efforts.

site_title: Tree cutter dies after being hit by falling branch
summary: A 45-year-old Indian national, Mr Ganesan, was killed in a freak accident while cutting a tree in a forested area behind Kheam Hock Road in Singapore. He was struck by a falling branch while sitting on a 10m-high branch, leaving him suspended by his safety harness. Rescuers lowered him to the ground, but he was found unresponsive and pronounced dead by SCDF paramedics. Investigations have classified the death as unnatural, and police are ongoing.

site_title: Ezra Holdings nears sale of subsea unit stake to Japan's Chiyoda
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore marine services provider, is nearing a deal to sell a 50% stake in its subsea business to Japanese engineering firm Chiyoda Corp. for over US$1 billion, including debt. This follows Ezra's sale of its offshore marine operations for US$520 million last year. The transaction aims to allow Ezra to focus on the growing subsea services market, where it competes with global rivals. The sale comes as Ezra shares have fallen 64% this year, resulting in a market value of US$239 million.

site_title: Noble Group surges 14% to lead gains on Singapore benchmark
summary: Noble Group Ltd. surged 14% to 51.5 Singapore cents, the largest gain since Aug 4, leading gains on Singapore's benchmark equity measure. The stock is still trading at less than half its price in mid-February after criticism of its accounting methods. Noble has pledged to boost annual operating income to over $2 billion within five years and held an investor meeting to restore confidence. Fellow commodity trader Olam International Ltd. also made significant gains, with no further details provided.

site_title: China's yuan ends firmer on suspected intervention, stock rally
summary: China's yuan closed firmer against the dollar on Thursday, supported by suspected central bank intervention and a strong rebound in the country's stock indexes. State-owned banks reportedly made large transactions, possibly on behalf of the central bank, which boosted the yuan's value. The onshore spot market closed at 6.4053 per dollar, 0.08% stronger than the previous close. Despite this, offshore yuan was trading 1.1% weaker than the onshore spot, indicating downward pressure on the currency amid a slowdown of the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: China denies rushing forces to border during Korean tensions
summary: China has denied rushing soldiers to its border with North Korea, following increased tensions between the two Koreas. The Defence Ministry stated that the reported deployment of additional tanks to Yanbian was "untrue and completely hyped up." China's border defense forces are said to be in normal combat readiness and training, with the situation on the border remaining generally stable. This comes as North and South Korea agreed to end a military standoff and China seeks to maintain its isolation of North Korea amid strained ties over nuclear tests and border murders.

site_title: Indonesia sanctions JPMorgan for negative research note
summary: Indonesia has sanctioned JPMorgan Chase & Co after the investment bank downgraded its rating on Indonesian government bonds from "overweight" to "underweight" due to concerns over the country's fragile economy. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro accused JPMorgan of spreading panic and labeled the downgrade as "unethical." The exact nature of the sanctions was not disclosed, but Brodjonegoro hinted they would be "disturbing" for JPMorgan. The downgrade reflects investor sentiment toward Indonesia's slowing economy and declining forex reserves.

Bersih 2.0's leader Maria Chin Abdullah stated that the ban is against constitutional rights and the right to information, and that the group will sue if the ban is not withdrawn. The MCMC's decision has been described as "shocking" by Bersih 2.0.

site_title: Woman in China robbed, molested by Uber driver: Report
summary: Chinese police have arrested an Uber driver suspected of robbing and molesting a female passenger in Chengdu, Sichuan province. The 42-year-old driver, who pulled a knife on the woman, was detained two days after she reported the attack on August 9. The incident highlights concerns over safety in China's loosely regulated ride-hailing app market, which has seen similar incidents in the past. The arrest is the latest in a series of regulatory challenges faced by Uber in China.

summary: South Korean prosecutors arrested four people, including a former Goldman Sachs employee, for allegedly manipulating shares in a small Korean conveyor belt maker, Dong Yang P&F, in 2011. The former Goldman Sachs employee was accused of receiving 100 million won (approximately $118,722) for assisting the manipulation. The trading allegedly took place before Goldman Sachs' South Korean asset management unit was shut down in 2012. The firm denied any wrongdoing and has been cooperating with prosecutors.

site_title: Football: De Bruyne to seal record $118m move to Manchester City after medical
summary: Kevin de Bruyne's transfer from Wolfsburg to Manchester City is set to be finalized for a record-breaking 74 million euros ($118 million), surpassing the previous Bundesliga record. The 24-year-old Belgian international attacking midfielder, who played a key role in Wolfsburg's German Cup win, will undergo a medical check in Manchester to complete the deal. The transfer fee could rise to 80 million euros with bonuses, marking a significant signing for Manchester City.

site_title: MyRepublic to start mobile network trial in October at Jurong East
summary: MyRepublic to launch 8-week mobile network trial in Jurong East starting October 22, with up to 500 participants selected to test the network. The trial will cover a limited area, including shopping malls and public facilities, and will use small cell mobile network technology. Interested parties can register at my4thtelco.sg until September 8. The company aims to become Singapore's fourth telco, joining Singtel, StarHub, and M1, with a promise of free local data for a year to broadband customers who sign up before September 30.

site_title: SanDisk launches new portable solid-state drives
summary: SanDisk has launched two new portable solid-state drives, the Extreme 500 and Extreme 900, offering faster transfer speeds and durability compared to conventional hard drives. The Extreme 500 is a compact device with capacities of 120GB and 240GB, while the Extreme 900 offers up to 1.92TB of storage with transfer speeds of up to 850MB per second. The company also introduced the Connect Wireless Stick, a wireless mobile flash drive that can be linked to three devices via Wi-Fi. Both products are available for purchase now.

site_title: New social service office in Pasir Ris officially opened
summary: A new social service office in Pasir Ris officially opened on August 27, 2015, marking the 22nd office launched by the Ministry of Social and Family Development since mid-2013. Located at the Pasir Ris Sports and Recreation Centre, the office serves over 137,000 residents and aims to provide help within 2km of where 95% of needy residents live or work. It has successfully piloted an after-school programme for low-income families and plans to expand it if successful. The office works with voluntary welfare organisations and community partners to better coordinate social services.
