site_title: StarHub prepaid customers can now use existing mobile data caps in Malaysia.
summary: StarHub has introduced a data roaming service for its prepaid customers in Malaysia, allowing them to use their existing mobile data caps without incurring additional roaming fees. Prepaid users can dial *123*5*2# to activate the service, which offers local prepaid rates and no additional activation or subscription charges. This move follows M1's Data Passport service, which enables postpaid customers to use their existing data bundles in six countries for $10 a month.

site_title: Lonely US rhino to seek mate in Indonesia
summary: The Cincinnati Zoo is sending its only Sumatran rhinoceros, Harapan, to Indonesia to mate, as breeding efforts at the zoo have been unsuccessful. Harapan, an 8-year-old male, will remain on exhibit while preparing for the 60-hour journey to the Sumatran Rhino Sanctuary. The decision comes after Indonesia indicated it will not send another rhino to the US, and Malaysia, the only other country with captive rhinos, has infertile females. This move aims to increase the species' global population, which is believed to number only 100 in the wild.

site_title: Newborn dies after rat bites in India hospital: Mother
summary: A 10-day-old newborn in southern India died after being bitten by rats in a government-run hospital, the baby's mother alleged. The incident occurred at the Guntur Government Hospital in Andhra Pradesh state, where the baby was being treated for a urinary tract problem. Three health officials have been suspended and an inquiry has been ordered. The hospital's top official stated that rat mesh was installed in the neonatal intensive care unit, but the boy's death still occurred. This incident highlights concerns over under-staffed and run-down government hospitals, where most of India's population relies on free treatment.

site_title: Football: I can score more goals by being 'selfish' but team is more important, says Ozil
summary: Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil says he can score more goals by being more selfish, but prioritizes team success over personal glory. The 26-year-old World Cup winner has scored nine goals in 51 Premier League appearances, aiming to increase his goal tally this season. Ozil believes his ability to play defense-splitting passes and prioritize team needs is his key characteristic, and he will continue to play for the team's success rather than personal achievements.

summary: Turkey has expressed regret over speculation linking its citizens to the Bangkok bomb attack that killed 20 people, and vowed to cooperate with Thai authorities if concrete evidence emerges. Thai police are investigating Turkish nationals who arrived in Thailand around the time of the blast, but have not ruled out any group or nationality. The attack, which targeted the Hindu Erawan Shrine, also raised the possibility of a connection to the Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking Muslim minority from China.

summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest bank, reported a 0.6% increase in Q2 net profit to RM1.58 billion, driven by a 9.1% rise in net operating income. Fund-based income grew 13% to RM3.54 billion, while loans rose 11.1% on an annualised basis. The bank attributed steady growth in net operating income across all business pillars. A single-tier interim dividend of 24 sen per share was declared, with a 4 sen cash portion and a 20 sen electable portion.

site_title: Suicide bomber kills 2 Iraq generals in Anbar: Army
summary: A suicide bomber in an explosives-rigged vehicle killed two high-ranking Iraqi army generals, Staff Major General Abdulrahman Abu Raghif and Staff Brigadier General Safin Abdulmajid, in Ramadi, Anbar province, on Thursday. The attack occurred north of the city, and the bomber was reportedly neutralized by security forces. The incident occurred on the same day that Iraqi forces launched a major operation to retake Ramadi from the Islamic State (ISIS) group.

site_title: Swimming: American Michael Andrew clocks new championship record in men's 50m backstroke at Fina World Junior meet
summary: Michael Andrew of the US set a meet record in the men's 50m backstroke at the Fina World Junior meet, completing the event in 25.14 seconds. This broke the previous record of 25.44s set by Grigory Tarasevich in 2013. Hoong En Qi became the first Singaporean swimmer to qualify for the semi-finals, finishing 16th overall in the women's 50m butterfly heats. The top 16 swimmers in each event qualify for the semi-finals, with the top-eight in the 400m events progressing to the final.

site_title: Wanda Group, controlled by Asia's richest man Wang Jianlin, buys Ironman triathlon brand for US$650m
summary: Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group has acquired World Triathlon Corp for US$650 million, expanding its sports empire. This deal adds to Wang's sports-related holdings, including soccer team Atletico Madrid and marketing company Infront Sports & Media AG. World Triathlon Corp, organizer of Iron Man triathlons, is expected to generate US$183 million in revenue this year. The purchase is part of Wang's strategy to tap China's growing sports industry, with plans to acquire more companies in the second half of the year.

site_title: Ex-CAAS technical officer jailed 15 months for corruption
summary: A former employee of the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and Changi Airport Group (CAG) was jailed for 15 months for corruption. Henry Goh, 45, accepted bribes totaling $43,780 between 2008 and 2011 in exchange for awarding contracts to the giver's company. Goh, a technical officer, used false quotations to justify his recommendations and knowingly deceived the organizations with non-genuine offers. He pleaded guilty to three charges of corruptly accepting bribes and six charges of knowingly deceiving the organizations.

site_title: Malaysia turns to 1998 currency peg architect as markets bleed
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has unveiled an economic task force, modeled after his predecessor Mahathir Mohamad's National Economic Action Council in 1998, to combat the ringgit's slide amid global financial market turmoil. The task force includes business leaders and former finance officials, aiming to stem the decline in confidence in the country's economy. The move comes as the country faces allegations of financial irregularities and a decline in global investor confidence, with the ringgit weakening beyond the peg set by Mahathir in 1998.

site_title: Malaysia to block all websites promoting Bersih rally
summary: Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC) plans to block all websites promoting the Bersih 4 rally, citing concerns over public unrest and national stability. The rally, scheduled for Aug 29-30, aims to push for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation amid allegations of corruption. The MCMC urges the public to report websites spreading such content, warning of potential harm to the nation's stability and economic stability.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party introduces second batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has introduced its second batch of candidates for the upcoming polls, including lawyer Terence Tan, sales consultant Cheryl Denise Loh, chocolate factory owner Firuz Khan, and managing partner Luke Koh. The candidates were introduced by party chairman Sylvia Lim and Hougang MP Png Eng Huat, highlighting their backgrounds and experiences. The party aims to field a record 28 candidates in five group representation constituencies and five single-member constituencies, with the theme "Empower Your Future."

site_title: New awards for GPs to go into geriatric and family medicine
summary: Singapore's Health Ministry and the Agency for Integrated Care have introduced new awards to support General Practitioners in pursuing geriatric and family medicine. The awards will fund 70% of the course fees for the Graduate Diploma in Geriatric Medicine and Family Medicine. This expansion builds on a previous award launched last year for palliative care, which received positive feedback from recipients. The awards aim to develop expertise in intermediate and long-term care.

site_title: GE2015: Is this the final line-up of the SPP-DPP team for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC?
summary: The Singapore People's Party (SPP) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have leaked a mock-up of their joint election poster for the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC team, revealing the likely slate of candidates. The team consists of two DPP members, Benjamin Pwee and Hamim Aliyas, and three SPP members, Law Kim Hwee, Abdillah Zamzuri, and Bryan Long. The parties have reportedly agreed on the team, with the poster featuring the slogan "We hear you. We speak for you." The team's composition and election slogan are expected to be officially announced on Nomination Day.

site_title: Germany's Merkel meets Balkan leaders over spiralling migrants crisis
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel met with Balkan leaders in Vienna to address the European migrant crisis, the largest since World War II. Merkel vowed zero tolerance for anti-migrant violence, while Balkan countries called for a concerted EU action plan to tackle the crisis. The talks come amid growing criticism of the EU's failure to agree a joint response, with Hungary refusing to attend. The crisis has led to increased tensions, with Austria considering tougher anti-migration measures and the UN urging countries to prove their compassion.

site_title: What you need to know about Malaysia's Bersih movement
summary: Malaysia's Bersih movement is set to hold a massive rally this weekend to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Najib Razak. The movement, led by Maria Chin Abdullah, consists of 84 non-governmental organizations calling for electoral reform and has eight demands, including updating the electoral roll and reforming postal ballots. Past rallies have been marked by clashes with police, with the 2012 event resulting in hundreds of arrests. The current rally, known as Bersih 4.0, aims to push for Najib's resignation and institutional reforms to prevent corruption.

site_title: Malaysian armed forces will take action if Bersih rally leads to state of emergency
summary: Malaysia's Armed Forces (ATM) will intervene in the planned Bersih 4.0 rally only if the government declares a state of emergency, said its chief Tan Sri Zulkifeli Mohd. The ATM has been conducting annual training sessions for the eventuality of a peaceful gathering getting out of hand. Zulkifeli expressed concern that an incident similar to the Thailand bombing could occur, and noted that the ATM will take preventive measures to maintain public order. The rally is set to take place on August 29 and 30 in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Young companies dominate ranks of Singapore's 'Fastest Growing 50'
summary: Singapore's 'Fastest Growing 50' Awards revealed a new breed of high-flying companies, with 22 winners under 10 years old. Lattice SG, part of US-based Lattice Semiconductor Group, was named the fastest growing company in Singapore. Home-grown enterprises dominated the list, with 28 Singapore companies making the FG50 winner's list, up from 23 last year. These young companies have achieved at least 10% annual turnover growth and remain profitable, making Singapore an attractive place to do business.

site_title: Australia eyes closer US security ties amid concerns over regional instability
summary: Australia's Defence Minister Kevin Andrews announced plans to strengthen its security alliance with the US amid growing regional instability, driven by China's increasing assertiveness in the South China Sea. The country's strategic defence white paper, set to be released later this year, aims to deepen ties with the US and bolster its own military capabilities. The move comes as the Asia Pacific region shifts towards the US and China, with billions of dollars in trade passing through the South China Sea. The US alliance remains Australia's top priority for security and defence planning.

site_title: Football: LionsXII get JDT II, Terengganu and Kedah in Group A of Malaysia Cup
summary: The LionsXII will face Johor Darul Takzim II (JDT II), Terengganu, and Kedah in Group A of the 2015 Malaysia Cup. The team, which includes Singapore national team captain Shahril Ishak and veteran defender Baihakki Khaizan, will look to improve their performance after finishing third in the group stages last year. The first round of group matches will be played on September 12, and the LionsXII have already won silverware this campaign, claiming the Malaysia FA Cup with a 3-1 victory over Kelantan in May.

site_title: Aussie dollar hits new record low below parity against Singdollar
summary: The Australian dollar hit a record low below parity against the Singapore dollar on August 27, 2015, trading as low as 1.0049 to one Singdollar. The decline was attributed to plummeting commodity prices, a rising US dollar, and uncertainty over China, a key export market. This marked the first time the Aussie dollar closed below parity since the global financial crisis in 2009.

site_title: Question raised by Virginia shooting video: Does anybody need to see it?
summary: A shooting in Virginia on August 26, 2015, killed two journalists and an interviewee during a live broadcast. The incident raises questions about whether viewers need to see the footage, with some media outlets deciding to show the graphic content while others chose to avoid it. The controversy centers on re-broadcasting the footage, with some stations freezing or cutting away from the video. Social media platforms also decided not to show the footage. The incident highlights issues of ethics, the potential impact on copycats, and the over-hasty reporting of unconfirmed information.

site_title: Millennium sequel hits bookstores with a twist and a new author
summary: The Girl In The Spider's Web, the fourth book in Stieg Larrson's Millennium trilogy, has been released with a new author, David Lagercrantz, who wrote the book after being tasked with the job. The book features Lisbeth Salander, the tattooed young hacker, in a contemporary backdrop with spies from the US National Security Agency. The book has sold over 2.7 million copies in the first edition and has been translated into 42 languages, sparking controversy in Sweden with some calling it a "grave robbery."

site_title: Hong Kong student leader Joshua Wong charged over pro-democracy protests
summary: Hong Kong student leader Joshua Wong, 18, has been charged with "unlawful assembly" and inciting others to participate in an unlawful assembly over pro-democracy protests in 2014. Wong, who became the face of the democracy movement, is already due in court on Friday for separate charges of obstructing police. The charges stem from a student protest on September 26 last year, and activists accuse the authorities of a "political prosecution." Wong's lawyer calls the charges "flawed" and a "clear abuse of process."

site_title: Free admission to River Safari for children aged 7 and 8 from Sept 1-30 for 'Panda Party'
summary: Wildlife Reserves Singapore is hosting a "Panda Party" at River Safari to celebrate the third anniversary of giant pandas Kai Kai and Jia Jia's stay in Singapore. Children born in 2007 and 2008 will receive free admission from Sept 1-30. The pandas will also celebrate their birthdays in September, with a private birthday bash on Sept 3. Activities during the "Panda Party" week, from Sept 5-13, will include panda awareness, meet-and-greets, and educational sessions.

site_title: Delicious things I'm eating: Catalan food, budget gourmet and more
summary: Catalan chef Carles Gaig's La Ventana in Singapore has received positive reviews for its authentic and delicious Catalan food. The restaurant offers a Gran Apat Tasting Menu ($148++) and various tapas, including Jamon Iberico de Bellota and Lobster Coca. Another notable dish is the Black Cod & Samfaina, slow-cooked bacalao on a vegetable ragout. The restaurant also features a house specialty, Canelon, and a seasonal food festival with guest chefs, including Luke Burgess and Rene Knudsen. In contrast, Immigrants Gastrobar is closing after three years, leaving fans of chef Damian D'Silva's unique Eurasian dishes.

site_title: No link found between eating sashimi and GBS infections
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has clarified that there is no link between consuming sashimi and Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infections. An investigation found an association between GBS and the consumption of "yusheng style" raw fish sold at food stalls, but not sashimi. The number of GBS cases has decreased significantly since licensed food vendors were advised to stop selling raw fish dishes. MOH advises vulnerable groups to continue exercising caution and avoiding raw ready-to-eat food.

site_title: More internship, part-time job opportunities for seniors as Golden Work series expands
summary: The People's Association (PA) has expanded its Senior Academy Golden Work Series, increasing the number of companies offering internships and part-time jobs to seniors. 10 new companies have joined, adding 100 vacancies, and the program has seen 560 seniors sign up for courses. The PA is also expanding the program to 15 community centers, and seniors can earn between $5 to $8 an hour from these opportunities. The program aims to provide job skills-related workshops and opportunities for seniors to stay engaged and active.

site_title: Lanxess opens 200m euro synthetic rubber plant in Singapore, its biggest single investment globally
summary: Lanxess, a German specialty chemicals maker, has opened a 200 million euro synthetic rubber plant in Singapore, its largest single investment globally. The plant, which produces neodymium butadiene rubber, has a production capacity of 140,000 metric tons per year and will serve global markets, particularly in the growing Asian market. The facility has created about 100 highly-skilled jobs, largely filled by locals, and is seen as a strategic base for Lanxess to manage its Asian operations. The move is expected to capitalize on the region's growing demand for chemical products.

site_title: Hong Kong schools need to be less competitive and more humane : China Daily
summary: Hong Kong's education system is deemed too competitive and inhumane, prioritizing school reputation over students' well-being. The failure of a school to call emergency services after a student's death and the stress caused by the Territory-wide System Assessment are cited as examples. To address this, the Education Bureau should modify the system to evaluate schools on factors beyond academic results, such as the learning environment, to promote a more balanced and equitable education.

site_title: Indonesia to unveil policy package today to help economy and rupiah, which hit record low to Singdollar on Wednesday
summary: Indonesia is set to unveil a policy package Thursday aimed at boosting the rupiah, which hit a 17-year low against the US dollar, and promoting investment. The package includes tax incentives and deregulation measures to strengthen the economy and encourage foreign currency inflows. The move comes after Bank Indonesia cut its GDP growth outlook for this year and next year, and follows China's weakening of its yuan. The rupiah has shed about 12% against the US dollar this year and hit an all-time low of 10,110 to the Singapore dollar on Wednesday.

site_title: China market chaos blamed on exodus of overseas returnees
summary: China's stock market chaos is attributed to the exodus of top financial talent, known as "sea turtles," who returned to China from overseas during the 2008 financial crisis. Despite being recruited by the government to reform the markets, many of these returnees became disillusioned with their low pay, lack of influence, and limited opportunities for promotion. The exodus has led to a lack of expertise in Chinese markets, resulting in misguided policies and further market instability. The crisis has damaged China's credibility and government commitment to financial reform, with the country's public funds failing to stem the market decline.

site_title: Commander of US Pacific Fleet makes first official visit to Singapore
summary: US Pacific Fleet Commander Admiral Scott Swift made his first official visit to Singapore, meeting with Minister for Defence Dr Ng Eng Hen and other officials. The visit highlights the strong defence relations between the US and Singapore, with both navies engaging in regular interactions through visits, exchanges, and exercises. These interactions aim to enhance professionalism and mutual understanding between personnel, solidifying the friendship between the two nations. The visit is seen as a significant step in strengthening the defence ties between the two countries.

site_title: Bangkok blast: Youngest victim wounded returns to Hong Kong for treatment
summary: A 9-year-old girl, Jasmine Chu, wounded in the Bangkok blast, returned to Hong Kong for treatment. She was one of 20 people killed in the Erawan shrine bombing, the country's worst single mass-casualty attack. Jasmine had three rounds of surgery, including a 7-hour operation to remove shrapnel, and is now stable at Princess Margaret Hospital. Her father says she's recovering well and is worried about school and homework, with some shrapnel remaining in her body.

site_title: Currency pegs under pressure in emerging markets as commodity prices fall
summary: Plunging commodity prices are testing the viability of emerging currencies' long-standing pegs to the US dollar, with some already abandoned. Kazakhstan unshackled its tenge last week, and others, such as the Saudi riyal, Nigerian naira, and Egyptian pound, are at risk due to overvaluation. Analysts warn that countries reliant on commodities and exposed to China's weakening economy will struggle to justify the cost of clinging to fixed exchange rates, making it increasingly difficult to defend pegs.

site_title: Schools in New South Wales barred from showing gay film
summary: A film about children with same-sex parents, "Gayby Baby," was barred from being shown in public schools in New South Wales, Australia, despite being part of a student-led initiative promoting diversity and inclusiveness. The film's director and Wear it Purple Day founder expressed disappointment, citing the film's positive benefits for students. The ban was sparked by parental complaints, but critics argue it undermines efforts to promote acceptance and inclusiveness in schools. The film is set to open in cinemas next week.

site_title: Cleaner jailed 11 months for misappropriating $109k
summary: A 56-year-old cleaner, Lim Sim Hong, was jailed for 11 months for misappropriating $109,160 transferred to his OCBC Bank account by someone he befriended online. He had agreed to help a woman named Laura set up an art gallery in Singapore, but instead used the funds for his own investments and lied about spending the money. Lim had also spent $13,450 on himself and family members. He made restitution of $14,210, and $99,710 has been recovered to date.

site_title: Temasek joins consortium to bid for Tesco's South Korean unit, Homeplus: Sources
summary: Temasek Holdings has joined forces with private equity firm MBK Partners to bid for Tesco's South Korean unit, Homeplus, valued at around $6 billion. This move comes as Tesco battles to recover from accounting scandals and market share losses in Britain. The potential second-biggest merger in the Asian consumer sector aims to spread risks in the tough South Korean retail market. The sale of Homeplus is Tesco's largest divestment to improve its financials, with the unit generating $8.27 billion in annual revenue in 2014.

site_title: OCBC, Lion Global upsize private-equity fund by 40% to $550m on strong investor demand
summary: OCBC Bank and Lion Global Investors successfully closed their private-equity fund, the Lion-OCBC Capital Asia Fund I, L.P., after being upsized to $550 million from $400 million due to strong investor demand. The fund will invest in small and medium companies in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, and China. It took nine months to secure investor subscriptions, significantly faster than the typical one-year timeframe. Investors include insurance companies, regional banks, sovereign wealth funds, and high net worth individuals, attracted by the fund's superior returns and unique positioning as a bank-sponsored investment fund.

site_title: Heard of China's fake Rolexes? Now there's a fake Goldman Sachs
summary: China's Goldman Sachs clone, Goldman Sachs (Shenzhen) Financial Leasing Co., has been operating in Shenzhen, Hong Kong, using a nearly identical name to the US-based Goldman Sachs Group Inc. The company claims to be one of the city's largest financial leasing firms, but its ties to the US bank remain unclear. A US casino workers union has accused the company of being linked to a group of gambling companies controlled by Cheung Chi-tai, a prominent figure in Macau junkets, and alleged ties to Chinese organized crime gangs. China's government has been accused of tolerating brazen name-borrowing by foreign companies, with similar cases involving pirated movies, handbags, and Rolexes.

site_title: Beijing braces itself for a less friendly post-Ma Taiwan: The China Post
summary: China's top negotiator, Chen Deming, has warned that cross-strait relations will become increasingly challenging after Taiwan's presidential election in 2016, with officials hinting that signed agreements could be undone if Taiwan denies the "1992 Consensus" on one China, different interpretations. This marks a shift in tone, as Beijing has learned to hold its fire in campaign seasons. The warning is seen as a resignation to a post-Ma Taiwan that may be less China-friendly, with Beijing facing less leverage to offer deals to Taiwan as its economy slows down.

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party unveils candidates for West Coast GRC, Radin Mas SMC
summary: The Reform Party (RP) has announced its candidates for the 2015 General Election, including Director Kumar Appavoo for Radin Mas SMC and a team led by party secretary-general Kenneth Jeyaretnam for the West Coast GRC. The RP will contest in three GRCs, including Ang Mo Kio GRC, where blogger Roy Ngerng and his former lawyer M. Ravi are also candidates. The party's manifesto includes proposals for a monthly $500 pension for seniors and child benefits of $300 for under-16 children. The slate will be finalized on Nomination Day on Sept 1.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.63% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 1.63% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,919.86 points. The benchmark index rose 46.86 points, driven by a higher volume of trades with around 102 million shares exchanged. Gainers outpaced losers 152 to 19, indicating a positive market sentiment.

site_title: China central bank sets yuan midpoint at weakest level since 2011
summary: China's central bank set the yuan's midpoint at 6.4085 to the US dollar, the weakest level since 2011. The move, announced in early August, has led to a 3% slide in the yuan against the dollar. The People's Bank of China also cut its seven-day repo money rate guidance to 2.35%, amid concerns over capital outflows. The yuan's devaluation has accelerated global market volatility, with tighter money rates also contributing to recent large equity falls in China.

site_title: Shock and tears as Virginia TV station grapples with on-air murder of two journalists
summary: Two journalists, Alison Parker, 24, and Adam Ward, 27, were shot and killed during a live telecast at WDBJ-TV in Moneta, Virginia, on August 26, 2015. The gunman, Vester Lee Flanagan, 41, also killed himself after posting a video of the murder online. The station's staff and viewers were in shock, with many still reeling from the news. The victims were a popular on-air duo known for their energy and ambition, and their deaths have left a lasting impact on the community.

site_title: China police arrest 12 suspects over Tianjin blasts
summary: Chinese police have arrested 12 suspects, including the chairman and senior managers of Rui Hai International Logistics, over the giant explosions in Tianjin that killed 139 people and injured hundreds. Prosecutors are also investigating 11 officials for "abuse of power" and "dereliction of duty" over the blasts, which devastated the port city. The arrests come after widespread outrage over alleged safety violations and possible official collusion, with the incident sparking concerns about pollutants contaminating the air and water.

site_title: Hazy in Malaysia till middle of September
summary: Malaysia's haze from Indonesia's open burning is expected to persist until mid-September, with the west coast and coastal states particularly affected. The situation is linked to the south-west monsoon season, and winds carrying smoke from Kalimantan and Sumatra to Malaysia and Singapore are expected to continue. Sarawak may see an improvement in haze conditions over the next few days. Weather experts warn that the global El Nino phenomenon could increase the chances of hot and dry weather in Indonesia, leading to increased hot spots and more smoke.

The team is expected to compete against the Workers' Party (WP) in a keenly-fought contest. The PAP also announced Cheryl Chan as the candidate for Fengshan single-member constituency, replacing the incumbent MP Raymond Lim, who has announced his retirement.

site_title: Malaysia police warn all groups not to incite violence as anti-Bersih group plans to counter rally
summary: Malaysia's Inspector-General of Police Khalid Abu Bakar has warned against inciting violence amidst a planned counter-rally by an anti-Bersih group. The group, led by Umno division chief Jamal MD Yunos, plans to gather 30,000 people to counter the overnight Bersih rally, which aims to demand Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation. The police have declared the Bersih rally illegal and vowed to take action against those with weapons, warning that they will arrest those found in possession of arms. The public is urged to stay clear of the rallies.

site_title: GE2015: PAP introduces new face Cheryl Chan to contest Fengshan SMC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its candidate for the Fengshan Single-Member Constituency (SMC) in Singapore: 38-year-old grassroots leader Cheryl Chan. Chan, who has a decade of volunteering experience in Fengshan, replaces incumbent MP Raymond Lim, who is retiring after 14 years. Chan aims to champion causes such as helping the elderly and children from less privileged backgrounds. The PAP's decision to field a new face in Fengshan is rare, with only Lee Hong Chuang, a senior IT manager, contesting another single-seat ward.

site_title: Panasonic to stop making batteries in Beijing, cuts 1,300 jobs
summary: Panasonic will stop producing lithium-ion batteries at its Beijing factory, cutting 1,300 jobs, due to weak demand for basic mobile phones and digital cameras. The 15-year-old factory, acquired from Sanyo Electric in 2010, will close this month. Panasonic is restructuring to focus on higher-margin electric car batteries, shifting away from consumer electronics. The move follows stiff competition from Asian rivals and the emergence of South Korean manufacturers, leading to disappointing growth expectations. The closure is part of Panasonic's efforts to adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Oil rebounds as US crude stockpiles unexpectedly decline
summary: US crude inventories unexpectedly declined by 5.45 million barrels to 450.8 million through August 21, according to the Energy Information Administration. This led to a 1.9% rise in oil futures, with West Texas Intermediate reaching $39.35 a barrel. Crude production declined for the third week, and prices have decreased 35% from this year's peak in June, driven by concerns over a prolonged global supply glut. Despite this, analysts expect stockpile draws and predict a return to volatility.

site_title: GE2015: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong to contest WP-held Punggol East SMC
summary: Veteran PAP MP Charles Chong will contest the Punggol East Single-Member Constituency (SMC) at the upcoming general election, a surprise move by the ruling party. Chong, 62, will face Workers' Party incumbent Lee Li Lian, who won the seat in a 2013 by-election. This marks a bid by the PAP to regain control of the constituency. Chong, a seasoned politician with six general election wins, has been campaigning in the area and holding meet-the-people sessions in the past month.

Unlike past crises, China's stock slump is primarily a correction to a frothy valuation rather than a financial crisis. The economic impact is expected to be limited due to the stock market's marginal role in company funding.

site_title: Relief rally takes hold in Asia after US rebound, STI up 1.9%
summary: Asian stocks rose, tracking the US rebound, with the Straits Times Index jumping 1.55% and the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 1.6%. The rally followed a two-week selloff that erased over $8 trillion from global equities, and was fueled by the US S&P 500's 3.9% gain, its steepest increase since November 2011. Industrial metals, including copper and oil, also rose, while the yen weakened. China's Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.6%, and Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index surged 3.5%, as investors sought to capitalize on the US rebound and stimulus packages.

site_title: British ISIS hacker killed in US drone strike in Syria
summary: A British ISIS hacker, Junaid Hussain, was killed in a US drone strike in Syria on Tuesday, according to a US source. Hussain, 21 at the time of his death, was a top cyber expert for ISIS and was believed to be the leader of CyberCaliphate, a hacking group that attacked the Pentagon's Twitter account. US and European officials considered him a nuisance hacker rather than a serious threat, and his killing is the second reported killing of a senior ISIS figure in the last eight days.

site_title: Boxing: Amir Khan vows to help Pakistan produce boxing champions
summary: British boxer Amir Khan has vowed to help Pakistan produce champion boxers with a network of academies across the country. Khan, a two-time world champion, aims to set up schools in western Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, eastern Punjab, and Karachi. He believes Pakistan has the talent to produce boxing champions and plans to train Pakistani boxers to qualify for the Olympics. Khan's efforts follow the country's sole Olympic boxing medallist, Hussain Shah, who won a bronze in 1988, and Asian Games gold-medallist Mehrullah Lassi, who won in 2002.

site_title: Wal-Mart stores in US to stop selling AR-15 and other semi-automatic rifles
summary: Wal-Mart has announced it will stop selling AR-15 and other semi-automatic rifles due to sluggish demand, shifting focus to hunting and sportsman firearms. The decision is unrelated to high-profile incidents, including the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. The company cited low demand, affecting only a third of its US stores, and comes as part of a shift under new CEO Doug McMillon to address public opinion on social issues. The move follows pressure from investors, including New York City's Trinity Church, and is seen as a departure from Wal-Mart's previous stance on gun sales.

site_title: Joe Biden deciding if he can give 'heart and soul' to White House run
summary: US Vice-President Joe Biden expressed uncertainty about his ability to give "my whole heart and my whole soul" to a potential presidential run, citing emotional exhaustion following recent family tragedies. In a conference call with Democratic National Committee members, Biden said he's trying to decide whether to run for the White House, citing the need to evaluate his commitment to the campaign. His eldest son's death in May and his own past losses are reportedly factors in his decision-making process. Biden has been discussing options with senior advisers and met with Senator Elizabeth Warren over the weekend.

site_title: The global fixation on Chinese stocks makes no sense, say analysts
summary: Analysts say the global fixation on Chinese stocks makes little sense, citing the market's lack of correlation with economic fundamentals. Despite China's significant economic influence, the Shanghai Composite Index has little insight into the country's economic health due to speculation and individual investors dominating the market. The market's recent slump has led to increased links with global assets, but analysts argue that the risks of an economic slowdown or hard landing in China are overstated.

site_title: Olympics: LA officials ponder US$4.1 billion 2024 Olympic bid proposal
summary: Los Angeles city council is reviewing a $4.1 billion bid proposal for the 2024 Summer Olympics, which relies on private partnerships to cover venue costs. The bid, if successful, could generate a surplus of $161 million. The proposal includes plans to renovate and reuse existing venues such as the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, Staples Centre, and StubHub Centre. The USOC must submit the bid to the International Olympic Committee by September, with Paris, Rome, Hamburg, and Budapest already in the running. A city council decision is expected on Friday.

site_title: MMA: Ronda Rousey jabs Floyd Mayweather again, saying I earn more than you per second
summary: MMA star Ronda Rousey claims she earns more per second than Floyd Mayweather, stating she makes "two to three times more" than him. Rousey also pokes fun at Mayweather's literacy skills, saying she can text him when he learns to read and write. Mayweather has previously said no MMA fighter has made over $300m in 36 minutes, a claim Rousey disputes, stating she is the highest-paid UFC fighter.

site_title: Nasdaq executive urges China authorities to use circuit breakers
summary: Nasdaq's global trading head Hans-Ole Jochumsen urges China authorities to implement circuit breakers to prevent panic selling in the stock market. The country's stocks have experienced the biggest five-day drop in two decades, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.3% at close. Jochumsen believes circuit breakers can help avert the kind of market volatility seen in China and Europe, and notes that the US market has successfully implemented similar systems to prevent flash crashes.

site_title: Virginia shooter's first-person video of attack becomes ghoulish Internet hit
summary: A gunman, identified as Vester Lee Flanagan, live-streamed his attack on two TV journalists, Alison Parker and Adam Ward, in Virginia. The 56-second video, shot from the gunman's perspective, was posted on Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube, showing the shooting and the aftermath. The video was removed from social media sites, but not before it went viral. Flanagan, who had been fired from a TV station in 2013 for erratic behavior, died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound after fleeing the scene. The incident raised questions about the ethics of displaying graphic news footage online and the role of social media in sharing such content.

site_title: Football: Everton survive Barnsley scare as Martinez slams Stones 'circus'
summary: Everton came from 2-0 down to beat Barnsley 5-3 in the English League Cup, winning in extra-time. The match was overshadowed by speculation about defender John Stones potentially leaving for Chelsea, but manager Roberto Martinez stated Stones was "incredible under enormous pressure" and not for sale. Martinez criticized the media attention, calling it a "circus" and emphasizing the team's focus on becoming better. The win sets up an upcoming match against Championship side Reading in the third round.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras rules out forming national unity govt
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has ruled out forming a national unity government if he fails to win a majority in snap elections. Tsipras dismissed suggestions of cooperation with conservative opposition New Democracy, socialists Pasok, or centre-right Potami, stating he won't work with parties that ran previous governments. The election date is expected to be announced by President Prokopis Pavlopoulos by the end of the week, with September 20 being a likely schedule. Tsipras remains popular, but the outcome of the election is uncertain.

site_title: Golf: Tiger 'only going to get better', says niece
summary: Tiger Woods, after a torrid 2015, is on his way back to becoming a force in golf, according to his niece Cheyenne Woods. Tiger finished fourth at the Wyndham Championship, his best scoring sequence in two years, and his first top-10 finish since 2013. Cheyenne believes her famous uncle will continue to improve, saying "he's only going to get better from here." Tiger's focus and determination remain strong despite a 2015 slump, and his niece is excited to see him return to form.

site_title: Two SDP faces to focus on healthcare and education
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has introduced two new candidates, Dr. Paul Tambyah and Jaslyn Go, to focus on healthcare and education in the upcoming elections. Dr. Tambyah criticized the healthcare system for being "really, really expensive" and proposed alternatives, while Ms. Go spoke about the stressful education system and advocated for a more balanced approach. Both candidates emphasized the need for social justice and equality, and Dr. Tambyah called for a minimum wage and a talent-based immigration system.

site_title: Wall Street chalks up biggest gain in four years after six-day rout
summary: Wall Street experienced its largest one-day gain in four years on August 26, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 3.95% to 16,285.51. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the former rising 3.9% to 1,940.51 and the latter adding 4.24% to 4,697.54. The gains were driven by a positive durable goods report and comments from New York Fed President William Dudley that a September interest rate hike seems less likely. The rally followed a six-day losing streak and marked a significant turnaround in market sentiment.

site_title: MORNING MINUTES: What will make headlines today, Aug 27, 2015
summary: Singapore commemorates the 70th anniversary of the end of Japanese Occupation and WWII with a national event. The National Heritage Board will hold a commemorative event, honoring those who fell and those who survived. Meanwhile, 28 hotels will receive the Singapore Green Hotel Award for their environmental efforts, the highest number of winners since the award's inception. Petrochemical giant Lanxess inaugurates its €200 million synthetic rubber plant on Jurong Island, producing 140,000 tonnes of high-performance rubber annually. The western Balkans will host a summit of leaders, dominated by the European migration crisis.

site_title: No sharing of rallies under new rules
summary: The Elections Department in Singapore has introduced new rules for the upcoming General Election, including a ban on sharing rallies and rally sites among different political parties and independent candidates. Candidates and party leaders are also barred from speaking at each other's rallies, with a requirement to reveal their faces. The rules aim to prevent public safety concerns, such as overcrowding and potential violence. Opposition parties are expected to be more affected by the new conditions, with some analysts warning that they may need to curb their rhetoric on hot-button issues like immigration.

site_title: GE2015: Political chess game in the east
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is considering deploying former Cabinet minister Lim Boon Heng as a candidate for Aljunied GRC, a move that could impact the Workers' Party (WP). The WP, which won the constituency in 2011 with 54.72% of the vote, is rumored to be considering moving its MPs, including Sylvia Lim, to contest other seats. The PAP is also considering veteran MPs Charles Chong and Yeo Guat Kwang for Aljunied GRC. The WP's strategy may be weakened if it sends a "big gun" to contest East Coast GRC, where the PAP is also considering fielding candidates.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim Boon Heng in Serangoon North for a PAP Aljunied GRC meeting. PAP sources say it is unlikely that he will contest, but the very idea that he might is enough to make the WP hesitate on its next moves.

site_title: What's News: Aug 27, 2015
summary: Singapore has launched a $3 billion, five-year Action Plan for Successful Ageing, aiming to provide senior citizens with opportunities to learn, volunteer, and live independently after retirement. The plan includes opening senior centres and daycare facilities in new HDB projects and allocating up to $200 million for ageing-related research. Meanwhile, Singapore's factory output contracted 6.1% in July, its sixth consecutive decline, due to tepid global demand and rising business costs.

site_title: While You Were Sleeping: 5 stories you might have missed, Aug 27 edition
summary: Two Virginia TV journalists, Alison Parker and Adam Ward, were fatally shot during a live broadcast on Wednesday, August 26, by a suspect who claimed to be a "powder keg" of anger over racial discrimination. The suspect, Vester Flanagan, 41, died hours later after shooting himself while being pursued by police. Meanwhile, Wall Street experienced its largest one-day gain in four years, driven by concerns over a potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

site_title: Singapore-made device survives rocket explosion
summary: A Singapore-made device embedded in a Danish satellite, worth $12,000, was feared to be destroyed in a rocket explosion last year. However, the satellite was found intact on a US beach, and the device is still operational. Scientists from the NUS Centre for Quantum Technologies confirmed the device's survival through data comparison. The discovery validates the device's design and boosts confidence for future space missions, but the device will not be reused.

site_title: Use phone during meals? We hate it but we do it
summary: A survey by Ikea found that half of Singaporeans find it annoying when others use their mobile phones during mealtimes, but 83% admit to doing it. Only 22% of Singaporeans cook at home every day, with 36% enjoying cooking with others. The survey also revealed that 29% blame convenience of takeaway food and 25% lack of cooking skills as major hurdles to cooking at home.

site_title: Officers lauded at police commendation ceremony
summary: Police officers and auxiliary officers received awards at a commendation ceremony for their outstanding work and leadership. Assistant Superintendent Cyndi Koh was awarded for her role in solving a high-profile murder case, while Certis Cisco officers Simon Laurance and Yusaini Selamat were recognized for rejecting bribes from a suspect attempting to bribe them to stop a car from driving into a playground. A total of 242 Team Commendation awards were given out, with 5 High Commendation awards also presented for demonstrating the police core values of courage, loyalty, integrity, and fairness.

summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Low Thia Khiang has unveiled the party's theme for the upcoming General Election: "Empower Your Future". He urged voters to entrench the opposition's growing presence in Parliament to make Singaporeans part of the nation's decision-making process. Low emphasized that empowering citizens through voting is crucial to "supervise the Government" and not become "sacrifices" in the process. The WP is contesting 28 seats, with rookies Daniel Goh, Redzwan Hafidz, and Dylan Ng, among others, vying for positions.

site_title: Mood has changed but it's still tough: Boon Heng
summary: Former PAP chairman Lim Boon Heng says the mood in Aljunied GRC has changed since the last election, with people being more friendly towards the PAP team, but it's unclear if this translates into votes. Lim declined to reveal the candidates, citing a desire to let residents assess them on a more considered basis. He also dodged questions about his own potential return to politics, saying it will be known on Nomination Day. The PAP is set to unveil its Aljunied GRC candidates tomorrow.

images.alt_text: Ex-PAP chairman Lim Boon Heng was coy about whether MP Yeo Guat Kwang (above) is being fielded in Aljunied.

site_title: Not a question of fear but confidence
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Low Thia Khiang stated that the party aims to empower Singaporeans by giving them confidence, rather than playing up the fear factor. He attributed the lingering fear among voters to psychological baggage inherited from the past, rather than a genuine fear of repercussions from the government. Low Thia Khiang emphasized the need to build a confident people to move forward and thrive, rather than relying on the government for cues. This approach is part of the WP's strategy to address the current state of Singaporean society.

site_title: Home Briefs: Five men arrested over stolen m-cycles
summary: Five men in Singapore have been arrested for their suspected involvement in several motorcycle thefts, with three reported stolen between August 11 and 20. The suspects, aged 20-25, could face fines and up to seven years in jail if convicted. Meanwhile, a 38-year-old managing partner, Neo Leong Kiat, has been charged for submitting false information to obtain a $6,000 Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) payout, and must pay a maximum fine of $28,000 and a penalty of three times the amount wrongfully obtained.

site_title: Man charged with hurting maid
summary: A 41-year-old Indian national, Palaiyan Murugadass, has been charged with causing grievous hurt to a 38-year-old Filipino domestic worker, Ms. Allen Remedios Adolfo, in Singapore. Murugadass allegedly attacked Adolfo with a penknife at their condominium complex on Sunday evening, leaving her with deep scars. He was remanded for a week for investigations and faces up to 15 years in jail if convicted. The case will be mentioned in court on September 2.

site_title: ST170 Treats Contest: Cleaner wins 4-day cruise
summary: The Straits Times' 170th anniversary contest, ST170 Treats Contest, awarded five winners a prize: a 4-day cruise trip to Penang and Langkawi on Star Cruises' SuperStar Gemini for two, worth $5,480, or a staycation at Festive Hotel at Resorts World Sentosa. Winners include Mr Tan Sew Fock, a 63-year-old cleaner, and Faustina Tan, an aviation executive, who plan to take their wives and mothers on the trip. The contest, which began in March, received over 132,400 entries, with a grand draw for a new Land Rover Discovery Sport scheduled for September.

site_title: Learning about $ and cents can be fun
summary: Children in Singapore's Ang Mo Kio Family Service Centre - Basic participated in a financial literacy exercise, using scrapbooking activities based on The Straits Times, to learn the difference between needs and wants. The exercise, sponsored by RHB Banking Group and The Straits Times, aims to build English language vocabulary and promote self-learning. The activity will be distributed to beneficiaries of The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, and will include four special inserts on financial literacy throughout the year.

site_title: 300 Sweep tickets 'thrown away by accident'
summary: A stack of 300 Singapore Sweep tickets, worth $900, was accidentally thrown away by staff on August 6. The tickets were consigned to a retailer and reported missing to the police last week. Despite this, prize claims will be honoured for a winning ticket from the lost stack, with the top prize valued at $2.3 million. Unclaimed prizes will be forfeited and channelled to the Tote Board for worthy causes, unless proven otherwise.

site_title: Woman run over at carpark; driver arrested
summary: A 69-year-old woman, Madam Ying, was killed when a 65-year-old driver allegedly hit her while parking at a carpark in Bukit Panjang, Singapore. The driver panicked, accelerating instead of braking, causing Madam Ying to be run over and killed. The driver was arrested on suspicion of causing death by a negligent act and is believed to be distraught. An investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Skyline Luge's visitor numbers defy gravity
summary: Skyline Luge Sentosa celebrated its 10th anniversary with a record 1.5 million riders in the last financial year, a 120% increase from 10 years ago when it opened with just 191 customers. The attraction's success can be attributed to its ability to appeal to people of all ages, with 4,000 visitors per day. The company has achieved 20% annual revenue growth, with recent upgrades including ticket and photo counters and LED lights. A new program aims to teach students science concepts through the attraction.

images.alt_text: The Skyline Luge Sentosa's success has been attributed to its ability to appeal to people of all ages. About 4,000 people ride its toboggans (right) each day.

site_title: Elections Dept sets out rules for civic, professional, business groups
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) of Singapore has set out rules for civic, professional, and business groups participating in political activities before the polls. These groups must ensure their activities align with their Constitutions and not influence votes. They can discuss candidate merits among members but must not impact voting decisions. Foreigners are banned from election activities, and groups must obtain written authorisation from candidates or election agents to promote or procure election. The ELD has also released guidelines and an e-booklet with information on Nomination Day proceedings and ballot paper details.

site_title: Jail for filming two women in shower
summary: A Singaporean business consultant, Low Tian Sheng, was jailed nine weeks for secretly filming two female guests showering in his home. He hid a Blackberry smartphone in a toilet, recording the victims for nearly 30 minutes. Low, 33, had previously committed similar offenses in 2011. His actions were deemed an intrusion into the women's privacy, and he was given a reduced sentence due to prior offenses. The incident highlights the importance of respecting individuals' right to privacy.

site_title: Ability to see many perspectives
summary: Henry Kwek, 39, is a candidate for Nee Soon GRC. With a background in economics and management science, he believes Singapore is at a crossroads, facing both opportunities and challenges. Kwek aims to address these issues, focusing on cost-cutting measures and motorcycle costs, particularly for average motorcycles used by many Singaporeans. He emphasizes the need for future generations to come forward and serve the society, citing his diverse experience in public and private sectors, as well as grassroots involvement.

site_title: $4 million SMU bursary launched
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU) has launched a $4 million bursary, the Hotel 81-Choo Chong Ngen Bursary, to help needy students pay tuition fees. The bursary, valued at $5,000 each, was donated by budget hotel magnate Choo Chong Ngen, who matched the Government's $2 million contribution dollar-for-dollar. The bursary aims to support deserving students in achieving their full potential without financial obstacles, with the first 24 recipients announced.

site_title: Negligence suit over girl's death settled out of court
summary: The parents of 10-year-old Leela Ruba Kamalakannan have settled a negligence suit against the National Skin Centre, Healthway Medical Corporation, and two doctors, agreeing to confidential settlement terms after her death from alleged negligent treatment in 2011. Leela died from a brain bleed after being treated for a skin rash, sparking a lawsuit over whether a timely blood test could have detected the condition earlier. The parties denied negligence, but the settlement will include a "no admission of liability" clause, allowing them to avoid admitting fault.

site_title: Independents turn up at Elections Department
summary: Seven independent candidates, including former SDP and SDA members, have registered for the Sept 11 election, potentially disrupting opposition party plans for straight fights with the People's Action Party (PAP). However, experts say independent candidates are unlikely to have a significant impact, as opposition voters tend to avoid splitting their vote and independents typically need to be well-known leaders in their sectors. The last time independents contested a general election was in 2001, and they have historically struggled to win seats since the PAP came into power in 1965.

images.alt_text: Among the potential independents at the Elections Department yesterday were (from top): Mr Arthero Lim; former SDP member Jarrod Luo (centre) and lawyer and independent candidate Tan Lam Siong (centre in black shirt).

site_title: She baldly goes public with disease
summary: Chan See Ting, 23, publicly shared her struggle with alopecia areata, an autoimmune disease causing hair loss, on Facebook. The post, which garnered over 8,000 shares, sparked a potential first support group for the condition in Singapore. Nine others have responded, and they plan to meet up to discuss their experiences. The disease, which affects 147 million worldwide, is unpredictable and cyclical, with no cure but treatment options available. Chan's openness has brought comfort to over 100 strangers and fellow sufferers, who have reached out to her for support.

images.alt_text: Ms Chan See Ting used to have a full head of hair (above), but in 2013 was diagnosed with alopecia areata, an autoimmune disease that attacks the body's hair follicles, The disease left her bald (left).

site_title: Projects of the Govt ' likely to go on as planned'
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) candidates are likely to see their constituency projects come to fruition, regardless of the outcome of the September 2015 general election. Law and Foreign Minister K.Shanmugam stated that some projects are government-led, while others depend on the town council and individual MPs. The outcome of these projects will depend on the working relationship between agencies and MPs. If the PAP is not elected, it is up to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to decide whether the candidates will stay on to push their plans.

site_title: 300 gain entry to early childhood courses before exams
summary: More than 300 students, about half of 600 O-level applicants, have secured places in early childhood courses at Ngee Ann and Temasek polytechnics through the discretionary admission (DPA) scheme. This is the highest number since 2007. The offers come amid efforts to attract and retain pre-school teachers with better pay and training incentives, with each student receiving an ECDA training award of up to $40,000. Senior Minister of State for Education Indranee Rajah says the growing interest is "heartening" given the sector's shortage of teachers.

images.alt_text: Ngee Ann Polytechnic Child Psychology and Early Education student Eden Yeong, 19, playing a game of word dice with children at the MOE Kindergarten at Dazhong Primary.

site_title: Adding diversity to team
summary: Singapore's People's Action Party (PAP) has announced its candidate for Nee Soon GRC: Louis Ng, 37, the chief executive of Animal Concerns Research and Education Society (Acres). Ng, a biologist and conservationist, aims to bring diversity to the team and champion animal welfare, while also promoting volunteerism and supporting families. He plans to focus on issues such as increasing support for families with children and implementing measures to encourage volunteerism. Ng's wife, who works part-time at Acres, and their 18-month-old daughter are also mentioned as part of his family.

site_title: 'Most feel Govt has got major social policies right'
summary: Singaporean voters believe the government has implemented major social and economic policies correctly since 2007, despite acknowledging that local factors may influence election results. Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that the government's shift to the left in social policies was not a knee-jerk reaction, but rather a response to impending social and demographic changes. The PAP aims to win back the "protest vote" by addressing economic concerns, while also highlighting the government's track record in managing town councils, such as the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council.

site_title: Children 'should enjoy the learning process'
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) candidate Jaslyn Go Hui Leng, a 43-year-old sales director, has expressed her commitment to education policies, emphasizing the need to reduce stress and make learning enjoyable for children. Born into a low-income family, Go credits her own hard work and determination to succeed, and now seeks to address issues affecting her children and the younger generation, including overemphasis on paper qualifications and the need to amend immigration policies.

site_title: Strong support for Edwin Tong in Joo Chiat
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin have pledged to support PAP candidate Edwin Tong in Joo Chiat ward, a constituency he was unexpectedly moved to from Jalan Besar. Tong has expressed excitement to work with the Marine Parade team and has promised to address local issues such as estate improvement and congestion. The PAP team expects a tough fight in the upcoming polls on September 11, but is confident in their support for Tong.

site_title: RP revives interest in Pioneer ward
summary: The Reform Party (RP) is considering fielding a candidate in Singapore's Pioneer ward, a single-seat constituency, if the National Solidarity Party (NSP) withdraws or fails to field a strong candidate. RP chief Kenneth Jeyaretnam stated that the party made efforts to contact NSP leaders, but was unsuccessful, and is now declaring its interest publicly. The RP had previously agreed to withdraw from Pioneer due to speculation that NSP would contest the ward, but now sees an opportunity to fill a potential gap.

summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) candidate Paul Ananth Tambyah, a medical professor, is seeking to represent the people's concerns in Parliament. Tambyah believes that healthcare is a basic human right, not a commodity to be traded, and will focus on this issue, as well as education, population policy, and housing. He is motivated by the struggles of ordinary Singaporeans, including the stress of childcare costs and overcrowding due to uncontrolled immigration. Tambyah aims to be the SDP's voice in Parliament to address these pressing concerns.

summary: Seven opposition parties in Singapore, excluding the Workers' Party and Singapore People's Party, launched a "Vote for Change" campaign badge to signal their unity ahead of the September 11 General Election. The badge, inspired by US President Barack Obama's 2008 campaign slogan, was unveiled at a rally and will be sold for $5 each to raise funds. The parties aim to move past internal disagreements and focus on policy views, with the badge serving as a symbol of unity among opposition forces.

site_title: GE2015: Party big guns draw battle lines for coming polls
summary: Singapore's General Election is set for September 11, with key politicians drawing battle lines ahead of the polls. The People's Action Party (PAP) has introduced its slate in challenging constituencies, while the Workers' Party (WP) has unveiled its election slogan and candidates, including academics Daniel Goh and Paul Tambyah. Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong has asked voters for a "strong mandate" for Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, accusing the WP of arrogance. The WP aims to consolidate its 2011 breakthrough and become a sustained opposition bloc in Parliament.

site_title: $3b plan to help seniors live more fulfilling lives
summary: Singapore unveils a $3 billion, five-year plan to support seniors' active ageing, aiming to help them live more fulfilling lives. The Action Plan for Successful Ageing includes senior centres, daycare services, and free perks for those aged 60 and over. The plan also allocates up to $200 million for ageing-related research and aims to reach 400,000 seniors by 2030. The initiative includes active ageing hubs, elderly-friendly public transport, and therapeutic gardens, marking a shift from focusing on problems to possibilities for the elderly.

site_title: Imagine being a ticking time bomb
summary: A new art show, "Take Me Places," at the Singapore Art Museum aims to raise awareness about life with chronic illnesses. The project, "Project Dreamcatchers," pairs professional artists with young people living with chronic conditions, resulting in five installations by four artists and 19 patients. The art pieces convey the strain of daily life with conditions like congenital heart disease and kidney failure. The exhibition, which opened on July 31, features works that highlight the resilience and struggles of those with chronic illnesses, providing a unique perspective on their experiences.

site_title: Quick acting tour leader treats man for altitude sickness
summary: A tour leader in Tibet, John Tan, 50, saved a 53-year-old man, Richard Nai, from altitude sickness by providing oxygen and tending to him until he recovered. Nai, who had severe symptoms including hallucinations, was rescued after his tour leader measured his blood oxygen level and administered oxygen from oxygen tubes in the cabin. Nai's wife was also calmed down by Tan, who continued to care for him throughout his recovery. The incident has earned Tan praise from Nai, who has commended Tan for his care and prompt intervention, and has also received recognition from his employer, Chan Brothers Travel.

images.alt_text: Mr Richard Nai (wearing spectacles), 53, wants people to know how tour leader John Tan (in blue shirt), 50, went out of his way to nurse him back to health during a trip to Tibet in May when he fell seriously ill with altitude sickness.

site_title: Shutters soon at Shashlik
summary: Shashlik, a Russian restaurant in Singapore, will close at the end of the year when its lease runs out due to slow business and stiff competition. The restaurant, which has been in operation since 1986, has seen a decline in staff and turnover over the years. Despite introducing innovative technologies such as the iPad system to streamline orders, the business has struggled to stay afloat. The existing staff, many of whom are nearing retirement age, have decided to call it a day, with some expressing hope that the restaurant will be taken over by new owners.

site_title: Two American soldiers killed in Afghan 'insider attack'
summary: Two US service members were killed in an insider attack in Helmand province, Afghanistan, on Wednesday, marking the first such incident since Mullah Akhtar Mansour's ascension as Taliban leader. The attack occurred at an Afghan security forces compound, and both attackers were killed by the US troops. The incident coincided with the fall of the strategic district of Musa Qala to Taliban insurgents, raising concerns about the security situation in the volatile province.

site_title: Credit to opposition? It's just a rooster's boast: ESM Goh
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong countered opposition claims that having more alternative voices in Parliament after the 2011 General Election led to the Government adopting more redistributive and inclusive policy measures. He likened the opposition's views to a rooster's boast, saying that policies change over time to adapt to new situations and meet changing needs. Goh also defended the PAP Government's integrity, pointing to its own checks and balances, and questioned the opposition's motives, suggesting they prioritize plunder over the people's welfare.

summary: Singapore's Workers' Party has unveiled its first candidate for the 2015 General Election, 30-year-old engineer Redzwan Hafidz Abdul Razak. A Malay-Muslim, he aims to improve the living standard and education level of his community. Razak, who holds a Master's degree from the University of Warwick, believes in offering alternatives to the government and promoting political competition to scrutinize Bills before they are passed. He will focus on issues like transparency in housing costs and education, reflecting his party's manifesto, which has not yet been released.

site_title: Foreigner who made inflammatory remarks convicted
summary: A 29-year-old Filipino, Ed Mundsel Bello Ello, was convicted of promoting feelings of ill-will and hostility for making inflammatory comments about Singaporeans on his Facebook page. He pleaded guilty to one charge under the Sedition Act and admitted to two counts of providing false information to police. Ello's remarks, which included labelling Singaporeans as "loosers" and praying for disasters to strike the country, were deemed "xenophobic, derogatory and highly inflammatory" by the prosecution. A sentence of 20 weeks in jail is being sought.

site_title: 9/11 'dust lady' Marcy Borders dies of cancer at 42
summary: Marcy Borders, known as the "dust lady" of the 9/11 attacks, died at 42 after suffering from stomach cancer. A mother of two, she became a symbol of the tragedy after a photo showed her covered in dust while escaping the World Trade Center. Borders blamed her cancer on inhaling dust during the attack and suffered from depression, addiction, and anxiety in later years. Despite struggling with health issues, she regained custody of her children and became sober after a rehab stint. Her death highlights the ongoing health struggles of those affected by the 9/11 attacks.

site_title: Football: Rooney treble seals Champions League return for Manchester United
summary: Manchester United has qualified for the Champions League group phase after defeating Club Brugge 4-0 in the play-off final. Wayne Rooney scored a hat-trick, his first in Europe since 2004, to seal the win and end a 10-game goal-scoring drought. The victory marked United's return to the tournament after a 19-year absence. Rooney's performances, combined with Ander Herrera's goal, gave Louis van Gaal's side a 7-1 aggregate win over Club Brugge, securing their spot in the Champions League group stage.

site_title: Cost of living a key focus
summary: Dylan Ng Foo Eng, a 40-year-old head of wealth management at RHB Bank, has joined the Workers' Party as a candidate for the 2015 General Election. Ng, who comes from a humble family, has expressed a focus on cost of living and population issues, which he believes affect the average Singaporean. He aims to serve the community and engage in policymaking to impact many lives. With a background in economics and private banking, Ng seeks to bring a unique perspective to politics, and Labrador Park is his favourite spot in Singapore.

site_title: After the misspelling gaffe
summary: A recent incident involving a prominent news organization has raised concerns about the importance of proofreading and editing. The mistake, a simple misspelling, was made public after it was shared on social media. The incident highlights the need for thorough review and fact-checking processes to ensure accuracy and credibility in journalism. As a result, the organization has emphasized the importance of attention to detail and the value of having multiple pairs of eyes review content before publication. The incident serves as a reminder of the significance of quality control in maintaining the integrity of news reporting.

site_title: Cheating 19 Kids reality TV star Josh Duggar enters rehab
summary: Former reality TV star Josh Duggar, 27, has entered rehab after admitting to cheating on his wife and being addicted to porn. His admission came after his name was leaked from the hacked Ashley Madison adultery website. Duggar's parents, Jim Bob and Michelle, expressed their grief and prayed for his complete repentance and sincere change. This follows another scandal, in which Duggar admitted to sexually abusing four of his sisters as a teenager. He has resigned from his job at Family Research Council and his reality show "19 Kids And Counting" was cancelled last month.

The government has been targeting volatility in the market, with a recent rescue package including a crackdown on short-selling and state-backed buying of shares. A journalist, Wang Xiaolu, has been accused of spreading false information, while eight Citic Securities employees are suspected of illegal trading. Authorities have also restricted 164 clients from opening positions due to "abnormal trades". The crackdown is part of the government's efforts to stabilize the market.

site_title: Smaller of two newborn pandas at Smithsonian's National Zoo in US dies
summary: The smaller of two newborn giant panda cubs at the Smithsonian's National Zoo in the US died on August 26, despite efforts by zoo staff to care for it. The cub, less than four days old, was treated with antibiotics and bottle-fed, but ultimately succumbed to its condition. The larger cub, which appears healthy and robust, is being cared for by its mother Mei Xiang. This is the third set of panda twins born in the US to have lost one sibling, with only one set previously surviving.

site_title: Colorado movie gunman sentenced to 12 lifetimes and 3,318 years
summary: Colorado movie gunman James Holmes was sentenced to 12 life sentences and 3,318 years in prison with no chance of parole for his role in a 2012 movie theater massacre that killed 12 and injured 70. Judge Carlos Samour condemned Holmes, calling his actions "evil" and stating that mental illness and morality are not mutually exclusive. The sentence was the maximum the judge could issue, and survivors and relatives of the victims applauded the decision, with some expressing disappointment that Holmes was not sentenced to death.

site_title: Windows 10 spreads to more than 75 million devices
summary: Microsoft's Windows 10 operating system has spread to over 75 million devices since its release on July 29, with more than 90,000 different computer and tablet models powered by the software. The system is being offered as a free upgrade for most devices, allowing for voice, pen, and gesture input, and biometric identification for improved security. The success of Windows 10 marks a significant milestone for the company, as it aims to gain traction in the mobile sector and emerging technologies for computing.

site_title: Some 50 migrants found dead in boat off Libya: Italy coast guard
summary: Italian coast guard rescued 430 migrants from a boat off Libya, but found 50 bodies in the hold. The migrants, mainly from Africa and the Middle East, were on a small boat that was never designed to cross the Mediterranean. This year, over 100,000 migrants have reached Italy, with at least 2,300 believed to have died during the crossing. The incident highlights the dangers of the perilous Mediterranean sea route, with thousands attempting to reach Europe in small, overcrowded boats.

site_title: Governments must do 'much more' to end migrant crisis: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged governments to show compassion and take action to end the migrant crisis, stating that hundreds of thousands of migrants and refugees face perilous journeys and encounter new challenges upon arrival. He called on European and other governments to prove their compassion and do "much more" to address the crisis, which he described as the largest displacement of people since World War II. Ban emphasized the need to save lives, fight against trafficking and discrimination, and defend human rights.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic becomes Unicef goodwill ambassador
summary: Novak Djokovic, the reigning world tennis champion, has become a goodwill ambassador for the UN Fund for Children (Unicef). The 28-year-old Serbian has already worked to help vulnerable children through his role as Unicef Serbia ambassador and his Novak Djokovic Foundation. Djokovic, who grew up during the Balkans war, aims to defend and uphold children's rights and provide access to early childhood care and development for every girl and boy. He joins a roster of athletes and celebrities, including David Beckham and Serena Williams, in promoting Unicef's mission.

site_title: Fed's Dudley says decision on September liftoff less compelling
summary: US Federal Reserve's New York President William Dudley stated that a September interest rate hike is "less compelling" amid recent global stock market sell-off. The slowdown in China's economy has raised concerns about a slower global growth rate and reduced demand for the US economy, making a rate hike less necessary. Dudley emphasized that the Fed is concerned about the future economic outlook, not just current performance, and that international developments can impact the economic outlook.

site_title: Tennis: McEnroe vs Williams would be a huge payday but could hurt both their reputations
summary: Tennis legend John McEnroe has expressed confidence in his ability to beat Serena Williams, but a potential match between the two would not be good for their legacies. The contest would be more commercial than meaningful, and would not define their records. Historically, asymmetrical matches have had an appeal, but in modern women's tennis, such a contest would not have broad significance. Williams' focus is on the US Open and a potential calendar Grand Slam, and she has not responded to McEnroe's challenge.

site_title: Muslims not doing 'enough' to fight ISIS: Jordan's Queen Rania
summary: Queen Rania of Jordan stated that moderate Muslims are not doing enough to fight against ISIS ideology. She emphasized the importance of helping the Middle East's youth, who are often unemployed or forced to flee their countries, to prevent them from joining extremist groups. Rania called for education, opportunities, and a sense of purpose to counter the "diabolical ideology" of ISIS, warning that failure to act would lead to devastating consequences for the region.

site_title: GE2015: NSP President Sebastian Teo denounces mud-slinging, writes post to 'set the record straight'
summary: National Solidarity Party (NSP) president Sebastian Teo denounced "mud-slinging tactics" against him and his party, which he said aimed to discredit him and his party. The NSP was hit by a crisis after the resignations of two central executive council members and revelations about Teo's 1970s corruption conviction. Teo, 68, explained the circumstances behind the conviction, stating he pleaded guilty due to professional advice and has since "constantly improved" himself. He reiterated his commitment to contesting 12 seats, including MacPherson, and appealed to Singaporeans to look beyond his past.

site_title: Suspect in Virginia TV shooting had history of workplace issues
summary: A 41-year-old former journalist, Vester Flanagan, shot and killed two TV journalists, Alison Parker and Vicki Gardner, during a live broadcast in Virginia. Flanagan, who went by the name Bryce Williams, had a history of workplace issues and had previously filed a lawsuit against a Florida station alleging discrimination due to his black background. Perceived racism may have been a factor, with social media posts suggesting this was the motive. Flanagan had a 20-year journalism career, but was known for being difficult to work with and had been terminated from WDBJ7 in 2013.
