site_title: STI closes 13 points down, shares swing between positive and negative territory
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed down 13.29 points or 0.43% to 2,873 after a volatile trading session. The benchmark index sank as much as 1.3% during the day due to a weak lead from Wall Street and concerns over US rate hikes. Despite a surprise interest rate cut by the Chinese central bank, markets remain cautious, with analysts viewing the move as a "band-aid solution." The STI is still in a downtrend, with some analysts predicting a potential September rate hike.

site_title: U.S. stocks surge in opening trade, Dow up 2%
summary: US stocks surged in opening trade on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 2% at 15,985.73. The S&P 500 rose 2.09% to 1,906.70, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 2.35% to 4,612.30. The gains came after a six-day losing streak, with global markets mixed. The Shanghai index fell 1.27% despite Chinese central bank monetary stimulus. Oil prices remain near six and a half year lows, with Schlumberger's $14.8 billion acquisition of Cameron fueling energy sector optimism.

site_title: Swimming: Australia lead medal table at Fina World Junior Championships
summary: Australia leads the medal table at the Fina World Junior Championships with four gold medals, ahead of the United States with three and Russia with two. Australia's Minna Atherton won the women's 100m backstroke in a world junior record time, while Clyde Lewis secured the 200m individual medley gold. The United States added golds in the men's 200m freestyle and women's 800m free, while Russia claimed golds in the men's 100m breaststroke and mixed 4x100m medley relay.

site_title: South Sudan president signs peace deal, with reservations
summary: South Sudan President Salva Kiir signed a peace accord to end 20 months of civil war, but expressed "serious reservations" about the deal. The agreement aims to bring an end to the conflict, but Kiir warned that ignoring these reservations could jeopardize the peace. The signing ceremony was attended by regional leaders, diplomats, and journalists. The accord's long-term viability remains uncertain due to Kiir's reservations.

site_title: Charity walk: Great Eastern staff raise $28,000
summary: About 300 Great Eastern staff participated in a charity walk from their office to Marina Bay and back, raising $28,000 for charity. Ten senior management team members, including CEO Khoo Kah Siang, donned tutu skirts to support the event. The walk was part of the 10th Great Eastern Women's Run, where staff will also participate in a run. The charity walk aims to involve male staff in the fundraising efforts, as they are not eligible to participate in the women's run. The event raised a significant amount for charity.

site_title: Maritime sector lauded for green practices at annual awards
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) of Singapore won two of three titles given to the maritime sector at the annual Singapore Environmental Achievement Award. MPA received the Outstanding Singapore Environmental Achievement Award and the public sector category title. The industry also recognized Orient Overseas Container Line for its regional award. The awards highlighted green practices in the maritime sector, including energy-efficient lighting, solar panels, and fuel-saving initiatives. MPA's sustainability office drives programs such as the Maritime Singapore Green Initiative, encouraging eco-friendly ship designs and technologies.

site_title: Obama, Japan's Abe discussed quickly concluding trade deal: White House
summary: US President Barack Obama and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe discussed their commitment to concluding the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement as soon as possible in a phone call. The White House stated that Obama emphasized US "intelligence collection is focused on national security interests and is as narrowly tailored as possible." No specific timeline was mentioned, but both leaders expressed their commitment to the agreement's completion.

site_title: Athletics: Shanti Pereira fails to make the cut for 200m at World Championships
summary: Singaporean athlete Shanti Pereira failed to qualify for the women's 200m semi-finals at the IAAF World Championships in Beijing, finishing last in Heat Five with a time of 24.22 seconds. This falls short of her personal best of 23.60 seconds, set when she won gold at the SEA Games in June. Pereira competed for the first time since the biennial Games, running alongside Olympic champion Veronica Campbell-Brown, who won the heat in 22.79 seconds.

site_title: 2 US journalists shot dead on live TV; dead suspect was 'angered by discrimination'
summary: Two US journalists, Alison Parker, 24, and Adam Ward, 27, were fatally shot during a live TV interview in Virginia on August 26, 2015. Vester Lee Flanagan, a 41-year-old former employee of the TV station, allegedly carried out the attack due to perceived racial discrimination and anger over his own experiences. Flanagan, who had a history of discrimination claims, shot himself after police pursued him on a highway, and later died at a hospital. The incident was widely condemned, with the White House describing it as another example of gun violence.

site_title: Needy students can tap on $4m SMU bursary thanks to Hotel 81 boss's $2m donation
summary: Singapore Management University (SMU) launched a $4 million bursary for needy students, with Hotel 81 founder Choo Chong Ngen donating $2 million. The bursary will provide $5,000 to 24 students, with the government matching the donation dollar-for-dollar. Choo, who did not attend university himself, aims to create a level playing field for disadvantaged students, with his daughter Carolyn, an SMU alumnus, encouraging his philanthropy. This is the largest single bursary contribution to SMU from a single donor.

site_title: Merkel vows no tolerance for migrant hate as 40 die in Mediterranean
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel has vowed zero tolerance for anti-migrant hate as 40 migrants died in a Mediterranean boat tragedy off the Libyan coast. Merkel faced hecklers at a migrant shelter in eastern Germany, but reaffirmed her commitment to caring for refugees. The UN chief, Ban Ki-moon, has called for European countries to show compassion and do more to address the crisis, which has seen 2,370 people drown in the Mediterranean since 2015. The EU is struggling to find a coherent response to the crisis, with Hungary building a razor-wire barrier and other countries considering troop deployments.

site_title: Angry Birds maker Rovio sees lower earnings and plans 37% job cull
summary: Rovio, the maker of Angry Birds, has forecast a drop in earnings this year and plans to cut 37% of its workforce, approximately 260 jobs. The company attributed lower-than-expected sales and a decline in operating profit. Rovio aims to focus on core businesses, such as games, media, and consumer products, and plans to divest a preschool unit. The company's CEO, Pekka Rantala, stated that "fundamental changes" are needed to ensure Rovio's success, with the goal of becoming the leading entertainment company with mobile games at its heart.

site_title: The Straits Times' News In A Minute: Aug 26, 2015
summary: Key news headlines include opposition party representatives and independent candidates collecting nomination forms, a Filipino assistant nurse being charged with insulting Singaporeans, and the Malaysian ringgit plummeting to new lows below 3.05 to the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Two injured in fire at Teck Whye, block suffers power outage
summary: A fire broke out on the 10th floor of Block 3 Teck Whye Avenue in Singapore, injuring a 50-year-old man and an eight-month-old baby. The baby suffered suspected smoke inhalation and was sent to the National University Hospital, while the man had cuts from falling debris. The fire started in the master bedroom and was extinguished within 30 minutes. About 20 residents evacuated the building, and the block suffered a power outage following the incident.

site_title: Literature teaches analytical skills relevant for life
summary: A recent trend shows a decline in students taking literature as an O-level subject, with many viewing it as difficult and lacking practical value. However, a student shares a personal experience, highlighting the benefits of studying literature, including developing analytical skills, critical thinking, and the ability to articulate opinions coherently. Literature, the student argues, teaches valuable life skills such as evaluating situations, embracing ambiguity, and appreciating different perspectives, making it a necessary subject for today's youth.

site_title: 69-year-old driver arrested after hitting and killing 65-year-old woman while parking
summary: A 69-year-old driver was arrested after hitting and killing a 65-year-old woman while parking her car in Singapore. The victim, who had just finished shopping, was walking home through an open-air carpark when the driver mistakenly stepped on the accelerator instead of the brakes. The victim was pronounced dead on the spot. The driver was arrested for causing death by a negligent act, with investigations ongoing.

site_title: Team Singapore athletes rewarded with cash prizes for SEA Games achievements
summary: Singapore's Team athletes, led by swimmers Joseph Schooling and Quah Zheng Wen, were rewarded with cash prizes for their SEA Games achievements. The Multi-Million Dollar Awards Programme awarded swimmers Schooling ($31,250) and Quah ($31,250) for their gold medals, while Tao Li ($23,750), Quah Ting Wen and Amanda Lim ($21,250 each), and table tennis player Gao Ning ($20,500) also received awards. Team Singapore clinched 84 golds, 73 silvers, and 102 bronzes at the Games.

site_title: A society needs literature to have a 'soul'
summary: A decline in literature enrollment in Singaporean schools is a worrying trend, with fewer students taking the subject and parents perceiving it as lacking practical relevance. The importance of literature in shaping society, culture, and individual perspectives cannot be overstated, as it mirrors and reflects human experience. A lack of literature study may lead to ignorance and stereotyping, hindering social progress and cultural diversity. The government's emphasis on creativity and innovation requires a proactive approach to fostering literature education, lest Singapore loses its cultural identity and "soul".

site_title: China work safety chief sacked as blasts death toll rises in Tianjin
summary: China's work safety chief, Yang Dongliang, has been sacked amid the country's ongoing investigation into a deadly chemical explosion in Tianjin that killed 139 and injured hundreds. Yang, 61, was removed for "suspected severe violation of discipline and the law," a euphemism for corruption. The blast occurred two weeks ago at a storage facility in Tianjin, and the death toll has risen despite ongoing investigations into possible government collusion and lax safety regulations. A rigorous investigation has been vowed by the State Council.

site_title: Have separate queue for premium taxis at airport
summary: At Changi Airport Terminal 3, a slow-moving queue of premium taxis occupied 60% of taxi boarding bays, causing normal-priced taxis to wait. This resulted in passengers waiting for extended periods. To address the issue, it is suggested to limit premium taxis to 20% of bays or set up a separate queue for premium taxis. This would enable taxi coordinators to manage demand and occupancy rates, allowing for more efficient use of the taxi bays.

site_title: Tan Chong International reports H1 net profit of $31.2 million
summary: Tan Chong International reported a net profit of HK$172.3 million (S$31.2 million) for the six months to June 30, up from HK$153.2 million a year ago. Revenue grew to HK$7.2 billion, driven by the consolidation of unit Zero and strong sales growth in its passenger vehicle retail and distribution operations. Earnings per share increased to 8.6 HK cents, up from 7.6 HK cents a year ago. The company also declared an interim dividend of 2.5 HK cents.

site_title: Overcharging on ez-link card a cause for concern
summary: A Singaporean passenger reported being overcharged on his ez-link card for bus service 43 on June 1. The issue was confirmed by MRT station officers, but the passenger was advised to contact SBS Transit for a refund. Despite submitting a complaint, the passenger has yet to receive a response. The ez-link card's automated system should prevent fare changes, raising concerns about frequent overcharging incidents that may go unnoticed. The passenger urges the Land Transport Authority and SBS Transit to investigate the matter seriously.

site_title: Japan lawyers join opposition to controversial security bills
summary: Japan's national bar association has joined the opposition to security bills that could allow Japanese troops to engage in combat for the first time since World War II. Hundreds of lawyers, academics, and citizens groups held a Tokyo rally calling for the government to scrap the legislation, citing concerns it would violate the country's pacifist constitution. The bills, which have passed the lower house, aim to give Japan's Self-Defence Forces the option to protect allies without a direct threat to Japan, and are deeply unpopular among the public. The opposition is described as "unprecedented" by the JFBA chairman.

site_title: UK banker bonuses falls to 13,100 pounds on average, still 8 times other workers
summary: UK bankers' average bonuses fell to 13,100 pounds in 2014/15, down 6% from the previous year, as European rules cap bonuses and shift pay to fixed salaries and shares. Total finance industry bonus payments decreased by 10% to 13.6 billion pounds, while payouts in the rest of the economy rose 10% to 28.8 billion pounds. The finance industry now accounts for 8 times the average pay across all industries.

summary: Asian shares closed mixed on Wednesday after China's interest rate cut, with Tokyo surging 3.20% and Seoul rising 2.57%, while Shanghai fell 1.27% and Hong Kong lost 1.52%. Despite the rate cut, investors remain cautious, with concerns over China's economic growth rate and the need for further policy support. The dollar edged up in Tokyo, while oil prices gained ahead of the latest US energy report.

site_title: Five plunge into sinkhole at bus stop in China
summary: A sinkhole at a bus stop in Heilongjiang province, China, swallowed five people on August 22, 2015. Security camera footage shows the ground breaking apart, with four falling into the hole and one clinging to a metal bar. All five were rescued with the aid of bystanders, with four hospitalized for minor injuries. The cause of the incident is under investigation, amid concerns about general and industrial safety standards in China following recent incidents.

site_title: Italian painting damaged in Taiwan could be a fake: Expert
summary: A centuries-old Italian painting by Paolo Porpora, valued at $1.5 million, was damaged in Taiwan after a 12-year-old boy tripped and punched a hole in it. The incident raised doubts over the painting's authenticity, with some experts suggesting it may be a fake. The painting's similarity to a 17th-century piece by Mario Nuzzi has sparked suspicions, with experts questioning the painting's provenance and exposure to environmental factors. The incident has raised questions about the artwork's legitimacy and the exhibition's handling of the piece.

site_title: Postpone repainting of buildings to save water
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) is considering postponing the repainting of buildings in Singapore to conserve water, given the current low water levels in the Johor river. Currently, buildings must be repainted every five years, but owners can request an extension if needed. By deferring repainting, the BCA believes it can save water and eliminate the need for owners to write in for an extension, producing immediate results. This move aims to conserve water amid a dry spell and high costs of producing water through desalination plants.

summary: AC Milan striker Mario Balotelli will have a "good behaviour" clause inserted into his contract, which includes restrictions on extravagant hairstyles, clothing, smoking, and night club visits. The clause is based on Italian air force regulations and aims to promote a healthy lifestyle. Balotelli, who previously had a tumultuous spell at the club, must also limit his drinking and adhere to a regular training schedule. The move is seen as an effort to manage his behavior and improve his work rate after a disappointing season at Liverpool.

site_title: Maersk seeks to shut three small oilfields in UK North Sea
summary: Maersk Oil plans to seek regulatory permission to shut its Janice installation in the UK North Sea, producing 7,000 barrels per day, due to falling oil prices. The shutdown could affect 200 jobs and be implemented in the second quarter of 2016. Maersk Oil is also considering a shift to a "three weeks on, three weeks off" offshore rotation. The move is part of the company's review of operations in response to the volatile oil market, which has seen prices drop by more than half from year-ago levels.

site_title: Foreign countries view Malaysia as anti-corruption role model: Anti-graft agency
summary: Malaysia is viewed as a model for anti-corruption efforts by foreign countries, including developed nations, according to Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission deputy commissioner Datuk Mustafar Ali. The country's 14 special courts and "name-and-shame" database for convicted corrupt individuals have been adopted by other countries as best practices. The 16th International Anti-Corruption Conference, hosted by MACC, will bring together about 1,000 participants to discuss anti-corruption efforts, with a focus on "Ending Impunity: People, Integrity, Action".

site_title: Hungary migrant crisis escalates as police fire teargas
summary: Hungary's migrant crisis escalated as police fired teargas at its main processing centre, dispersing around 200 migrants who refused to be fingerprinted. The government announced deploying 2,000 "border hunters" to stem the flow of record numbers of migrants entering from Serbia. Over 2,500 people, mostly from Syria, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, crossed Hungary's southern border on Tuesday, with 500 children among them. The crisis has led to a summit of western Balkans leaders to address the issue, with Hungary's right-wing government attempting to stem the flow by erecting a barrier and deploying police reinforcements.

site_title: Reform Party stakes claim on Pioneer SMC, wants to contest seat if NSP pulls out
summary: The Reform Party has expressed interest in contesting the Pioneer Single Member Constituency (SMC) seat, with secretary-general Kenneth Jeyaretnam stating the party will field a candidate if the National Solidarity Party (NSP) withdraws or cannot field a strong candidate. The NSP had initially agreed to withdraw from the election but has since changed its decision. The Reform Party has downed its groundwork in the constituency and has not ruled out entering a three-cornered fight if necessary. The party urges the NSP to clarify its intentions soon.

site_title: Dyna-Mac secures $12 million contract
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings Ltd has secured a $12 million contract from a Singapore-based multinational corporation for a project in Singapore. The firm will supply and install modular units, structural steel, electrical and instrument works, and other services at its yard in Malaysia. The project's modular units are scheduled to be delivered progressively, with the last unit by May 2016. Dyna-Mac CEO Desmond Lim expressed confidence in delivering the units and meeting the customer's stringent requirements, citing the company's vast experience and proven track record in detailed engineering and construction.

summary: IHH Healthcare reported a 9% rise in fourth-quarter net profit to RM228.1 million, driven by higher turnover across its home markets in Malaysia, Singapore, and Turkey. Revenue jumped 12% to RM2.09 billion, with the group's largest subsidiary, Parkway Pantai, contributing 17% to overall revenue. The company attributed its success to its focus on quality healthcare, operational efficiency, and growth strategies, including the completion of hospital acquisitions in India and the opening of new hospitals in Turkey and Malaysia.

site_title: School sports: Bukit Panjang fight back to claim C Division boys' volleyball title
summary: Bukit Panjang Government High School defeated Presbyterian High School in the C Division boys' volleyball final, coming back from the brink of defeat to win 25-14, 20-25, 25-16, 13-25, 17-15. This marked Bukit Panjang's fourth C boys' title, their first since 2012. In the girls' division, Ngee Ann Secondary secured their first title since 2007 with a 25-18, 25-17, 25-19 win over Cedar Girls' Secondary.

site_title: Samsung tells 'PenGate' complainers to read the manual first
summary: Samsung acknowledged its Galaxy Note 5 can break if the stylus is inserted backwards into the storage slot, prompting criticism on social media. The company advised users to read the manual, citing the manual's warning about potential misuse of the stylus. Samsung stated that the issue is not a manufacturing defect, but rather user error. The company is counting on the Note 5 to compete with Apple's products, despite falling 1.1% in value after the issue was raised.

site_title: China's yuan reverses fall to close firmer, volumes surge
summary: China's yuan closed slightly stronger against the US dollar at 6.4105 per dollar, reversing earlier declines, with volumes reaching $49 billion, the second-highest since 2013. The People's Bank of China cut the one-year benchmark bank lending rate and reserve requirements, sparking market uncertainty, with some traders believing the central bank may defend the currency's value. Economists predict further depreciation, but note China's strong trade surplus limits significant weakening.

site_title: Student jailed four weeks for upskirt offences at bookstore
summary: A 23-year-old student, Jed Chung Junyi, was jailed for four weeks for taking upskirt videos of women at a bookstore in Singapore. He pleaded guilty to five of 15 charges of insulting modesty and was found with a total of 15 upskirt videos on his devices. The incidents occurred on April 2 and 3 last year, with Chung Junyi targeting women at the Popular bookstore at Compass Point shopping mall. His actions were discovered after a female shopper alerted the store manager, leading to his arrest and sentencing.

site_title: Thai elephant kills keeper, runs off with 3 Chinese tourists on its back
summary: A male elephant in northern Thailand killed its keeper, Karen, and ran off with three Chinese tourists on its back after a ride at a tourist attraction. The incident occurred when the tourists, a family of three, were on the elephant's back. The elephant, not familiar with its new keeper, suddenly turned violent, goring the man to death. The tourists were safely led back to camp once the elephant was calmed down. This incident highlights concerns over the treatment and welfare of domesticated elephants in Thailand's tourist trade.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia to deploy rapid response team to fight soaring piracy
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia are deploying rapid response teams to combat a surge in piracy attacks in the Malacca and Singapore straits, with over 70 ships targeted this year. The attacks, which have increased since 2008, have led to the formation of a joint naval and police patrol in the area. Security experts have welcomed the move, but urged a more proactive approach, calling for a permanent security presence during nighttime hours. The teams will focus on robbery and hijacking incidents, with some members potentially being deployed on merchant ships.

site_title: Condor Heroes stars Michelle Chen and Chen Xiao turn from reel to real lovers
summary: Michelle Chen Yan-hsi and Chen Xiao, who starred as Little Dragon Girl and Yang Guo in the 2014 TV adaptation of Return Of The Condor Heroes, have confirmed to be in a romantic relationship. The pair, who met on the set of the show, were spotted on secret dates and celebrating each other's birthdays in June and July. Their managers confirmed the romance after photos of them together appeared on social media. The 32-year-old Chinese actress and 28-year-old Taiwanese actor have been active in the entertainment industry since 2012 and 2013, respectively.

site_title: Thailand wins guarded praise for destroying ivory stockpile
summary: Thailand destroyed over 1.2 million kilograms of confiscated ivory worth around $3 million, in a move hailed as a milestone in the fight against the illegal ivory trade. The destruction came after a series of public awareness campaigns and new legislation aimed at controlling the possession and trade of ivory. The move is seen as a significant step by Thailand, a top destination for African ivory smuggling, to crack down on the trade. The destruction of ivory is a step forward, but more needs to be done to catch perpetrators and address the root causes of the problem.

The move is expected to boost the toy industry, with NPD Group predicting a 6.2% increase in US retail sales to $19.2 billion. The event will be live-streamed on YouTube and covered on ABC's Good Morning America, with midnight events at stores like Walmart and Target.

Both candidates emphasized the need for reforms in education and healthcare, with Ms Go focusing on reducing stress in the education system and Dr Tambyah advocating for a minimum wage and stricter immigration policies. The SDP will contest five constituencies, including Holland-Bukit Timah and Marsiling-Yew Tee GRCs.

site_title: Nine sets of e-cigarettes and 113 bottles of e-cigarette accessories seized: ICA
summary: Nine sets of e-cigarettes and 113 bottles of e-cigarette accessories were seized at Woodlands Checkpoint in Singapore on August 23, 2015. The items were found in a Malaysian-registered car and are believed to be worth thousands of dollars. The driver and passenger, both 34 and 26 years old, are assisting with the investigation. E-cigarettes are banned in Singapore, and the seized items will be referred to the Health Sciences Authority. The authorities are advising the public not to purchase or bring e-cigarettes into Singapore and to refrain from using them.

site_title: American rockers Imagine Dragons hit Singapore with a lights-and-lasers spectacular
summary: Imagine Dragons performed a high-energy 105-minute show at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, featuring a range of visual effects including lasers, strobe lights, and LED screens. The band, led by frontman Dan Reynolds, delivered a solid 16-song setlist, including hits like "It's Time" and "Demons." Reynolds' charismatic stage presence and genuine connection with the audience were notable highlights, and the band's performance was well-received by the 8,500-strong crowd. The show ended with a display of lights and lasers during the performance of "Radioactive," a fitting climax to the event.

site_title: India, Australia to hold naval drills with eye on China
summary: India and Australia will hold joint naval drills in the Bay of Bengal in September, as they deepen defence ties and counter China's growing presence in the Indian Ocean. The maritime exercises will include anti-submarine warfare and coordinated drills. The move comes after China's submarine visits to Sri Lanka's Colombo port, seen as a "wake-up call" for India to strengthen its naval capabilities. The drills mark a significant step in India-Australia defence cooperation, with similar exercises planned with Japan and the US later this year.

site_title: Man pushes cyclist off her bike in London street
summary: Police in London released helmet camera footage showing a pedestrian pushing a cyclist off her bike in the middle of a London street. The incident occurred on May 1 at Sidney Street in east London, where the pair exchanged words before the man chased the cyclist, shouting insults, and then pushed her off her bike. The cyclist, in her 40s, did not require medical treatment but was visibly upset. The police are seeking help to identify the 40-year-old suspect, who is also believed to be the perpetrator.

site_title: Peruvian penguin taken into custody
summary: A Peruvian Humbolt penguin was taken into custody by local police in the coastal town of Bello Sur after leading a frantic chase through the streets. The penguin, named "Pingui", became disoriented and refused to come quietly, resulting in a stand-off with authorities. Eventually, Pingui was calmed with a bucket of fish and taken to a local penguin sanctuary, where it will be cared for.

site_title: New centre to promote translation and intercultural efforts 	opens
summary: A new arts non-profit organisation, The Select Centre, has opened in Singapore to promote translation and intercultural efforts. Co-founded by former Arts House director William Phuan and Select Books director Tan Dan Feng, the centre aims to develop and raise the capabilities of writers and translators, increase public awareness, and promote an exchange of literature and translation between Singapore and its neighbouring countries. The centre has already organised workshops and planned various activities, including a translation symposium and a translation festival, to be held in the coming year.

site_title: Man jailed for insulting modesty of two women
summary: A Singaporean business consultant, Low Tian Sheng, was jailed for 9 weeks for filming two female guests showering in his toilet without their knowledge. He used a Blackberry phone with a taped-over camera and recording mode, capturing nearly 30 minutes of footage. Low pleaded guilty to two charges of insulting modesty. His defense cited a mental disorder and a distinguished 10-year career, but the judge rejected these claims, stating there was no medical evidence to support them.

site_title: World War II plane discovered in Poland
summary: A World War II Soviet plane, suspected to be an Ilyushin Il-2, has been discovered in a lake in central Poland. The plane and its two-man crew were believed to have been shot down by Germans in 1945, but evidence suggests it may have crashed in 1943. The discovery was made possible by an extreme drought that exposed the wreckage, which was then excavated by a team of explorers and experts. The remains are now being taken to a museum in Wyszogrod for further examination.

site_title: Ex-assistant nurse admits to posting seditious comments and giving false info
summary: A Filipino assistant nurse, Ed Mundsel Bello Ello, 29, was convicted of three charges related to posting seditious comments on Facebook and giving false information to the police. Ello pleaded guilty to publishing anti-Singaporean comments and lying to the police, and faces up to $5,000 fines and three years' jail. His comments, which included vile and derogatory posts, went viral on social media, prompting many to file police reports against him. The court postponed sentencing to September 16.

site_title: Anti-Bersih Reds prepare to 'fight' yellow-shirted Bersih protestors
summary: Anti-Bersih Reds, a group affiliated with Umno, are preparing for a potentially violent protest against the Bersih 4 rally, set for Aug 29-30. The group's leader, Datuk Jamal Yunos, has trained his members to defend themselves with long knives and swords, stating they will only respond to violence from the yellow-shirted Bersih protestors. The group plans to mobilize 30,000 people from 200 NGOs to pressure the government to cancel the rally, which the police have declared "illegal." The event is seen as a counter-protest to Bersih's demands for Prime Minister Najib's resignation.

site_title: Jeb Bush: I support birthright citizenship
summary: US Republican presidential hopeful Jeb Bush defended his use of the term "anchor babies" during a news conference in McAllen, Texas, saying it referred to Asians giving birth to obtain US citizenship. Bush clarified his record on immigration, stating he supports birthright citizenship, and emphasized his own experiences as a married Mexican-American. The 14th Amendment grants citizenship to any child born on US soil, regardless of parentage. Bush aimed to reassure Hispanic voters that his stance on immigration is not anti-immigrant, while also highlighting his own diverse background.

site_title: GE2015: Groups must ensure their Constitution allows for participation in political activity, says Elections Department
summary: The Elections Department in Singapore has issued an advisory to civic, business, and professional groups stating that they must ensure their Constitution allows participation in any form of political activity. This comes after a voluntary welfare organization, Swami Home, was found to have breached its Constitution when hosting a People's Action Party candidate introduction event. The department emphasized that groups must not influence individual voting decisions and individuals must be individually authorized to conduct election activities, with those not Singapore citizens prohibited from participating.

site_title: Baby girl born on German navy ship after migrant rescue
summary: A Somali woman gave birth to a baby girl, named Sophia, on board a German navy ship after being rescued from a migrant boat in the Mediterranean Sea. The 33-year-old mother had traveled for five months from Somalia and was among over 4,000 people saved in the Mediterranean over the past weekend. Sophia weighed 3,000 grams and was declared healthy by medical staff. It was the first birth on board a German navy ship since its founding.

site_title: Singapore junk bond market lacks depth, say money managers
summary: Singapore's junk bond market lacks depth, according to money managers, as evidenced by the muted reaction to a securities probe into China Fishery Group Ltd. The probe has wiped out $600 million from the group's shares and US currency bonds, but the Singapore-dollar notes have barely reacted. Traders and fund managers have raised concerns about the lack of price discovery, liquidity, and the risk of misleading quoted prices, hindering the growth of the market.

site_title: EU ministers to hold talks on Saturday in Paris after train attack
summary: EU interior and transport ministers will hold talks in Paris on Saturday to discuss security measures following last week's foiled train attack. The attack, carried out by a Moroccan gunman, prompted the meeting to review concrete proposals. French Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve stated that the talks aim to address security concerns, following the gunman's charge on Thursday.

site_title: GE2015: 5 key events in the lead-up to Polling Day
summary: A general election has been called, with Polling Day scheduled for September 11. Parliament has been dissolved and the Writ of Election issued by President Tony Tan Keng Yam. Five key events to watch include the election campaign period, debates, party manifestos, and the release of the Election Day timetable. Singaporeans will cast their ballots on September 11, with the outcome determining the country's leadership and direction for the next five years. The election campaign period is expected to run from August 26 to September 11.

site_title: US train passengers could soon face ‘airport-level’ security measures
summary: Amtrak plans to implement "airport-level" security measures on trains ahead of Pope Francis' visit to the US next month. The move comes after a foiled attack on a high-speed rail in France. Amtrak will increase security presence at Northeast Corridor stations, including deploying VIPR teams with bomb-sniffing dogs and agents. Passengers failing to consent to security procedures will be denied access to trains. The measures are expected to enhance security at sensitive targets, including the Northeast Corridor between New York and Washington.

site_title: White House fence jumper fatally shot in Pennsylvania
summary: A man, Curtis Smith, 34, was fatally shot at a Pennsylvania courthouse after allegedly slashing a sheriff's deputy with a knife. Smith, from Coatesville, Pennsylvania, had a prior arrest for climbing the White House fence in March. He entered the courthouse lobby and attacked the deputy, prompting a second deputy to shoot him, resulting in his death. Smith had a history of assault and burglary convictions. The courthouse was evacuated and will remain closed for the day.

site_title: Dizzying, exhilarating display of absurdity and angst through Japanese lenses
summary: Real Reality, a Japanese dance piece by choreographer Mikuni Yanaihara, explores the relationship between the virtual world and physical movement through fast-paced routines against video projections. The performance, part of the SIFA Dance Marathon, features dancers performing repetitive movements that blur the lines between technology and human ability. Meanwhile, Yukio Suzuki's Lay/ered presents a disjointed but logical cacophony of sound and movement, incorporating instruments and everyday objects to create a dystopian world. Both pieces examine universal themes through a Japanese lens, showcasing the country's unique expressionist and avant-garde styles.

site_title: GE2015: Workers' Party unveils first batch of candidates
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) unveiled its first batch of candidates for the 2015 Singapore general election, including associate professor Daniel Goh, engineer Redzwan Hafidz, and wealth manager Dylan Ng. WP chief Low Thia Khiang announced the party's theme of "empower your future" and introduced the candidates, who will contest in 10 constituencies. The party has fielded a record 28 candidates, up from 23 in 2011, and aims to bring fresh faces to Parliament.

site_title: Chinese authorities escalate blame game for stock rout
summary: Chinese authorities have escalated the blame game for the stock market rout, announcing probes into alleged market malpractice and market manipulators. The Shanghai Composite Index has plunged 40% from its peak, wiping out $5 trillion in trading value. Authorities are investigating people connected to the China Securities Regulatory Commission, Citic Securities, and Caijing magazine on suspicion of offenses including insider trading and spreading false information. The probes aim to "purify" the capital markets and hold those responsible accountable.

site_title: South Korea, US say North Korean military easing off war footing
summary: South Korean and US officials announced that North Korea's military is easing its battle-readiness posture after securing a deal allowing them to step back from the brink of an armed clash. The agreement, reached in the border truce village of Panmunjom, saw North Korea shift down from a "semi war state" after South Korea ended propaganda broadcasts across the border. Signs of de-escalation include the re-appearance of North Korea's submarine fleet and the closure of gunports on heavy weapons installations. Both sides have expressed a willingness to hold official talks to discuss issues such as sanctions and improved relations.

Yuen, known for her prominent opera performances, will guide the opera to greater heights with her vast experience and dedication. She plans to organize an Asean Voice Competition, co-present opera works with regional companies, and recruit more singers for the chorus and children's choir. This appointment comes after the general manager stepped down, marking the opera's 25th anniversary.

site_title: Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos' son mulls presidential run
summary: Philippine Senator Ferdinand Marcos Jr., son of late dictator Ferdinand Marcos, has hinted at a possible presidential run in next year's elections, offering his family a chance at a comeback. Marcos, 57, has been discussing "higher office" and has not ruled out running for president or vice-president. Despite poor public opinion surveys, Marcos believes he can still run and has considered joining forces with Vice-President Jejomar Binay. His family's return to politics comes after a successful comeback in the 1990s, with his mother Imelda holding a seat in parliament.

Proceeds from the screenings will go towards the 7 Letters' beneficiaries, supported by the Singapore Film Commission. The 10-member committee, chaired by Economic Planning Minister Abdul Wahid Omar, includes experts such as CIMB head Nazir Razak, who has been critical of 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). The committee aims to develop immediate and medium-term plans to strengthen Malaysia's fundamentals and report directly to Najib.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing shrinks 6.1% in July as output falls for 6th straight month
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 6.1% in July, its sixth consecutive month of decline, exceeding economists' 4% forecast. The biomedical segment suffered the largest drop, with a 13.4% year-on-year contraction. Excluding biomedical, manufacturing output would have fallen 4.1%. The only bright spot was the chemicals cluster, which grew 4.4% due to higher export demand.

summary: The chairman of Bersih, Maria Chin Abdullah, insists the two-day rally will proceed as planned on Saturday despite being declared illegal by authorities. The group has been urging Prime Minister Najib Razak to step down amid a political funding controversy. The High Court previously declared Bersih a lawful society in 2012, and the Bar Council's Human Rights Committee stated that attending a rally is a constitutional right. The police have been urged to focus on potential saboteurs rather than the rally itself.

The company aims to promote world peace and end the rivalry between the two burger chains for a day. site_title: Man charged with slashing domestic worker with penknife
summary: An Indian national, Palaiyan Murugadass, 41, has been charged in court with causing grievous hurt to a Filipino domestic worker, Ms Allen Remedios Adolfo, 38, in Singapore. Murugadass allegedly used a penknife to slash her face, wrist, and throat, resulting in deep wounds with permanent scars. The attack is believed to have occurred because Murugadass was the ex-boyfriend of the victim, who was returning to her employer's home. Murugadass is remanded at Bedok police division for a week for further investigation and faces up to 15 years in jail if convicted.

site_title: New Australian air force chief visits Singapore, calls on Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen
summary: The Royal Australian Air Force's new chief, Air Marshal Leo Davies, has completed his introductory visit to Singapore, calling on Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and other officials. As part of his visit, Davies visited Sembawang Air Base and took a familiarization flight on a Super Puma helicopter. The visit highlights the close defence relations between Singapore and Australia, with both air forces engaging in regular bilateral and multilateral training exercises and professional exchanges. The two air forces aim to strengthen and enhance bilateral defence ties and explore new initiatives for military training and cooperation.

site_title: Ministerial Committee on Ageing unveils $3 billion national plan to keep seniors active
summary: The Ministerial Committee on Ageing has unveiled a $3 billion national plan to keep seniors active over five years. The Action Plan for Successful Ageing includes subsidized classes, volunteer opportunities, and infrastructure improvements to promote active lives. Initiatives include senior-friendly facilities, such as therapeutic parks and ageless workplaces, as well as programs like the President's Challenge to encourage volunteering. The plan aims to delay the onset of dementia and improve quality of life for seniors, with a focus on skills development, accessibility, and research.

site_title: Mum taught me to confront my emotions, emerging Singapore writer says of her mother, poet Leong Liew Geok
summary: Singaporean writer Teh Su Ching, 30, has found inspiration in her mother, poet Leong Liew Geok. The duo recently shared the stage at a writers' session, with Teh reading her own poetry and expressing her emotions. Leong, 68, has two poetry collections and is working on her third, while Teh has started writing poetry herself after her mother's influence. Teh credits her mother with teaching her to confront her emotions and express herself through writing, a trait she now shares with her mother.

site_title: Tanorexia: When getting a tan becomes an addiction
summary: In Spain, a growing number of people are developing an addiction to getting a tan, dubbed "tanorexia." The condition is characterized by a desire to tan on waking, needing increasingly bigger doses, feelings of anxiety when not tanning, and annoyance when others comment on excessive tanning. Experts compare the symptoms to those of heroin addiction. Researchers say that exposure to ultraviolet rays can be addictive, releasing endorphins that produce feelings of relaxation and euphoria. As a result, tanning salons have become a popular destination, despite the World Health Organization's classification of UV-emitting tanning devices as carcinogenic to humans.

summary: Potential candidates for Singapore's 2015 general election began collecting nomination papers at the Elections Department's headquarters on August 26. At least three individuals, including private car driver Shirwin Eu, real estate executive Ooi Boon Ewe, and former businessman Zeng Guoyuan, confirmed their intention to stand as independent candidates. Members from various political parties also picked up documents, with the Singapore Democratic Party and Workers' Party submitting their candidates' Political Donation Certificates. Nomination Day is set for September 1, with Polling Day on September 11.

South Korea had previously demanded an apology from North Korea as a precondition for lifting the sanctions, but has relaxed its stance. The talks aim to address a range of issues, including the lifting of sanctions and improving communication between the two nations.

summary: China and Japan are vying to build Indonesia's first high-speed railway, with both countries offering sweet deals and charm to win over Jakarta. China has promised a lower interest rate and a faster completion timeline, while Japan has a history of safe and reliable high-speed rail. The decision is expected to be made by President Joko Widodo, who has been courting both countries to secure investment for Indonesia's aging infrastructure.

site_title: Why markets are not impressed with China's rate cuts
summary: China's People's Bank of China cut its benchmark lending rate and reserve requirement ratio, but the market was unimpressed, with the Shanghai Composite down 1%. The reason is that interest rate cuts do not stimulate consumption in Asia, particularly among Chinese consumers, who are more likely to reduce spending to offset lower savings rates. Investment growth is also hindered by state-dominated companies, and government spending is seen as a potential solution, but the state's track record of stimulus packages has been disappointing, leading to higher non-performing loans.

site_title: Obama says sorry to Japan after WikiLeaks claims of US spying
summary: US President Barack Obama apologized to Japan for alleged US spying on Japanese politicians, following WikiLeaks' claims of years-long NSA espionage. In a telephone conversation with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Obama expressed regret and agreed to work together on global economic issues. The US and Japan will collaborate on addressing market turmoil sparked by China's yuan devaluation, which has led to a global equities sell-off. Obama also reiterated support for Abe's speech on Japan's World War II record, despite criticism from China and South Korea.

site_title: Yuan declines after China central bank cuts interest rates
summary: China's yuan declined to a two-week low after the central bank lowered borrowing costs in a surprise move. The People's Bank of China reduced interest rates by 25 basis points each and trimmed the reserve-requirement ratio by 50 basis points, effective September 6. The yuan fell 0.26% to 6.4293 USD before trading down 0.18% at 6.4240. Analysts say the move may not be sufficient to curb the currency's depreciation, with some predicting further weakness.

summary: Crude oil futures fell to near six-and-a-half-year lows due to lingering concerns about the Chinese economy, which received support from the country's central bank. Oil prices rose slightly, with Brent trading at $43.22 a barrel, but US October crude fell to $39.25 a barrel. Analysts predict that the market will remain oversupplied in the short term, with some emerging markets experiencing a slowdown in demand. Policymakers in top Opec producer Saudi Arabia have remained silent, but support is growing among non-Gulf members for action.

summary: The Malaysian Road Transport Department (JPJ) acknowledged teething problems with the online registration of foreign vehicles for the Vehicle Entry Permit (VEP), which began on Aug 15. Despite receiving over a dozen daily enquiries, booths have not been set up at the Causeway or Second Link for in-person registration. The JPJ is addressing issues such as complicated registration forms, and has announced that the VEP registration can only be done online at www.jpj.gov.my/vep. The Transport Ministry is working to resolve the issues, with the goal of implementing the VEP at more road entry points in stages.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB denies Abu Dhabi's IPIC pulling out of debt restructuring plan
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund has denied that Abu Dhabi's IPIC is pulling out of a debt restructuring plan. The fund stated it remains engaged in discussions with IPIC, contrary to a report citing a source that said IPIC is considering withdrawing from the plan. This news follows allegations of financial mismanagement and graft surrounding 1MDB's $11 billion in debt, which has led to multiple investigations. The report's impact has seen the Malaysian ringgit drop to a new low against the Singapore currency and a 17-year low to the US dollar.

site_title: China to restrict stock index futures trading to curb speculation: Exchange
summary: China's China Financial Futures Exchange will restrict trading in stock index futures to curb speculation. The measures, announced on Tuesday, include raising margin requirements, restricting daily open positions, and including transaction fees. The restrictions come after the futures contracts slumped by 10% for two consecutive days. The changes will take effect on Wednesday, aiming to reduce speculation and stabilize the market.

site_title: Thailand's 'no-plastic bag' policy should be more than 'temporary packaging': The Nation
summary: Thailand aims to become a plastic-bag-free nation by implementing a one-day moratorium on plastic bag usage at supermarkets, convenience stores, and large malls every 15th of the month. As part of an agreement with retailers, shoppers are encouraged to bring their own reusable bags, with some retailers having already reduced their plastic bag usage by 26.4% in the first year. The policy's success depends on shopper cooperation, and experts emphasize the need for a longer-term sustainable living ethos and collective awareness to address the country's growing plastic waste problem.

site_title: GE2015: PAP introduces 2 new faces in Nee Soon GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has announced two new candidates for the Nee Soon Group Representation Constituency (GRC) in the upcoming general election. Louis Ng, an animal rights activist and CEO of Animal Concerns Research and Education Society, and Henry Kwek, an executive director of FoodTraco Supplies, will join two-term MP Lee Bee Wah and Parliamentary Secretary Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim in the five-member team. The new team aims to bring exciting plans to Nee Soon in the next five years, including upgrading town facilities and addressing issues such as volunteerism and community engagement.

The concert will be filmed and aired as part of a new xinyao-themed drama, "Crescendo," which debuts in October. Liang, a Cultural Medallion recipient, aims to innovate and engage new audiences, while Wong Hong Mok and composer Lee Wei Song will also perform. The concert will take place on November 14 at The Max Pavilion, with a setlist still in the works.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.86% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.86% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index at 2,861.51, down 24.78 points. Around 503.4 million shares were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 117 to 67.

site_title: Hack of adultery website Ashley Madison strikes fear in users
summary: A massive data breach on Ashley Madison, a website for people seeking extramarital affairs, has led to online extortion attempts and has been linked to at least two suicides. The breach exposed the data of 32 million users, including account details of at least two individuals who have come forward to speak about their experiences. The hackers, known as the "Impact Team," are offering a $500,000 reward for information leading to their arrest. The incident has sparked fears among users, particularly those in the military and those with jobs in conservative industries, and has raised concerns about online privacy and the consequences of infidelity.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang swings to Q4 loss from weaker sales in Hong Kong, Malaysia
summary: Traditional Chinese medicine retailer Eu Yan Sang International reported a net loss of $3.6 million for the fourth quarter ended June 30, 2015, due to weaker sales in Hong Kong and Malaysia. The company attributed the decline to macro-environmental challenges and a 6% goods and services tax in Malaysia. In contrast, Singapore and Australia saw revenue increases, with Australia expected to show a turnaround by FY2016. Eu Yan Sang remains cautious on its business outlook and plans to rationalize weak-performing retail outlets and focus on improving efficiency through technology.

site_title: US serviceman who foiled French train attack to earn army's top non-combat award
summary: Aleksander Skarlatos, an Oregon National Guardsman, will receive the US Army's Soldier's Medal for his role in foiling a French train attack. Skarlatos, along with two friends and other passengers, subdued a gunman who emerged from a bathroom on a high-speed train. Skarlatos' actions were hailed as heroic, and he was awarded the medal "for extraordinary heroism above and beyond the call of duty". French President Francois Hollande also awarded the Legion d'Honneur medal to the American friends and a British man who assisted in the incident.

summary: Malaysia's Natural Resources and Environment Minister Datuk Seri Dr Wan Junaidi Tuanku Jaafar will meet his Indonesian counterpart to discuss haze pollution from open burning in Indonesia affecting parts of Malaysia. The issue has led to recurring haze in Sarawak, with satellite images detecting 192 hotspots in Indonesia, including 22 in Kalimantan. Malaysia has urged Indonesia to do more to tackle the fires, and the two countries are set to negotiate a bilateral prevention programme on transboundary haze pollution.

site_title: Ringgit hits new low, goes below 3.05 against Singapore dollar
summary: The Malaysian ringgit plummeted to a new low below 3.05 against the Singapore dollar, trading at 3.0470 at 8:37 am. The currency has weakened over 18% in 2015 due to a slowing economy, a political scandal, and the devaluation of the yuan. It has also slumped to a 17-year low against the US dollar, trading at 4.2875. The ringgit's freefall has sparked a surge in demand for the currency in Singapore, with some money changers running out of stock.

site_title: Hiker sustains burns after jumping into Idaho hot spring to save dog
summary: A hiker in Idaho suffered severe burns after jumping into a hot spring to rescue his dog, which had fallen into the scalding water. The incident occurred at the Panther Creek Hot Springs, where temperatures had apparently risen due to drought conditions. The hiker managed to save one dog and was airlifted to a hospital for treatment of his burns. Forest officials say the incident highlights the importance of testing hot spring temperatures before use, and they plan to inform the public to prevent similar tragedies.

site_title: What on earth is going on in China? Even top mining CEOs can't agree
summary: Top mining CEOs, including Andrew Mackenzie of BHP Billiton and Ivan Glasenberg of Glencore, are at odds over China's economic future, with Mackenzie expressing confidence in the country's ability to adapt, while Glasenberg admits he can't "read" China's current situation. China's economic woes, including a slowdown in growth and a plummeting stock market, have shaken global markets, and investors are worried about the long-term impact on raw materials and mining companies. Despite this, some CEOs remain optimistic about China's long-term demand for commodities.

site_title: France train attack suspect charged with attempted murder of terrorist nature
summary: A Moroccan man, Ayoub El Khazzani, has been charged with attempted murder of a terrorist nature for launching a premeditated attack on a high-speed French train. El Khazzani, 25, was armed with a Kalashnikov rifle and ammunition, and was subdued by off-duty US servicemen and a British consultant. Prosecutors say the attack was "targeted and premeditated" and that El Khazzani had grown increasingly evasive in his responses to police. He faces charges of attempted murder, terrorism, and participation in a terrorist association.

site_title: China shares end down 1.27% despite rate cut as European markets join nervous Asia on roller-coaster, STI closes 0.4% lower
summary: China's stock markets closed down 1.27% on Wednesday, despite the People's Bank of China's interest rate cut and loosening of bank lending restrictions. The CSI300 index fell 0.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.3%. European markets also declined, with the Straits Times Index closing 0.4% lower. Analysts attribute the market's reaction to the central bank's move to investors' caution, citing concerns about the economy's slowdown and the need for more significant policy support to restore investor sentiment.

site_title: Malaysian police say Bersih 4 rally is illegal
summary: Malaysian police have declared the Bersih 4 rally planned for this weekend as illegal due to the organisers' failure to issue a complete notice to the police. The police had asked the organisers to submit a detailed plan of the routes and venues by August 16, but they failed to comply. The police are now planning for security and traffic control, and the Malaysian Bar has deployed an "urgent arrest team" to provide legal assistance in case of arrests. The rally's planned venues at Dataran Merdeka and Padang Merbok have also been rejected by the Kuala Lumpur City Hall.

site_title: GE2015: PAP unveils its slate for Marine Parade GRC
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) unveiled its candidate slate for Marine Parade Group Representative Constituency (GRC) on August 26, 2015, with a five-man team consisting of Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin, and veteran backbenchers Fatimah Lateef and Seah Kian Peng. Edwin Tong, a first-term MP, will represent the Joo Chiat division. The team emphasized their focus on creating a caring community and providing reliable leadership, with Tan Chuan-Jin appealing to voters to support the PAP. The team's strategy includes supporting Edwin Tong in Joo Chiat and highlighting their record in providing good healthcare and housing.

This milestone marks Spain's first time having five teams in the Champions League group stage simultaneously.

site_title: Man on trial over alleged rape on Sentosa
summary: A 26-year-old former Sentosa lifeguard, Pram Nair, is on trial for raping a 20-year-old relief teacher at Siloso Beach in 2012. The woman, now 23, was intoxicated after attending a beach party and was found motionless on the beach with police. Nair faces one count of rape and one of sexual assault, both carrying up to 20 years' jail. Prosecutors claim Nair took the woman to the beach, sexually violated her, and she tried to push him away. The trial, scheduled for 11 days, continues.

site_title: Junior chefs over the moon
summary: Twenty kids from the Singapore Children's Society, aged nine, participated in a mooncake-making party at Orchard Hotel's Hua Ting Restaurant, sponsored by the Hong Leong Foundation. Master Chef Chung Lap Fai and Kwek Eik Sheng guided the children in creating their own snowskin mooncakes, which they then enjoyed as part of a high tea spread. The event aimed to provide a fun and educational experience for the young participants, with the mooncakes being taken home as a keepsake.

images.alt_text: Muhammad Izzat Mohd Ismail (left) and Zulqarnain Mohd Zainuddin, both nine, having a fun time learning to make snowskin mooncakes. They were among 20 kids from the Singapore Children's Society being treated by Hong Leong Foundation to a mooncake-maki

site_title: Man charged with sexually abusing young niece
summary: A 51-year-old Malaysian construction firm supervisor has appeared in the High Court charged with six counts of sexually abusing his 12- to 15-year-old niece, whom he had considered a "father figure". The alleged abuse occurred between 2005 and 2008, including one count of rape, which carries up to 20 years' jail and caning. The victim, now 23, has admitted to the charge of sexual assault and is set to testify in a seven-day trial, with the prosecution alleging he abused his position to groom and sexually assault her without her consent.

site_title: Call to mandate reporting of data breaches
summary: Singapore is urged to mandate reporting of data breaches, a move already adopted by countries like the US and Canada. Experts, including F-Secure's Mikko Hypponen and Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission chairman Leong Keng Thai, argue that transparency is crucial for consumers. The country's Personal Data Protection Act, which came into force in July, does not require reporting of breaches. The requirement is seen as a natural progression, but may not be implemented immediately due to complexity and the need for guidance.

site_title: Richest man in Asia Wang Jianlin loses S$18 billion in China crash
summary: China's stock market crash has led to a significant loss of wealth for Asia's richest man, Wang Jianlin, estimated to be around US$18 billion (S$26 billion). His publicly traded companies, Wanda Dalian Commercial Properties and Wanda Cinema Line, have plummeted in value, with shares falling by 38%, 36%, and 49% respectively. Wang's wealth had surged to US$42.6 billion earlier this year, surpassing Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-Shing as Asia's richest man. The losses are attributed to the recent volatility in the stock market and the performance of his companies since June.

Shanmugam attended the event, emphasizing the importance of preserving cultural identity while growing as a country, and highlighting the role of ITEs in developing specialized skills through SkillsFuture.

site_title: The kind uncle
summary: A Singaporean man, Mr Rimy Lau, 68, was commended for his kind act towards three foreign construction workers on a train. When they tried to give up their seats to men, Mr Lau encouraged them to stay and offered words of kindness, saying they didn't always have to give up their seats. The incident sparked discussion on how Singaporeans treat foreign workers and was shared over 800,000 times on social media, with many praising Mr Lau's gesture as a step towards recognizing migrant workers as deserving of respect and gratitude.

Lim, 43, joins SMRT next month and will focus on government relations and business development. His appointment aims to strengthen ties with the Ministry of Transport and Land Transport Authority, which regulate the transport industry. With nearly $2.7 billion in funds across six funds, GGV has invested in companies like Xiaomi and Alibaba, and Lee has recently invested in smart notebook and drone start-ups, including Xiaoniu and EHang.

site_title: Engineer jailed 8 months for molesting 2 teens
summary: A Singaporean air force engineer, Andrew Teng Ye Feng, was jailed for 8 months for molesting two teenagers. He pleaded guilty to two charges of molestation, touching a 13-year-old girl's breast on a bus and brushing against her buttocks in a lift. Teng had been suspended from duty since October last year and had sought psychiatric treatment. The court heard that he committed the offences out of "mischief" and had no understanding of his actions. The maximum punishment for molestation below 14 is five years' jail, a fine, and caning.

site_title: What's News: August, 26 2015
summary: Key GE dates announced for Singapore's election, with Nomination Day on September 1 and Polling Day on September 11. The election is seen as critical for the country. A deal was struck between North and South Korea to improve ties and reunite families separated by the Korean War. Deforestation is occurring at a faster rate than thought, with tropical forests set to be destroyed in the next 35 years, posing a threat to climate change.

site_title: Exam students evacuated after fire at S'pore Poly
summary: A fire at Singapore Polytechnic (SP) yesterday, the fourth in three years, forced the evacuation of around 350 people, including 300 students taking exams. The blaze was contained by the school's emergency team, but three security guards were taken to the hospital for smoke inhalation. Students who did not complete their exam papers will have to retake them next week. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) is investigating the cause of the fire, and SP has assured that upcoming lessons and exams will not be affected.

Dr Lee had introduced various initiatives to improve quality, affordability, and accessibility in the pre-school sector, including new career progression pathways and training opportunities. Mr Leong brings experience from the Ministry of National Development and has a background in economics and public administration.

site_title: SCDF dealt with fewer fires in first half of year
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) responded to 2,406 fire calls in the first six months of the year, a 5% decrease from the same period last year. Most fires involved residences, with a 1.7% drop in home fires. The most common causes were dropped light cases, unattended cooking, and discarded items. Non-residential premises saw a 25% decrease in incidents. Four deaths and 29 injuries were reported, with 31 cases of smoke inhalation. The SCDF increased fire safety checks to over 8,000, emphasizing public reporting of fire safety violations.

site_title: GE2015: Top concerns likely bread-and-butter issues, immigration, say observers
summary: Singaporeans are likely to focus on bread-and-butter issues and immigration concerns when voting in the upcoming general election on September 11. Political observers believe these issues, including rising costs of living, transport, and jobs, will be prominent in the election campaign. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and the largest opposition party, the Workers' Party (WP), are framing the election in different ways, with the PAP highlighting financial lapses at the WP's town council and the WP calling for more opposition MPs. Experts say these issues may not be the game-changers both sides hope for, and voters may focus on broader concerns like government efficiency and cost of living.

site_title: Labour relief for SMEs
summary: The Manpower Ministry (MOM) in Singapore has announced the Lean Enterprise Development Scheme, providing temporary relief to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) undergoing restructuring. The scheme allows SMEs to hold onto more skilled foreign workers on S Passes while shedding manual workers on work permits. This deviation from a one-size-fits-all approach and willingness to consider feedback signals a shift towards supporting local SMEs, which are heavily impacted by the labor shortage. The scheme can last up to three years and offers priority to SMEs with unions and industry association backing.

site_title: GE2015: Can PAP crack its performance paradox?
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is facing a performance paradox ahead of the 2015 General Election, as its impressive policy record may be overshadowed by the opposition's claims of credit for achievements. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong highlighted the PAP's 50-year track record of leading Singapore, while Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam argued that the party's inclusive growth agenda predates the 2011 General Election. The opposition, particularly the Workers' Party, may still be in a strong position, particularly among swing voters, who may view the PAP's policies as responsive to public discontent. The election outcome will determine who can best represent Singapore for the next five years.

site_title: Man suspected of slashing maid held
summary: A 41-year-old man accused of slashing the throat, wrist, and palm of his former girlfriend, 38-year-old maid Allen Remedios, has been arrested. Remedios suffered deep gashes to her left hand and throat during the attack on Sunday evening while returning to her employer's flat in Tampines. The assailant, believed to be her former boyfriend, a construction worker, was stopped by Remedios on the first storey and fled. Remedios was taken to hospital and later transferred to Singapore General Hospital, where she required a blood transfusion. The suspect will be charged in court for allegedly hurting Remedios.

site_title: Final farewell for Singaporean victim in Bangkok blast
summary: A Singaporean victim, 34-year-old Ms Melisa Liu Rui Chun, was killed in a deadly bomb explosion at the Erawan Shrine in Bangkok last Monday. Her husband, Mr Ng Su Teck, who sustained burns and injuries, bid a final farewell to her at a private church funeral. Over 100 mourners, including family, friends, and colleagues, attended the somber ceremony, with many expressing shock and grief at the sudden loss of the "easy-going" and "cheerful" woman. A taxi driver who may have driven the suspected bomber away was being questioned by Thai police.

site_title: Ambulance calls surge with ageing population
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) reported a 7.4% increase in ambulance calls in the first six months of the year, with 81,686 calls made between January and June. This is the highest figure in 15 years, attributed to an ageing population. To cope, the SCDF plans to increase its fleet of emergency ambulances from 50 to 80 by 2018. Non-emergency calls, accounting for 4% of the total, have more than doubled, prompting the SCDF to urge the public to treat its staff with respect and to report any abuse.

site_title: Aiming to help the vulnerable
summary: SDP candidate Chong Wai Fung, 45, has announced his candidacy for the party. A treasurer and administrator at Ren Ci Nursing Home, Chong holds a Master of Public Health and Master of Business Administration from the National University of Singapore and University of Adelaide, respectively. He aims to focus on helping vulnerable people, citing his nursing background and passion for improving healthcare policies. Chong believes he can make a greater impact in Parliament, influencing policies that affect many people at once. He is the first SDP candidate mentioned in the article.

site_title: Opposition starts candidate introductions
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) has introduced two of its 11 election candidates, including accounts manager Khung Wai Yeen, 34, and administrator Ms Chong Wai Fung, 45. The move comes just one hour after the Writ of Election was issued, with the SDP citing a desire to "quicken the pace" before Parliament's dissolution. Other opposition parties, including the Workers' Party and Singapore People's Party, have also announced their candidates, with the election set to take place on Nomination Day next Tuesday.

site_title: Opposition's approach more guarded
summary: The opposition parties in Singapore, particularly the Workers' Party (WP), are adopting a defensive strategy ahead of the Sept 11 General Election, contrasting with their approach in 2011. The WP has decided to keep its Aljunied team intact, defending its turf rather than expanding or attacking. This defensive stance may limit their chances of good results, as playing defensive rarely wins games. The WP's strategy is also reflected in its handling of criticism over the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council finances. Other opposition parties, such as the National Solidarity Party (NSP), are also preoccupied with defending their reputations, which may further hinder their chances.

site_title: Fengshan, Punggol East the SMCs to watch
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has named its candidates for 11 out of 13 single-seat constituencies in the upcoming General Election, leaving only Fengshan and Punggol East to be contested. The two constituencies are expected to see tough fights, with Fengshan possibly being contested by the Workers' Party (WP) and Punggol East being defended by the WP's Ms Lee Li Lian. MacPherson SMC is likely to see a three-cornered fight between the WP, National Solidity Party (NSP), and an independent candidate. The PAP has introduced new faces in most SMCs, but not in Fengshan, sparking speculation about its strategy.

images.alt_text: Mr Andy Zhu, chairman of the Reform Party, gearing up for the election campaign period at the party's office yesterday. The party had plans to visit homes in Ang Mo Kio yesterday, but cancelled them after learning that the Writ of Election had been issued

site_title: Bigger Baby Bonus and Medisave grant for newborns
summary: Singapore is increasing its Baby Bonus cash gift and Medisave grant for newborns. The Baby Bonus will now be $8,000 for the first two children and $10,000 for subsequent children, with the first $2,000 given at 15 months and the rest at 18 months. The Medisave grant for newborns will be raised to $4,000, covering MediShield Life premiums and medical expenses until the child is 21. The measures, announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, aim to support couples in caring for their children and will be implemented from next January.

site_title: 10 issues for GE 2015
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

As Singapore prepares for the 2015 General Election, several key issues have emerged, including leadership succession, economic concerns, security threats, immigration, transport, housing, cost of living, and checks on the dominant party's power. The ruling party, PAP, is expected to focus on issues like the Workers' Party's management of town councils and checks on its power. The election campaign is also likely to be influenced by global events, such as China's currency devaluation and the Islamic State threat. With a mix of old and new issues, voters are expected to head to the polls with diverse concerns.

site_title: Ng Wai Choong to announce election results on Polling Day
summary: Senior civil servant Ng Wai Choong, 49, will announce the results of the upcoming polls on Polling Day after the last ballot is cast and all votes are counted. Appointed Returning Officer in April 2013, Ng previously supervised elections in 2011, including the General Election and by-elections. He will oversee poll conduct and head the polling station officials.

site_title: Candidates' election deposit set at $14,500
summary: The election deposit for Singapore's upcoming general election has been lowered to $14,500, a decrease of $1,500 from the previous amount. This change is similar to the deposit amount in the 2013 Punggol East by-election. The deposit is 8% of the total allowances paid to a Member of Parliament in the preceding year. Candidates who receive less than 12.5% of the votes will forfeit their deposit. Nomination papers can be collected from Monday and must be submitted by noon on Nomination Day.

site_title: Key GRC battles pit PAP against WP
summary: The 2015 Singapore general election is expected to be closely watched, with several key Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) pitting the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) against the opposition Workers' Party (WP). The PAP and WP are expected to clash in East Coast GRC, where the WP is likely to send its second "A" team, led by Gerald Giam. The PAP team, led by Lim Swee Say, will face off against a slate of office-holders and business leaders. In other GRCs, the PAP and WP are expected to face off in Marine Parade GRC, where the WP is challenging the incumbent team, and Tanjong Pagar GRC, where the PAP is fielding a new team led by Chan Chun Sing. The election is seen as a key test of the PAP's strength in the face of growing opposition.

site_title: Flurry of activity as party activists and volunteers spring into action
summary: Activists and volunteers for various Singaporean parties sprang into action as Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the next general election, with the PAP, opposition parties, and independent candidates finalizing plans and preparations. The election, set for September 11, marks the culmination of months of preparation, with parties setting up election teams, gathering intelligence, and preparing campaign materials. The opposition parties, including the SDP and WP, are also gearing up, with the SDP introducing two new candidates and the WP unveiling its candidates today.

summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) candidate Khung Wai Yeen, a 34-year-old former naval specialist, has announced his candidacy for the upcoming election. Yeen, an accounts manager, joined the SDP due to its thorough research on its 2011 Shadow Budget paper. His policy focus areas include housing and healthcare, considering them essential for every person. As a family man, Yeen prioritizes his wife and three-year-old daughter, and enjoys weekend outings to the Marina Barrage with his family.

site_title: Renewed PAP all set for 2015 election campaign
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is gearing up for the 2015 election campaign, focusing on its "residents first" mantra to shed its image of being out of touch. The party has introduced new candidates in heartland settings, with most having volunteered on the ground for months or years before their political debut. PAP leaders have emphasized the importance of securing the next 50 years of leadership and have adopted a welcoming posture, engaging with socio-political websites and social media to improve its image. The party's campaign has been designed to have "very few surprises," but its strategy for contesting Workers' Party-held constituencies remains unclear.
