site_title: 15 symbols for independents
summary: Singapore's Elections Department has approved 15 symbols for use by independent candidates in the upcoming general election, including a ceiling fan, rhinoceros, and whale. The list includes a custom-designed red horse symbol by former National Solidarity Party chief Tan Lam Siong. Candidates can choose from the approved symbols, which must not have racial or religious significance, and will be displayed during campaigning and on ballot papers. The general election is set to take place on September 11.

site_title: Nominate S'porean heroes for new ST award
summary: The Straits Times is launching the Singaporean Of The Year 2015 award to recognize individuals who have made a positive impact in their community. The award, supported by UBS Singapore, will be given to those whose extraordinary acts of goodwill have improved the lives of others. The public can nominate individuals until December 31, and a shortlist of 10 candidates will be announced in January. A panel of 15 judges, including editors, writers, and celebrities, will select the winner, who will receive $20,000 and a trophy.

site_title: Jurong Region Line may be extended to join Circle Line
summary: Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew announced that the Jurong Region Line, a 20km MRT line in the west, may be extended to join the Circle Line at Haw Par Villa station. The extension, if feasible, would be completed by 2030, providing residents with another way to get to the CBD. The line is expected to serve areas like Choa Chu Kang, Jurong East, and NTU, and will offer a direct connection into the downtown area, making life more convenient for commuters.

site_title: Football: Fellaini set for advanced Man United role: Van Gaal
summary: Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has announced that Marouane Fellaini will play predominantly in attacking positions this season, citing the midfielder's goal-scoring potential as a solution to the team's struggles in front of goal. Fellaini has been used in various roles for the team, including central midfielder and striker, but Van Gaal plans to utilize him more in attacking positions. The Belgian international's goal in the Champions League play-off round against Club Brugge has given him a chance to push for a starting role in the return match.

site_title: Locating SIT in Punggol 'a sensible move'
summary: The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) will build its centralised campus in Punggol, a sensible move due to the estate's available space. Experts praise the decision, citing infrastructure developments in the pipeline that will support student commuting. The campus will feature facilities, including classrooms, workshops, and a multi-purpose hall, and will be linked to a creative industry cluster. While concerns about transport infrastructure and pressure on surrounding facilities are raised, experts and residents express optimism about the benefits of the new campus, including increased business activity and improved university experience.

site_title: Extra paternity leave may be mandatory in a few years' time
summary: Singapore is considering making extra paternity leave mandatory in a few years' time, following the government's announcement to double paternity leave to 16 weeks, backdated to this year. The extra week will be voluntary for now, but employers and unions will be discussed before any changes are made. The government will cover the cost of the extra week, capped at $2,500 per week, and encourages bigger companies to take the lead in offering the extra week. The aim is to set a competitive trend in the employment market and attract better people and retain good staff.

site_title: Singapore goes to the polls on Sept 11
summary: Singapore will hold its 12th general election on September 11, the first time since 1997 that a general election will be held on a weekday. The election comes amid a backdrop of global economic uncertainty, with concerns over global security and the anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is expected to face a strong challenge from opposition parties, with the Workers' Party targeting 28 seats. The election is seen as a critical test for the PAP, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong seeking to renew and reinforce the party's slate in Parliament.

site_title: US markets rally fizzles as China worries persist
summary: US markets closed down 1.35% on Tuesday, despite a strong initial rally, as investors locked in gains and took cover from potential turmoil. The decline followed Monday's 4% plunge, wiping $2.7 trillion off global equity values. The People's Bank of China's rate cut raised hopes for China's economy, with most Asian markets closing up, except Shanghai and Tokyo. Analysts warn that emerging-market economies are most vulnerable to the uncertainty, and a global recession cannot be ruled out.

site_title: Spain detects first case of mosquito-borne chikungunya virus
summary: Spain has reported its first domestic case of the mosquito-borne viral disease chikungunya, a 60-year-old man in Valencia, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. The man was likely infected in a seaside resort in Gandia and treated in hospital last month. This marks the first case of chikungunya in Spain without travel history to endemic areas, following 266 imported cases last year. The disease, typically not fatal, can cause debilitating symptoms including fever, headache, and severe joint pain lasting months.

site_title: Victims want no comforts for Colorado movie gunman
summary: Colorado movie gunman James Holmes will spend life in prison after being found guilty of murdering 12 people and wounding 70 in a 2012 rampage. Survivors and victims' families have made demands, including a televised apology, study by mental illness experts, and a PhD for Holmes to do "amazing things for humanity" while incarcerated. Some victims' families, however, have rejected such offers, including one who wants no contact from family or friends. The jury's decision not to reach a unanimous verdict on execution led to 12 automatic life sentences.

summary: Oscar-winning actress Julianne Moore is leading a petition drive to rename her Virginia high school, J.E.B. Stuart High, which honors a Confederate general, in honor of civil rights leader Thurgood Marshall. The school has gathered nearly 30,000 signatures and needs 5,000 more to reach its goal of 35,000. Moore and producer Robert Cohen, who attended the school in the 1970s, argue that the school's name represents racism and are seeking to rename it. The effort is part of a growing trend of protests against Confederate symbols in the US.

site_title: Gene study confirms low vitamin D, multiple sclerosis link
summary: A major genetic study has confirmed a link between low vitamin D levels and a higher risk of multiple sclerosis (MS), a debilitating autoimmune disease. The study, published in PLOS Medicine, analyzed data from 14,498 people with MS and 24,091 healthy controls, finding that those with genetically lower vitamin D levels face double the risk of developing MS. Experts say the findings could lead to better treatment and prevention, but further clinical trials are needed to confirm the relationship between vitamin D and MS. The study suggests that vitamin D deficiency may cause or contribute to the development of MS.

summary: Justin Wilson, a 37-year-old British IndyCar driver, died after being struck by debris during a Sunday race in Pennsylvania. His organs were donated, saving six lives. The incident has led to calls for a review of safety measures in IndyCar, with some suggesting that the sport should focus on continuous improvement and driver input to address potential safety concerns. Wilson's death marks the first fatality in IndyCar since 2011 and has sparked a renewed focus on safety.

site_title: Baby, policeman among four killed in French gypsy camp shooting
summary: A man shot and killed four people, including a six-month-old baby and a policeman, at a gypsy camp in northern France on Tuesday. The victims were killed "in cold blood," according to Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve. Three others, including the gunman, were seriously wounded. The policeman who was wounded later died of his injuries, and a three-year-old child and another policeman were in serious condition. The attack occurred after a fight erupted in the camp, and the gunman may have been intoxicated. President Francois Hollande and Prime Minister Manuel Valls expressed shock and condolences to the families of the victims.

This incident is the latest in a series of protests against SeaWorld since the 2013 documentary "Blackfish" exposed the company's treatment of orcas. Glover has a history of performing stunts and has been cited for previous violations.

site_title: Archaeologists unearth ancient Greek palace near Sparta
summary: Archaeologists in southern Greece have discovered the ruins of an ancient palace near Sparta, dating back to the 17th-16th centuries BC. The palace, with 10 rooms, features important inscriptions on tablets in Linear B, the oldest script in Europe, and objects of worship, including clay figurines and murals. The discovery will aid research on the Mycenaean people's beliefs, language systems, and societal organization. Over 150 archaeological excavations were carried out in Greece this year, highlighting the country's rich cultural heritage.

site_title: Turkey to join coalition's air fight against ISIS soon: Pentagon
summary: The US and Turkey have finalized an agreement for Turkey to join the international coalition's air strikes against ISIS. The plan fully integrates Turkey into the US-led efforts, allowing for the country's participation in air strikes against the militant group. It may take a few days to implement the technical arrangements, and both countries are continuing to discuss border operations. Turkey's commitment to fully participating in the coalition is expected, with the goal of bringing down ISIS soon.

site_title: Bob Dylan's 'Hard Rain' lyrics to be auctioned in London
summary: A draft of Bob Dylan's 1962 lyrics for "A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall" is set to be auctioned in London next month, with an estimated value of up to 200,000 pounds. The typewritten manuscript contains revisions and scratchings-out, and features a notable change to the final chorus. The song, written by Dylan at 21, has been speculated to be inspired by the Cuban Missile Crisis, although its origins remain unclear. The auction will take place on September 29 alongside Bruce Springsteen memorabilia from his 1975 album Born to Run.

summary: A UN report reveals that South Sudanese soldiers raped children, burned people alive, and hunted others in swamps in an ongoing conflict. The violence, part of a government offensive, targeted civilians and aimed to render communal life unviable. The report, based on a copy of an emergency $850 million military budget, warns of a "scorched earth policy" and "depth of antipathy" that goes beyond political differences. The UN aid chief says the cruelty suggests a need for an arms embargo, with a US-drafted resolution set to be discussed by the 15-member Security Council.

site_title: Russia court jails Ukrainian filmmaker Oleg Sentsov for 'terrorism'
summary: A Russian military court has sentenced Ukrainian filmmaker Oleg Sentsov to 20 years in a high-security penal colony on terror charges, in a trial condemned by Kiev, Western rights groups, and top film directors. Sentsov was convicted of masterminding arson attacks on pro-Kremlin party offices in Crimea after Russia's annexation of the peninsula from Ukraine. Fellow defendant Alexander Kolchenko was sentenced to 10 years. The US and EU have condemned the trial as a "clear miscarriage of justice" and "breach of international law". Sentsov's lawyer has announced plans to appeal the sentence, calling it "the height of injustice and lawlessness".

site_title: U.S. services sector growth slows in August -Markit
summary: The US services sector expanded at a slower pace in August, with Markit's Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) dipping to 55.2 from 55.7 in July. New business growth softened, with a subindex measuring new business at service companies declining to 54.8, its lowest level since January. This signals a renewed slowdown in US service sector growth, according to Markit's senior economist, Tim Moore.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is seeking to bolster his defensive options, and Stones is expected to add depth to the team. Researchers are now focusing on finding ways to prevent Alzheimer's disease, which is expected to affect 131.5 million people worldwide by 2050.

site_title: GE2015: First time Polling Day falls on a Friday, but not first time polls held on a weekday
summary: Polling Day in Singapore's 12th general election will be held on September 11, a Friday, marking the first time the day falls on a weekday since the country's independence in 1965. This breaks a tradition of polling on Saturdays, except for three previous elections in 1976, 1980, and 1997, which also took place during the year-end festive period. The September date may be seen as a strategic move by the ruling People's Action Party to remind voters of global dangers and encourage wise decision-making.
